PETITION.TITLE: Chiropractic Services
PETITION.PARA: The Acting Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Chiropractic Services
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows -
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice and does nothing to reduce the high cost of health care in Australia.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropratic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr Cross,Mr Groom and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respecfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to R.A.A.F. Base Richmond would make operations impratical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers and parents working in and for the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia, respectfully showeth that:
1. We fully support the Federal Government's actions in reducing funds for the wealthiest private schools, and in breaking the nexus between government and non -government school costs.

2. We endorse the Federal Government's principled opposition to the provision of 'base grants' to all non-government schools, as a positive step towards fulfilling their commitment of primary obligation to Australia's government schools.

3. We call upon the Federal Government, however, to recognise that its failure to create an adequate general recurrent resource base for government schools through providing increased recurrent grants, will undermine its own special programs and thus frustrate its own stated educational objectives of greater equity and participation.

4. We support the Federal Government's stated policy of entering into direct negotiations for joint agreements on these grants with State/Territory Governments, to ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights in the Soviet Union
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that the Soviet Union continues to violate human rights in Latvia. This is clearly demonstrated by the recent case of Janis Rozkalns, a practising Baptist who, on January 6, 1983, had his house forcibly entered into by K.G.B. agents searching for various religious publications. The K.G.B. confiscated 40 Bibles.
Mr Rozkalns was charged with 'anti-Soviet agitation and propaganda' and now faces a sentence of seven years deprivation of freedom plus five years internal exile.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled condemns the religious and human rights persecutions within the Soviet Union.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Self-Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in November 1978 more than sixty-two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a Referendum rejected the introduction of Territorial Government or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a Referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to Territorial or Local Government.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action nor legislate in respect of Territorial or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows their concern for the present unresolved economic, social, biological, genetic, environmental and technical problems associated with the mining of uranium, the development of nuclear power and the proliferation of nuclear weapons.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will
1. prohibit the establishment in Australia of nuclear power plants and all other stages of the nuclear fuel cycle.
2. declare a moratorium on all mining and treatment of uranium in Australia.
3. prohibit the export of Australian uranium.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Immigration Policy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the Australian Government has an immigration policy emphasising family reunion.
However, the humanitarian motivations of the family reunion policy are lost if an 'assurance of support' for aged relatives forces families into traumatic reunions.
Therefore we urge that
1. Assurances of support should be abolished and all previous agreements declared null and void.
2. That permanent residence status should guarantee automatic right to all pensions and benefits providing applicants meet all other eligibility criteria.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Paterson's Curse
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of concerned people of the Electorate of Indi respectfully shows their desire to stop the spread of Paterson's Curse.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House (the Government) act to implement the biological control of Paterson's Curse.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain citizens of Queensland, Australia, respectfully showeth that we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Wynyard Airport, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Tasmania shows:
(a) We are shocked and disappointed at the Federal Government's decision not to upgrade the Wynyard Airport.
(b) This decision will inevitably lead to downgrading and closure of the Wynyard Airport.
(c) Closure of Wynyard Airport will cause grave hardship and inconvenience to the people of the North West and West Coast regions of Tasmania.
(d) We urge the Federal Government to immediately reverse this disastrous decision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill is a timely measure. It has as its emphasis the tidying up and updating of administrative procedures which the industry and the Opposition support. Given the broad title of the Bill and the wide-ranging second reading speech of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), it allows the Opposition to indicate the contribution the industry makes to the economic life and employment opportunities of Australia and the failure of the Government and the Minister to recognise this and to honour its election promises.

SPEECH.PARA: I will proceed to deal with these matters in order. The Minister indicated in his second reading speech that a comprehensive review of Commonwealth fisheries legislation was taking place. I remind him that he made this statement on 7 December last year and it is now almost four months later and we have heard no further mention of the review. I hope that the Minister has not put this on the back burner. I can understand why the Minister is not in the chamber, having myself experienced difficulties of time, but it is difficult for me to suggest certain things to him if he is not present. However, I do not wish to appear to be critical.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will pass them on to him.

—I thank the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism for offering to take these comments to the Minister for Primary Industry. I repeat that I hope that the Minister has not put this review of legislation on the back burner . I suggest to him that it is getting rather late in the day. The industry needs more than words; it is becoming impatient. The Opposition supports the changed licence arrangements and the consequent savings in administrative costs. May this be a blueprint for the future. We support also parliamentary scrutiny of fisheries notices and administrative review in relation to certain matters.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there is one matter which causes us concern. It relates to the situation where the Joint Authority delegates its power under section 12E(1) to a Commonwealth officer. The net result of this is that the Commonwealth officer takes over the powers of the Joint Authority. He becomes it, as it were. Herein lies the anomaly. Some of the States, quite rightly, are upset about this. Their reasoning is logical and understandable. The Commonwealth Government has acknowledged that the decisions of the joint authorities themselves will not be subject to appeal by this Commonwealth Government body. In those circumstances it seems strange that the delegate of such a body should have his actions subjected to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The basis of the new Commonwealth-State arrangements on off-shore matters is the free and equal participation of the governments which constitute the joint authorities. The principles of this arrangement are now incorporated in both State and Commonwealth legislation. I have been informed that the Federal Minister for Primary Industry endorsed these principles at the last meeting of the Australian Fisheries Council. I understand that at that meeting there was no mention of this review procedure. I believe that it is quite inappropriate for it to be incorporated in the Commonwealth Fisheries Act without the agreement of the State partners in the new off-shore fisheries management arrangement. The Hawke Government has been rather long in its words of co-operation with the States but rather short on sensitivity in achieving it. I ask the Minister to have a rethink about this section of the Bill. Joint authorities are usually held together within a rather fragile fabric and any weakening of that fabric can be disastrous.

The Opposition has no difficulty with the aims of that provision of the Bill which seeks to improve jobs in the ship repair industry. It would be irresponsible of us to oppose job opportunity for Australian workmen and women. However, I have a twofold problem. One is always just a little wary when a Minister speaks of unlicensed foreign fishing boats. The word 'unlicensed' can conjure up, rightly or wrongly, a type of second rate vessel in structure, performance or activities. I seek an assurance from the Minister that every precaution will be taken and that the vessel and its crew will be thoroughly screened. The risks are always high.

As a member of Parliament I receive many approaches from people who are worried about our surveillance, particularly in northern Australia. We do not want to make it easier for smugglers or drug runners to operate. In the former case, as was brought into rather clearer focus in what may have been but a hoax, the telegraphed release of foot and mouth virus, we need to be fully aware that our animal husbandry industries can be virtually wiped out through the importation of disease. Of course, that would be disastrous. It would be even more disastrous if the concessions granted by the Minister could be used by the drug running trade.

I would be very relieved indeed if the Minister would put my mind, and the minds of many Australians, to rest on this matter and assuage the strong fears I and many others have in relation to this very important area. I appreciate that the Minister has indicated that such fishing vessels will not be allowed in for routine matters. I support that. However, I am nervous about his total proposition. That nervousness was reinforced when I read an article in today's copy of the Australian. I will quote certain sections of the article. Mr Speaker , you will recall that last week the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) made an announcement concerning future surveillance operations in the northern part of Australia. The article in the Australian states:
The number of coastal surveillance flights in northern Australia will be significantly reduced in moves announced by the Federal Government last week.
Contracts with two air charter companies will not be renewed next month and surplus Royal Australian Navy Tracker aircraft will not be used for coastal surveillance.
The Government expects to reduce the cost of its surveillance program by cutting flying hours by about one third, but says its effectiveness will be maintained.
The reduction stems from a finding by the Federal Department of Health that the number of quarantine flights along northern beaches could be cut.
The move brought criticism from the private operators who have bought expensive Nomad Searchmaster aircraft and sophisticated radar equipment for the work.

More importantly, the article states that the move has also angered the Queensland Government. As honourable members will know, the Queensland Government is rather slow to rise in anger. It takes a very disciplined view of all these sorts of things.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are rather slow, full stop.

—I know the honourable member for Bowman has had a long interest in containing drug trafficking in Australia. I know of his concern for young people . I know that he will be most interested in hearing that the anger of the Queensland Government is occasioned by a very firm belief about drugs. Who would suggest for one minute that the Hon. R. Katter, the Minister for Northern Development and Aboriginal and Island Affairs in Queensland and son of one of the great parliamentarians in this place, would utter a false statement or that he would get excited about something which was not of substance? The article in the Australian continued:

SPEECH.PARA: The Queensland Northern Development Minister, Mr Katter, said the revised coastal surveillance arrangements left north Queensland wide open to drug smuggling and exotic disease.

The Queensland Government certainly would not engage in telephone tapping or anything like that but is aware of the fact that vast quantities of drugs are smuggled into Australia via the exposed northern coastline. Mr Katter said that surveillance cuts would greatly increase not only drug smuggling but also the likelihood of exotic disease entering Australia. I think the Queensland Minister was fairly harsh when he said:
This proves that the Hawke Government is prepared to sacrifice the northern way of life for what must be a few dollars saved in the Treasury.

If we can sort the wheat from the chaff in this statement, I think it does but reflect the concern that I have. I hope that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism and Minister for Administrative Services (Mr John Brown), who is at the table, will take up with the Minister for Primary Industry the concern that I have expressed and the concern expressed by the Queensland Government, through its Minister for Northern Development, that if we downgraded surveillance we could be increasing drug running and making it easier for the importation of exotic livestock diseases. I ask the Minister, notwithstanding the opportunity for jobs in the ship repair business in the servicing of unlicensed foreign fishing vessels, to take every possible precaution to ensure that this move does not increase drug running and that it preserves the disease-free status of the Australian livestock industry.

In Parliament on Wednesday last week our colleague the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) delivered a statement. Due to the indulgence granted by the Leader of the House (Mr Young) I had the honour to support that statement which concerned the act of self-determination of the residents of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. I make no further comment about it because, as honourable members know, the United Nations delegation is at present, if the plane arrived on time, on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands to supervise that act of self-determination. I do not want to be seen to be influencing that at all.

However, I am concerned about the removal by this Bill of all references to traditional fishing from the Fisheries Act. My reason for this is rather simple. If the referendum decides that the Cocos (Keeling) Islands are to become part and parcel of Australia I want to ensure, and I know that you, Mr Speaker, want to ensure also, that the residents of that jewel of the Indian Ocean will be able to maintain their traditional fishing rights. The reason for the removal of the traditional fishing rights, as the Minister quite logically explained in the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill, was that the Act referred basically to the Papua New Guinean waters. Because the treaty has been concluded and the islands are now a nation in their own right, there is no need to have those words in the Act.

The seas around the Cocos (Keeling) Islands are rich with fish. For decades the people were forced to fish on Sundays to obtain sufficient protein for themselves and their families for the rest of the week. They had to work on the Clunies-Ross Estate for the other six days of the week. Fishing is very much part and parcel of their lives. I would be most appreciative if the Minister were to give an assurance that in due course, and if necessary, traditional fishing rights will be given to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands people. Their situation, in effect, is the reverse of that applicable to Papua New Guinea. On second thoughts, given the complexities of modern administration, the Minister may not have been aware of the activity of his colleagues regarding this act of self-determination. He might like to leave that clause in the Bill for removal at a later stage rather than bring back legislation to protect the way of life of the Cocos Malay people.

In his second reading speech the Minister indicated that he would consult with the States on the implications of the proposals for State officials acting under Commonwealth law. We look forward to hearing in this Parliament the results of such consultations, bearing in mind that this legislation was introduced some months ago and that there has been plenty of time for such consultations.

On a recent visit to the Northern Territory, Territorian officials indicated to me that there was an enormous need for research into the resources of the sea. They have many exciting plans concerning breeding waters, migratory habits and the development of new markets and fishing techniques. It is fitting and proper that their research funds should be matched by a Commonwealth contribution. I assure you, Mr Speaker, that the funds will be well and wisely spent.

Australian fisheries production was estimated to be worth $439m in 1982-83, a significant rise from the 1981-82 level. The major contributions to this increase were prawns, rock lobsters and scallops which registered significant increases in value of production. Prawn production was estimated to be around 20 ,800 tonnes. Its value was estimated at $147.2m, an increase of 35 per cent on its estimated value in 1981-82. Rock lobster production was 18,200 tonnes, up 11 per cent. The value of this production was estimated at $131.2m, an increase of 22 per cent. Scallop production was 34,600 tonnes, an increase of 18 per cent on the level of the previous year, and was valued at $25.7m, up 15 per cent. Abalone production was 6,200 tonnes and showed a fall of 12 per cent. Its value fell from $27.8m to $20.5m.

Total Australian exports of fisheries products in 1982-83 were valued at $368. 7m, an increase of 14 per cent on the value of exports in 1981-82. The value of exports of edible fisheries products rose by 15 per cent to $353m. Prawns, rock lobster and scallops were the main products which contributed to the increase. The value of prawn exports, at $158.9m, was $17.3m higher than in 1981-82 and accounted for 45 per cent of total value of edible exports in 1982-83. Japan and the United States of America continued as the main markets for Australian fisheries products. Sales to Japan increased by 11.6 per cent to $176.5m in 1982 -83, and represented 50 per cent of total edible fish exports. Exports to the United States of America were $109.8m, an increase of 14.7 per cent. In value terms, this was 31 per cent of Australia's edible fish exports.

I have quoted these statistics to illustrate just how important the fishing industry is to our overall economy, and to emphasise that it needs encouragement if it is to improve its performance even further. Unfortunately, despite the timeliness of this Bill, it must also be said that Labor is doing little else that is positive to encourage the industry. As a matter of fact, the Government will have to concede that it has implemented virtually none of its many promises to the Australian fishing industry before the last election.

The fishing area is one of the most graphic examples of Labor making a host of promises in the heat of the election campaign and then forgetting all about them . I can understand that the industry was strongly supportive of Labor's fishing policies before the election because they embodied promises on a number of issues which the fishing industry had been seeking for some time. However, there is now serious doubt and concern within the Australian fishing industry about the Labor Government's genuineness in treating fishermen as significant primary producers. In the twelve months and more that the Labor Party has been in Government, it has failed to implement its promises to establish a national fishing policy, to restructure the Department of Primary Industry's Fisheries Division and to establish management plans for the south-east trawl fishery, the southern shark fishery and the southern bluefin tuna fishery.

It is true that Labor announced a so-called interim management plan for the southern bluefin tuna fishery, but this has been widely condemned by fishing organisations, and in fact the move has endangered the southern bluefin tuna fishery by ignoring fundamental issues. The Minister will no doubt recall with some embarrassment the reaction of the members of the Tuna Boat Owners Association of Australia. They told him in no uncertain terms that his interim plan could result in lasting damage to the southern bluefin tuna fishery.

The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has also told the Minister that his proposed interim measures are in total contravention of the advice of Australian, Japanese and New Zealand scientists. Given this, it now seems possible that the Minister may be in breach of section 5B of the Fisheries Act, which compels him to ensure that living marine resources are not endangered by over-exploitation. To get back to Labor's list of broken promises, the House will recall that the Labor Party made these promises:
Provide funds for research and development of new fisheries in the Australian fishing zone.
Explore national marketing potential with particular regard of the need for fish promotion.
Treat the fishing industry similarly to other primary industries with respect to tax exemptions and other assistance measures.
Exempt four-wheel drive vehicles from sales tax where they are essential to the fishing business.

These promises are all contained on page 21 of Labor's policies for agriculture document which the Minister hawked around the country in the lead up to the last election. It is true that Labor has implemented one promise and that is to restore the free circulation of the Department of Primary Industry publication Australian Fisheries.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was one more than you achieved.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, you will be delighted to know that it was a promise that your Party has honoured, but the Government is using funds out of the Fishing Industry Research Trust Account to foot the Bill. That is a pretty easy way of honouring a promise. I ask you: What sort of misallocation of resources is that? Would not the money be better spent on research? Would it not be better to make the money available out of government funds rather than touching the till of essential research trust fund account moneys? Surely the Research Trust Account should be used only for fisheries research activities.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor made this solemn promise before the election:

Urgently move to establish management plans for the Southern Bluefin Tuna, South East Trawl, Northern Prawn Trawl and Southern Shark Fisheries in the belief that such management strategies, based on biological, economic and social factors will help reduce disagreements between states.

In actual fact, after more than 12 months in government, all Labor has done is to implement a discredited interim management plan for southern bluefin tuna and a new management plan for the northern prawn fishery. Nothing has been done about the southern shark fishery which, as the Minister should know, is just as important as other areas of the industry.

I have on many occasions demonstrated that the Labor Government simply does not understand the issues involved in primary industry affairs, and this has been particularly obvious this week in the Government's handling-or mishandling-of our beef exports. But it also seems unable to understand that the fishing industry is one of the nation's most fuel-intensive industries. If the Government really wanted to support fishermen it would reverse its Budget decision with regard to increased diesel excise and the removal of safe anchorages, and provide a fuel freight subsidy for remote fishing operations. The fishing industry has estimated that these disgraceful Budget decisions will increase overall operating costs by a massive $5m a year. In case this fails to register in the Minister's mind I will put it another way: The industry has estimated that the fuel cost component to catch one kilogram of prawns today is $2. It seems unbelievable, but obviously the Government does not understand the simple fact that if suddenly, overnight, we increase a thriving export industry' s operation costs by $5m a year we will sabotage its competitive ability on world markets.

Despite his efforts with this Bill, the Minister for Primary Industry has failed to deliver to fishermen the goods he promised during the election campaign. Time and again he gets rolled in Cabinet and fails to give primary producers the assistance they were told they could expect under a Labor government. This Minister is not looking after the interests of fishermen and the wider rural sector. It is about time his actions matched his words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —How dare the honourable member for Darling Downs ( Mr McVeigh) accuse the Labor Government of a lack of genuineness in its dealings with the problems of the fishing industry. For the first time in the history of the Australian fishing industry a government has seriously started planning its role in the Australian fishing industry. The Hawke Labor Government has introduced draft management plans for prawns and now tuna and the south east trawl. As usual, the Opposition is accusing the Hawke Labor Government of not achieving in a year what it failed to achieve in seven years. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin)-this is without precedent-is thoroughly versed in fishing industry matters. The Minister, who is the member for Werriwa, has been associated with the fishing industry over many years. As the former member for Macarthur he had a close association with the industry in that electorate, which the current member for Macarthur (Mr Hollis), who will speak later on this legislation, is now following.

SPEECH.PARA: The Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill 1983 legislates for measures which the fishing industry has been trying to gain and for which it has been working hard over at least 10 years. One decisive act in the legislation is the removal of the requirement for crew members of fishing boats to be individually licensed. In future only master fishermen will be required to hold a licence. In the proliferation of licences gross inefficiencies were perpetuated. For example, almost anyone could go off-shore to fish. Fifteen years ago government was asked through the Union of Co-operatives in New South Wales to take this action. Mr Peter Bell of Ulladulla played a major part in a submission to the Australian Government in 1969. The Union of Co-operatives was almost a lone voice among New South Wales fishermen at the time. Again four years ago new moves were made. I know that Jock Petrie, current Chairman of the Eden co-operative, again asked for action four years ago. This time the Fraser Government agreed, and showed its enthusiasm in the most eloquent way!

This is how the fishermen saw the then Government's co-operation: The Government agreed that there should be only one licence-for master fishermen. Naturally it decided that, if there was to be only one licence and crew members were not required to take out a licence, to keep up with costs the Government would have to raise the fee. But what happened? The fee was put up all right but crew members were still required to pay and take out a licence. What a good trick: Convince a government there should be only one licence; it agrees and puts up the fee, but sticks to more than one licence on a boat-one for each crew member. Yet the honourable member for Darling Downs complains about the Minister for Primary Industry taking four months to implement powers when it has taken at least four years for this legislation to be implemented properly. After 15 years of representation from the fishing industry at least we have a Minister who is prepared to listen to that industry. There is now one licence and one fee. The fishing industry is disillusioned because it firmly believes that this is the way government treats it. The industry has a history of distrust of government and internal friction. That friction has not been helped by our federal system.

The honourable member for Darling Downs has complained about relationships with the States. This Minister has gone out of his way to negotiate with State Ministers. If ever I have come across an industry which would like a co- ordinated national approach rather than a haphazard State approach it is the fishing industry. We have Western Australian tuna boats taking fish below size. The tuna come around the coast from the north-west to the east, and of course there is nothing left when the small fish have been taken along the west coast. Now we have the Premier of Tasmania asking that all seas south of 39 degrees 10 minutes be restricted to the Tasmanian industry. How can that sort of thing operate when fishing is common farming all over Australian and nearby waters? How can that isolationist approach operate? Mr Gray knows full well that there will be a time when the Tasmanian industry will want to go into other waters. Is this the sort of thing that the honourable member for Darling Downs wants the Government to take more account of? I hope not.

This legislation, with its amendments to streamline and improve the administration of fisheries management arrangements, is an approach towards the aims of this Government for the fishing industry. A major task of this Government is to establish a rarely experienced relationship between the people administering the scheme and fishermen. Tomorrow the Minister meets people in the industry from Sydney to Eden. These fishermen trust the Minister and they feel, I think, that if they speak with one voice the Minister will listen to them. Fishermen, like people in most other callings, are a mixed bunch. Some have too high a capital investment, and many went bankrupt in the Fraser years along with a record number of small businessmen. Some are undercapitalised and cannot fish efficiently. Almost all have low profitability and many are very poor. It is little wonder that there is a lot of scepticism in the industry; it is little wonder that many in the industry ask for no new boats and no more licences; it is little wonder that fishermen, the people on the sea, are sceptical of talk of underdeveloped zones when they are bringing in no fish. Boats are queueing up way out at sea, like football fans at a grand final, along a narrow continental shelf waiting for their turn, taking fish, and then having to get out to avoid arguments.

When that sort of thing happens, it is hard to talk of underdeveloped zones. The areas west of Tasmania alleged by some to be underdeveloped are said by fishermen to be well known and well fished. One fisherman and former government surveyor of fisheries has written to me, saying:

. . . we discovered all the commercial deepwater grounds off the Swains Reef, Tasmania, and western Victoria. That was several years ago. Since then, despite the expenditure of hundreds of thousands of dollars in repetitive and duplicated surveys, nothing more has been found. Within weeks of discovery the very limited commercial areas found within this survey area were being exploited, and all, without exception, are already showing indications of decline.

To talk of additional boats, or bigger boats, is either showing a dangerous ignorance, a sheer irresponsibility, or self-interest at the expense of proper fisheries management and compounding the dangers to the present fleet.

It is vital to the immediate future of the northern ports to realise that all the major fish species are migratory and although some biologists are inclined to disagree fishermen have convincing proof that morwong breed around the east coast of Tasmania, and migrate northwards, that flathead breed off Lakes Entrance and migrate northwards, and that gemfish and blue grenadier also follow a northward migratory route.

This being so, the whole of the trawlable area has to be considered as the one fishery. Any attempt to fence it off by way of zones, or differing management regimes, must necessarily exclude the majority of northern fishermen from the stock. As the fish movement is northwards, all ports north of Lakes Entrance must be affected by any effort expended in the southern regions.

If for some reason his call for one fishery is rejected, there are some fishermen who will feel that if people are licensed for a specific area they ought to fish only in that area. This correspondent of mine has pointed out that it would be quite irresponsible to consider the trawlable area to be other than one fishery.

The Government and the Department of Primary Industry are listening to that point of view now. The Government is showing its goodwill to the industry. True to the principles on which the Hawke Government came to office, it has begun a process of consultation with fishermen. The Department has been visiting areas already, getting fishermen's views. It will not be easy for the Department. I commend those involved for taking the plunge into a relationship with the industry which will be tough but, given the goodwill of all involved, will benefit both the industry and government.

It is clear that management has been inadequate for too long. It is clear that we can have management with a minimum of interference from government. Much remains to be discussed about licensing, including transferability and secondary endorsements. However, this Bill is a beginning to a satisfactory licensing policy. I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: — Legislation to streamline and improve the fishing industry is significant legislation. The Australian fishing industry is an ever- growing industry and one which has always created considerable export revenue for Australia. I am sure that the legislation before us, the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill, is welcomed for the areas in which it improves the handling of fishing in the arena of Commonwealth responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: I start by drawing to the attention of the honourable member for Eden-Monaro ( Mr Snow) some of the differences that have occurred in State legislation over the years in terms of controlling the fishing industry and particularly the stocks of fish. I am very proud to say that the Western Australian Government, through its Department of Fisheries, has over the years accepted the situation related to limited fisheries and limited access fisheries in an extremely good and successful fashion. This was brought out, I guess, most importantly by the lobster industry, which is very significant in Western Australia. I had the opportunity to observe it in the north-west of Western Australia with the development of the prawn industry in the town of Carnarvon, where I live. An extremely large industry now exists which clearly, had it been allowed to be treated as the east coast treated its prawn fisheries, would be in a similar parlous situation.

State governments and State departments must take a considerable amount of blame for the situation as it exists on the east coast. The controls were not there, and, as we know, the fishing industry is not one in which one can replant the stock; it is an industry which must be carefully watched. Many State governments could have looked to the Western Australian Government in the way in which it sensibly controlled this industry. The limited entry concept is excellent. Unfortunately, in some stages, from my experience in Western Australia, the demarcation dispute that exists to this day between Commonwealth and State authorities creates some problems. Probably one of the more significant problems is that of policing, because, if a certain style of fishing or certain boats are not permitted in a State limited entry area but are permitted in a Commonwealth area, we have a situation in which when we find people carrying equipment, for instance, that is banned in the State area but not banned in the Commonwealth area, we cannot prosecute them for having it on board, because they will invariably say that they were going to use it in the area controlled by the Commonwealth. This is a great pity, because we also recognise that the sea is a pretty big place and the policing of our fishery is always a difficult matter, even with the improved facilities of radar and things of that nature. Many of the problems, particularly those of the New South Wales fishing industry, must be visited upon a variety of State governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fish are not getting around there.

—Now the honourable member is talking about tuna. I shall refer to tuna in a moment. There are a lot more fish in the sea than tuna, and the southern bluefin tuna in particular. The facts of life are that the east coast prawn fishery is also in a parlous state. It is in that state because it was overfished and insufficient controls were imposed.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I am rather pleased that the honourable member for Eden-Monaro talked about the southern bluefin tuna, which was mentioned in the second reading speech of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). I congratulate the present Government on following what I think is the advice of its Department, and on the way in which that Department conducted inquiries into some controls to be applied to the southern bluefin tuna industry. It is a vexatious debate and one which is very much influenced by where one comes from. I represent the fishery in regard to the ports of Albany and Esperance. In that area the immature southern bluefin tuna come around the coast and pass the electorate of Forrest, represented by Mr Peter Drummond, in which, at Busselton, there is also a fishery; they come around the south-west corner and head across the Great Australian Bight, and they are in a growing stage while they do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had extensive discussions with all those people.

—We did. The shadow Minister was very kind in coming to that electorate and meeting those people and listening to the problems as they put them. I would not like to be the Minister or the shadow Minister in this particular argument, being obliged to take a national overview, because each of the separate fisheries-namely, those in Western Australia, South Australia and New South Wales-fishing on the southern bluefin tuna has very good arguments as to why it does everything right and everyone else does everything wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think the arguments are resoluble. I cannot entirely accept the argument that it will all be controlled if we catch only the big fish. As I understand it, most of the very big fish are being caught by the Japanese in international waters and, of course, we have limited controls there. Nevertheless, as this House has been told on previous occasions, there has been a substantial decline in the resource of southern bluefin tuna. Southern bluefin tuna, as I remember, do not commence to breed until they are approximately five years old. So what we are seeing in the water today is no indication of the circumstances that might confront us in five years time. We are still really and truly fishing the results of breeding some five years ago. That is the sort of time lag with which this industry is confronted. I am pleased that our Australian fisheries departments, in conjunction with Japanese scientists, have got together to try to put some sensible national and international controls on the fishing of this excellent resource.

It was interesting to read just the other day that the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) complained of how we have depleted this resource principally for the feeding of cats. If that is a cause of much of the damage, maybe we should be asking ourselves whether tuna should be classified as a food fish and removed from the pet food market. Quite clearly, it is a human consumption food fish. It is an excellent food fish in many regards, particularly for canning and in the type of food preparation that uses canned fish.

In my State, as I said, we are catching the smaller variety of fish and naturally we have to take a lot more fish out of the water to gain the same sort of tonnages caught in other States. Current restrictions are on tonnage. I often wonder whether it can be argued that every fish that the Western Australians catch would eventually mature into a larger fish somewhere along the line. Clearly, the sea has always been a place of predators. Although tuna is one of the more superior predators and, I presume, one that therefore has the speed and other capabilities to escape other varieties, clearly there is a mortality rate and the farming or culling of the small fish reduces that natural mortality rate . So there is an argument that the smaller fish, if not caught at that stage, might not mature to the size at which, for instance, the New South Welshmen catch them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell that to them.

—Let us not argue too much. I have made the point that we all have a right to represent the arguments of our constituents. I am trying to do that in a logical fashion and point out to the House that clearly not every little tuna that swims past Albany or Esperance will get to New South Wales; some will be eaten on the way. It is not easy to apply the rules of statistics on that point.

SPEECH.PARA: I will come shortly to the area in which I think New South Wales and Western Australia at least could combine to give the industry a degree of protection which it would not get in any other way. The other factor I wish to raise while talking about the immature tuna-these are caught from the boat by poling-is that we now have size restrictions which are proving to be ineffective. They are effective at the wharf because an inspector can come down to the wharf and measure fish that are being unloaded. Of course, quite properly he can take prosecuting action if undersized fish are on board; they are thrown back.

But my fishermen are telling me that they are just not able in the frenzy of poling these fish aboard-as they are able, for instance, when they unload crayfish from a pot, which is a rather slow and cumbersome process-to check the size of the fish. The fish are poled up on a barbless hook and dropped on deck. When they stop biting, the fishermen are supposed to throw back all of those that are undersized. Of course, a large number of them are dead or injured to the point at which they cannot be saved. It is a terrible waste to throw them back in the ocean. I know that a professional fisherman has an opportunity to assess somewhat the size of the school of fish that he is going into. Some schools are clearly all undersized and he should not fish there. But, just as clearly, he will never get them all at the same size or weight in a massive school and many undersized fish will come on board. He cannot hang a sign on his hook saying: 'If you are under X kilos please don't bite'. Therefore he will hook those fish and they will come on board. The fact is that they are dying before they get back in the water. I think it is a problem that has to be addressed.

More importantly, not that very long ago a new regime was introduced to the southern bluefin tuna industry. That was the purse seine. A peculiarity that I also observed many years ago in the north-west is that we can become too efficient in the means by which we catch fish. It is difficult to say that one can be too efficient as a farmer because farming efficiency is something that is controllable but in the sea we unfortunately cannot plant the fish. We cannot be selective, with highly efficient methods, as to the fish we catch. The introduction of the fish trap as compared to hand lining was a major drawback to the north-west snapper industry. Hand lining is very similar to poling. Hand lining was sufficiently efficient to allow a fisherman to make a good living. When we stepped past that point we went past the peak of the curve at which, although we improved the efficiency of catch, we had difficulty with handling that catch. Being a food fish, the gutting and other processing had to be handled speedily when the fish came on board. The fishermen could not do that properly when this mass of fish came on board. So there was a deterioration in the value of the product and much of it found its way back into crayfish pots, where it was not required. Similarly, there was a problem with depletion of the stocks. The method of fishing was just too efficient. Therefore, our State government took a decision to ban fish traps. As I made the point, there have been difficulties over many years at the Commonwealth level in handling that situation.

But the purse seine makes chicken feed of the fish trap. The fish trap is a box measuring about six feet by three feet by three feet. The purse seine net is probably a mile long and it could be a mile deep. It is put out by a very large ship. It runs around a school and everything inside it is technically dead from that time onwards because the fish cannot get away. As I said, the poler, when he throws his hook in, cannot show a sign saying 'Do not bite', but he does not have a sign saying 'You will bite', either. There is an opportunity in every school for fish to move on and escape. That is a conservation measure. There is no conservation with a purse seine. As I understand it, the purse seine was not introduced to fish southern bluefin tuna; it was introduced to fish the skipjack variety. I would like to think that the Fraser Government would have accepted that. I am sure from what the shadow Minister has heard about the purse seine that if he had control over the industry he would seriously consider either the banning of purse seines or returning their use to other less popular varieties. I am sure that would be a much better conservation measure than trying to tell, for instance, the Albany industry that it should stop catching the smaller fish. I believe that in one fell swoop we could get a reasonable level of conservation in the bluefin tuna industry which would assist all the various States that are fishing by the conventional method of poling. Fishing by poling will always mean , even if there is an increased number of boats-I am not recommending that-that some fish are left over to go through the breeding cycle so necessary to maintain our fishing stocks. I hope that it will not be long before we see some regulation that protects those fish.

The other great problem, of course, comes back to the matter of policing. We now have lines at given points beyond which certain fishermen are not permitted to fish. We have a rather strange situation in that the South Australian fishermen are allowed to encroach into what I might term our Western Australian waters. The boundary in the sea is not the State border. Unfortunately, while the pressure is on Western Australian fishermen to catch larger fish, and it is a fact that the fish get larger as they move east, they are being precluded from fishing a section of what could be called Western Australian waters, that area of water that follows the boundaries of our coastline. They are refused entry there and South Australian fishermen are allowed entry.

That seems to me to be a problem that should be resolved by allowing fishermen from one or both States to fish what could be common waters. It is difficult to say to Western Australians: 'You have to catch bigger fish but you are not allowed to go where the bigger fish are'. I am not suggesting that Western Australians should go into what I would term South Australian waters any more than I am suggesting that South Australians should be allowed in ours. A compromise should be reached. If there is an area of Western Australian waters where the South Australians go, Western Australians should have common use of it .

More importantly, in some of the more remote areas fish are being transferred from smaller boats to larger boats. Some of the larger boats are overseas vessels. Evidence on this has been put to the Minister for Primary Industry. I believe he is aware of it and has indicated that he is trying to do something about it. I recognise that he has as much difficulty as anyone else, but sightings have been reported to him and I hope he takes very severe action. The only way we will control the problem is by ensuring that all the fish come ashore, where they can be looked at and weighed, and where the controls the Government properly has applied can be policed. If people are prepared to transfer fish at sea and the fish go straight to Japan we will have great problems.

Finally, I come back to the problem of damaged fish. I have mentioned that the purse seine is the fish trap of the bluefin industry. I do not believe that type of fishing is suitable for the proper handling of fish. I think our fishermen, particularly those who have access to the larger fish, namely the New South Wales fishermen, are not using their brains sufficiently and going into the top end of the market. There is a Japanese delicacy-a dish called sashimi-which the Americans are now farming. They put nets out around the fish, keep them in the ocean and literally fatten them up. The price is so good that they are able to air freight those very large fish all the way from the United States to Japan and sell them within a very short time of their being removed from the water. That is how good the market is. Clearly, the Federal Government and the New South Wales Government should be giving encouragement to the New South Wales fishermen to consider that industry. It would be profitable and, at the same time, I believe it would leave room for the Western Australian end of the market , which is catching smaller fish and is probably able to serve only the canning market.

I have no objections to the moves the Minister is making in introducing this legislation. It makes improvements to the administration of the Act. I thank the House for the opportunity to raise all these matters on a very important industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, this is the first time since your election to your present high office that I have spoken while you have been occupying the chair. May I say how pleased I am to see you occupying that office and what a wonderful job you will do there. It is not very often that I find a substantial degree of concurrence with the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), but I find myself in agreement with many of the things he said today. I would dispute, perhaps, his remarks concerning the size of the fish off Albany, but I agree with what he said about the control of the fishing industry in Western Australia. SPEECH.PARA: I listened to the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh), and one always finds his speeches interesting. I am not sure about their content but they raise a laugh occasionally. He said at the beginning of his speech that he was in support of the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill, but then in his usual way he bagged the legislation and tried to bag the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), if such a term is appropriate when talking about fishing. For the benefit of the honourable member for Darling Downs I will quote from a report from a group of fishermen. Talking about the Federal Government, they said:

We feel that, generally speaking, there has been quite a degree of ignorance and a complete lack of interest shown by the previous Government on the problems facing the fishing industry in this country, particularly in the State of New South Wales.

This was said at a recent meeting and they were talking about the previous Government. So much for the honourable member for Darling Downs talking about what the Hawke Labor Government-he probably threw in the word 'socialist' as well-has not done for the fishing industry. According to the fishermen at that meeting it was the first time that they had met with government representatives from the Department of Primary Industry. They said that the Government 'has given us some hope for the future management of the fishery'. They are not my words; they are the words of the fishermen in the industry, the people involved. They were talking about the Hawke Labor Government and what it is doing for the fishing industry. Honourable members opposite have to accept the fact that we are the natural party for the rural areas of Australia as well as the urban areas. They had better learn to live with that because we will be around for a long time. We are on side with the fishermen, as we are with the farmers and all the other country people, as well as with the city and urban people.

As has been pointed out, the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill seeks to implement a number of amendments of an administrative nature to the Fishing Industry Research Act 1969, the Fisheries Act 1952 and the Continental Shelf ( Living Natural Resources) Act 1968, pending completion of a comprehensive review of Commonwealth fisheries legislation. The amendments are designed to streamline and improve the administration of fisheries management arrangements for the benefit of both the industry and the Government. All associated with the fishing industry recognise the need for a review of Commonwealth fisheries legislation. The industry has been subject to dramatic changes over the past few years. Not least of these are technological changes and their impact on the industry.

Although fishermen see many sunrises, the industry in its present condition could not be regarded as a sunrise industry. I am sure that my colleague the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) would agree with that. By world standards Australia is not a major fishing nation, producing only a minor percentage of the world catch. One of the reasons we are not a major fishing nation is that we have no massive rivers ejecting nutrients into the ocean and our relatively warm waters are far less productive than the cooler regions. Although we are not a major fishing nation by world standards, the fishing industry is important to Australia. It is especially important to my electorate of Macarthur and to the neighbouring electorate of my colleague and friend the honourable member for Eden-Monaro.

Over the past year, since we have both been members of this House, we have raised a number of problems for the fishing industry in the area we both represent. These problems are sometimes caused by our 'very good friends' in the Navy. Last year we had a problem with the spotter planes. That problem, on which we both worked, came to a satisfactory conclusion. Early this year we were both made aware of the problem arising when the Navy was engaged in an exercise off the south coast, when some of the fishing fleet's gear was destroyed. This was especially so with the lobster fishing industry. The Navy boats were cutting their gear adrift and causing them financial loss. Both the honourable member for Eden-Monaro and I raised this matter not only with the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) but also with the Minister for Primary Industry. Hopefully, again, we came to a satisfactory resolution of this potential conflict.

One of the great problems is that the fishing industry has virtually no protection, particularly compared with the protection given to some of our competitors. I refer especially to the unfair competition with New Zealand imports-cheaply produced fish caught by, say, Russian trawlers operating in New Zealand waters which are subsidised by the New Zealand Government for export to Australia. This morning I attended a meeting about New Zealand shearers who are operating in Australia. I assure honourable members that not only the New Zealand shearers give us some cause for concern; New Zealand fish coming on to the Australian market and unfairly competing with our own fishing industry is cause for concern also. We do need more control of the Australian fishing industry.

The honourable member for O'Connor mentioned the control that has been exercised over the crayfishing industry in Western Australia. As I said at the outset, I do not often stand up here and say that I support the honourable member for O'Connor, but in this case I do support him. I think the illustrations he gave of what was happening around Carnarvon are good illustrations. The fishing industry in other States should follow that example. It would lead to a balanced control of the fishing industry. The Government will take a close look at the industry and undoubtedly some hard decisions will have to be taken. The Hawke Labor Government has never shied away from taking hard decisions when they have had to be taken in the national interest.

The resources available to the fishermen on the New South Wales coast are clearly not expanding, so each fisherman is engaged in a horsepower and technological race to ensure he gets his share. As the value of the vessels increases each fisherman is looking for additional quantities of fish in order to cover his capital costs. Other speakers have mentioned this. These developments have been compounded by a rapid increase in fishing technology, with satellite navigation, sonar and similar developments greatly increasing the fishing power of the fleet. This pattern is further reflected throughout the world.

There is no way that governments can or should prevent fishermen from becoming more efficient. On the other hand, no government can sit by and oversee a commercial fishing industry which is bent on extinction. It is clearly imperative for governments to moderate the acceleration in fishing effort, and this is the rationale for the draft management plan for the south-east trawler fishery recently announced by the Minister. The thrust of this plan is to limit the number of vessels in this traditional, highly developed area and to ensure that, as boats are replaced, compensating amounts of fishing effort are removed from the fishery. This does not mean that all fishermen will be returned to profitability. There will always be a proportion who, through bad luck, bad management or bad weather, have difficulty in making a living. However, hopefully it will at least bring a degree of increased stability to the south- east trawler fishery.

The Government is very conscious of the problems facing the tuna industry. Partly because of the build-up in fishing capacity and because scientists advised last year that the tuna resource is biologically threatened, this Government has introduced an interim management plan and the Minister is studying long term measures designed to protect the viability of the tuna industry. All governments and industry groups want fisheries management, but with the benefits of management there are invariably some costs in terms of restrictions, size limits, closed seasons, quotas or some other form of restraint. To persuade each group that it must bear part of the cost if it wishes to participate in the benefits of management is not an easy task.

There is a basic problem concerning the over-fishing of the south-east trawler fishery. Although we do have the 200-mile limit, the actual fishing ground in that area is very small. This area is just off the edge of the continental shelf . Frankly, too many boats are operating what is a narrow field. We often hear about the 200-mile zone and fishing to the outer limit-it all sounds very impressive-but some fishermen recently said to me that the impact of the 200- mile zone in that area is like allowing farmers free access to the Simpson Desert. As I said, this is a very narrow fishing area. That naturally leads to over-fishing, which not only destroys the ground but also leads to a worsening price situation. The fleets' operating costs have risen but the prices of fish have remained low. Therefore, the profitability of those engaged in the industry has also been low.

The Bill before the House will amend the Fisheries Act 1952 to simplify licensing requirements, overcome a number of administrative difficulties and include review provisions in relation to licensing functions and fisheries notices made under section 8 of the Act. It will also remove the requirement for crew members of fishing boats to be individually licensed. This matter was touched on by my colleague, the honourable member for Eden-Monaro. In future only master fishermen will be required to hold a licence.

Another important provision of the Bill will enable the entry of unlicensed foreign fishing boats to Australian ports for major repair and similar purposes. The entry of unlicensed foreign fishing boats for these purposes, which has the potential to provide significant economic benefits for Australian industries, has been limited by restrictive port entry criteria in the Fisheries Act. Clauses 23 and 24 of the Bill will remove this difficulty by providing for the authorisation of entry into Australian ports for specified purposes. It is not intended that such authorisations be used for the purpose of allowing unlicensed foreign fishing boats to enter ports for routine refuelling or minor repairs on an ad hoc basis.

Clause 9 of the Bill will provide a procedure for formally controlling the activities of research boats in the Australian fishing zone by allowing the granting of permits for scientific purposes. Clauses 5 and 7 of the Bill will permit the application of the Fisheries Act to Australian fishermen operating beyond the outer limits of the Australian fishing zone should this be required under future international fisheries management arrangements. It is likely that if international agreement is reached on the management of highly migratory species of fish, such as tuna, each country concerned will be required to control its own fishermen on the high seas.

The Bill effects a number of other amendments to the Fisheries Act to streamline administrative procedures. These include additional powers relating to the cancellation of licence endorsements, changes in licence conditions and the endorsement of licences to exempt the licensee from a prohibition imposed by a specified fisheries notice. The Fisheries Act currently permits licences to be endorsed in respect of only one type of fisheries notice. These amendments will permit greater flexibility in implementing fisheries management arrangements.

The amendments will provide long-needed reforms to the fisheries legislation which will assist the Government to discharge more efficiently its management responsibilities for the valuable fisheries resources off our shores. The amendments come at a time when the Government is in the process of introducing new and improved management arrangements for a number of important fisheries to provide for the long term stability of the fishing industry and, at the same time, protect the biological needs of those fisheries. I commend the Bill to the House.

Particular attention should be paid to, firstly, the immediate and long term effects of various management measures on the biological and economic status of established fisheries; secondly, the effects of the implementation of the management regimes in one fishery on the biological and economic stability of neighbouring fisheries and on other fisheries resources and the need for a multispecies approach to management; thirdly, the development of new fisheries within the Australian fishing zone and the exploitation of less preferred species particularly for import replacement purposes.

One cannot place too much emphasis on the necessity for the development and implementation of a national fisheries policy in consultation with the States and the Northern Territory governments-a policy defining the objectives and strategies for the rational utilisation of Australian fishing resources. It is necessary for the future development of the industry. It is only in the last 15 to 20 years that the Australian fishing industry has assumed national and international significance. Prior to this the industry catered mainly for the needs of local communities and the populations of major cities. The recent growth of the industry can be attributed primarily to the export of the high unit value prawn, rock lobster, scallop and abalone fisheries, although Australia's demersal fisheries have continued to be exploited in areas over Australia's continental shelf close to the large population centres. Pelagic stock have been only lightly fished by Australians, with the exception of the southern bluefin tuna and the Australian salmon fisheries.

The creation of an expanded export market for Australian seafoods provided the stimulus for the growth of the Australian commercial fishing industry. The rock lobster industry in Western Australia and off the southern coast of Australia established the first seafood export market. Its development provided the basis for expansion into other markets. Scallops and prawns provided the next major export markets and the exploitation of these species resulted in the rapid expansion of scallop and prawn fishing in Victoria, as well as Western Australia and northern Australia. The industry responded by building larger and more powerful boats to extend its operations and installing more advanced equipment for position fixing and fish finding. Some of the developments in these two fisheries spread to the demersal and pelagic fisheries supplying fin fish for the local market.

During the 1960s the value of the Australian catch of fish, crustaceans and molluscs doubled from $30m to $60m per annum. However, the greatest growth in the history of the industry took place during the 1970s when total landings of fish doubled and the value of the catch trebled. That decade saw prawn fishing overtake rock lobster catching as the nation's most valuable export industry. There was also a steady growth in the production of abalone and scallops for export. Trawl fishing for the domestic market expanded and there was a period of consolidation in the growth of the tuna live bait and pole fishery from the previous decade. The extension of Australia's fishing limit to 200 nautical miles, signalled by the Commonwealth Government in 1977 and eventually implemented in 1979, further stimulated interest in Australia's fish resources by both Australian and foreign fishermen.

Research goes hand in hand with the future management and development of our fisheries. Our history in Australia of research in the fishing industry is one of which we should not be proud. It is now time that research was given priority within the overall development of our fishing industry. It is time that we established national objectives, priorities and criteria for the allocation of funds for fishing research activities within the Australian fishing zone. We should accord priority to projects relating to the development of new fisheries in the Australian fishing zone and to proposals submitted by the private sector relating to exploratory and developmental fishing operations and new product development. There should be an adoption of appropriate procedures for assessing all proposals for research grants funded by the Fishing Industry Research Committee Trust Account. There should be appropriate evaluation procedures for the financial supervision of the funds disbursed by the Committee and for the monitoring and evaluation of projects funded from the Fishing Industry Research Committee Trust Account.

There is a need within the industry to monitor and report to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) on the co-ordination of all fishing industry research and advise on the financing of such research, initially to rationalise existing funding procedures and, in the long term, to ensure that funds are allocated for approved and relevant research work which will meet the needs of the industry.

It is important and significant that the Hawke Government has taken a substantial step in the management of the northern prawn fishery. In October 1982 the Australian Fisheries Council directed that management of the northern prawn fishery declared management zone should be reviewed in order to find ways of effectively containing and reducing fishing effort. There were problems of overcapitalisation in the industry. Economic decline was predicted unless capital investment substantially reduced over time. A major review of management was completed in late 1983 and a seven-point implementation plan has now been put into place. The Federal Government will move to introduce other management plans throughout Australian fisheries but this will take time. It will be a necessary prerequisite that the industry assist in putting those management plans into place.

Finally I wish to refer to some of the clauses in the Bill. Firstly, I go to the amendments in clause 19 and clause 27 of the Bill which make provision for an administrative review of decisions relating to licensing functions, decisions other than those in respect of foreign boats or persons who are not citizens or residents of Australia. These provisions reflect the Government's commitment to the principle that discretionary powers exercised under Commonwealth legislation should be reviewable. However, special provision has been made in this Bill to recognise the position of State officials acting under Commonwealth law. Decisions on licensing matters made personally by the Minister or the Secretary will be directly reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Decisions on licensing matters by delegates of the Minister, including State officials acting on behalf of the Commonwealth, although not reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, will be subject to reconsideration by the Minister, the Secretary to the Department or a Commonwealth official delegated to review those decisions. Any decision made following reconsideration may then be reviewed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

I now refer to the provisions of clause 24 of the Bill. Under proposed section 13BAA unlicensed foreign fishing boats would be permitted entry to Australian ports where there would be significant economic benefits for Australia. For example, port entry by a boat for the purpose of major repair and maintenance would provide direct benefits to the local shipbuilding industry and would generate employment and income for a wide range of service industries. This amendment does not represent a reversal of Australia's policy of restricting the entry of foreign fishing boats into Australian ports. Access by unlicensed foreign fishing boats will not be permitted for the purpose of routine maintenance, refuelling or revictualling on an ad hoc basis. Already the benefits of this provision are being felt in Cairns, where major refits will be carried out to purse-seine trawlers of American origin.

In conclusion I say that by world standards Australia is not a major fishing nation, producing only a minor percentage of the world catch. Nevertheless, the future of Australia's fishing production is comparatively bright and it is a significant Australian industry for which proper management and research policies should be put in place. The amendments to which I have spoken are a step in that direction. However, in the future much more has to be done. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Customs law is vitally concerned with the operation of business in this country.
