SPEECH.PARA: Much of this Bill is the result of recommendations to the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) from the various authorities and commissions. The underlying policy considerations are what I wish to consider today by way of examination of just two of the amendments. I refer, firstly, to the logical conclusion of the putting into place of the closer economic relations trade agreement with New Zealand and, secondly, to the implementation of the recommendations of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Advisory Committee concerning quota levels for that sector of the manufacturing industry. The closer economic relations trade agreement was negotiated by the previous Government, and came into force on 1 January 1983. Initial phases of that agreement were put into place during 1983, and this legislation completes that implementation. The agreement between the two countries was based on the gradual and progressive liberalisation of trade across the Tasman on all goods produced in either country. The amendments relate primarily to Schedule 5 of the Customs Tariff Act 1982. In themselves these amendments are unexceptional, but their importance relates to the agreement itself. The freeing up of trade in our region has an Australia-New Zealand example to emulate. Both countries have prospered under this agreement which has gradually attended to the liberalisation of trade between them. May I suggest to the few honourable members who actually take an interest in this topic that this type of agreement could provide an impetus to similar agreements between Australia and other trading partners.

The second amendment which deserves consideration is the continuation of the textiles, clothing and footwear sectoral policy. Sectoral policies were devised to provide support for a defined period during which real efforts should be made by the industry to improve its structure and efficiency, thereby helping it to achieve a better and more certain long term future. The major industries in receipt of this type of assistance are textiles, clothing and footwear, passenger motor vehicles, and latterly steel. The political debate over protection in Australia is one of the most recurrent and long-standing in our short history. Traditionally, a protective tariff is said to be justified on only four occasions: Firstly, when defence requirements dictate the existence of a particular local industry for a future emergency; secondly, when the national interest requires that a particular industry should be encouraged; thirdly, when labour-intensive industries provide employment and no alternative employment is available; and fourthly, when an infant industry is established.

In the 1970s and 1980s when unemployment crashed onto the political agenda, a debate arose concerning the preservation of the manufacturing sector. This debate was heightened because of growing competition from newly industrialised Asian countries. Because of this competition there was general agreement that if the Australian manufacturers were to retain their market share, protection would be necessary. Following an Industries Assistance Commission report, a seven- year assistance program was put in place. The resultant Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Advisory Committee began its work in 1981, and on the basis of information before it makes recommendations to the Government concerning the level of protection required by the industry. If all is going well, quota levels are increased and the level of protection drops.

The recommendation for 1984 was for an addition to quota for prospective market growth for most quota categories. While these additions are less than decided upon for 1983, they are somewhat above the 1982 levels. The average effective rate of protection for textiles, clothing and footwear has, like that for motor cars, and steel, been higher than for the rest of the manufacturing industry since 1969. By way of contrast, protection levels for the remainder of the manufacturing sector have declined. The Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Advisory Committee in its sixth report in November 1983 states that there has been considerable reconstruction of the textiles, clothing and footwear industries since the announcement of the seven-year plan, especially in the areas of efficiency and competitiveness.

I can only hope that the provision of a reasonably predictable policy environment for manufacturers and exporters provided by this Bill will enhance the will of the industry to improve further its efficiency, competitiveness, and response to changing consumer needs. This Bill provides breathing-space for a beleagured sector of the manufacturing industry to begin the process of reconstruction. The textiles, clothing and footwear industries demonstrate many of the problems of the structural adaptation process. They are amongst the highest cost activities, and are labour-intensive. To maintain profitability they need protection.

The textiles, clothing and footwear sectors employ 9.8 per cent of people working in the manufacturing industry, or 1.8 per cent of the total industrial workforce. While these figures reflect a reduction in the numbers employed in that sector over the last decade, the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Advisory Committee has observed that the rapid decline in activity and employment experienced in 1982 and early 1983 had been arrested by the second half of 1983. In some cases, manufacturers reported the virtual elimination of short-hour weeks and, in a few cases, the introduction of overtime. These are encouraging signs indeed.

Nonetheless, this breathing space provided by protective quotas and the encouraging signs from the textiles, clothing and footwear sectors should not lull members of this House, manufacturers or associated businesses into acting as though nothing more needs to be done. Since the mid-1970s a plethora of reports has addressed the problem of the need to restructure the industrial base of this nation. That need has not vanished. Restructuring may involve progressive and gradual liberalisation of trade between countries, beginning with New Zealand and expanding to embrace a larger number of countries. Restructuring may also involve the gradual reduction of levels of protection which this nation presently extends to its least competitive sectors. Restructuring means planning for the future while taking account of the present, instead of planning for the future by steadfastly gazing into the past. Restructuring should not be a matter for excited rhetoric and name-calling in this place or any other forums because we have created for ourselves time for careful consideration.

Legislation, such as is presently before us, provides simply a breathing space for the consideration of the future of the industrial base and the international competitiveness of this nation. That is why it is important. It should remind us of the work we have to do. I hope that honourable members who take an interest in these topics will think not only about the present but also about the future in relation to issues in the protection area. In the case of New Zealand, the aim of freeing up trade is firmly under way. Application of the principle to other countries awaits us. In the case of sectoral policy for the manufacturing industry, time constraints are a little more rigid. The present agreement expires in 1989. What happens to the agreement at that time depends on what we decide in 1984 and 1985. Certainly the decision cannot wait until the agreement expires.

This Bill, unexceptional in itself, has no significant administrative costs associated with its measures. But it should act as a reminder to all honourable members that one of the most important issues we, as politicians, must come to terms with in the future is the whole future of our economic base, the whole future of our manufacturing industry and our international competitiveness. Without coming to terms with those issues the standard of living in this country must decline.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall Mr D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) said, the provisions and amendments of the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill are not such as to stir great passions. But I support the Bill introduced by the Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr John Brown) as the amendments provide necessary changes to current tariff levels and correct anomalies, especially under the closer economic relations agreement with New Zealand. Tariff legislation in this Parliament has always raised debate between the free traders and the protectionists. This was most evident in the Fraser years in the arguments between what were known as the 'wets' and the 'dries'. My opinion of that Government is that it was basically a damp argument. Australia now faces the very hard task of making for the future decisions on appropriate levels of protection. This includes what levels of Customs tariff should apply. The Bill before the House represents either increasing or decreasing tariff levels on goods ranging from audio-frequency amplifiers to vacuum cleaner parts.

SPEECH.PARA: Customs tariffs have, in my opinion, five major effects: The revenue effect, the production effect, the consumption effect, the redistribution effect and the competitive effect. The measures before us today take into account many of these effects. The first effect is the revenue effect. For too long Customs tariffs have been used by government as a means of revenue collection. The Government has a monetary disadvantage in reducing levels of tariff protection because it reduces government revenue. The amount of revenue raised is in the billions of dollars and with lower tariff levels the Government would have to find alternative sources of income. In my opinion, subsidies and quotas provide better incentive for Australian industry than do tariffs.

The second effect is the production effect. The imposition of tariffs alters the world price ratio. A tax wedge is driven between the world price and that perceived by domestic producers and consumers. The effect of this is to cause resources to move away from the production of goods in which a comparative advantage exists and to move back into import competing production. There is no better example of this than the Australian car industry. It has become fat and lazy behind high tariff barriers and is not competitive on the world market. In my electorate of Fadden, General Motors-Holden's Ltd is in the process of closing its Acacia Ridge plant. The main reason for the closure was that GMH wrongly believed it could go on producing an outdated model, as its competitors were at a price disadvantage behind the tariff levels. This is not true, and the Australian consumer has clearly shown that to be the case.

That leads me to my third point: The consumption effect of tariff levels. The imposition of a tariff has the effect of raising the relative price of imported goods. Because this provides an incentive to purchase the local product, we reduce imports and our opportunity to trade. At the same time we discourage industry from producing goods capable of being exported, as it is easier to produce products hidden behind the tariff wall.

The fourth effect, the redistribution effect, has a number of parts, the most obvious being the redistribution of income away from the consumer to the producer of goods protected by Customs tariffs. Although there is supposed to be a return of benefit back to the consumer from revenue collected by the Customs tariffs, it is never in direct proportion. Because many Australian manufacturers have not strived for modernisation and efficiency, I feel it is true to say that the ordinary Australian consumer is paying dearly for our high levels of protection.

The fifth effect, the competitive effect, is probably the most redeeming feature of Customs tariffs-that is, if used correctly. If an industry believes it will be protected, especially in its formative years, from unfair overseas competition there is an incentive for the establishment of that industry. However, an open-ended commitment to high tariff levels does not encourage Australian industry to become competitive in world markets. It only encourages industry to reach a level of efficiency in order to remain competitive behind the tariff wall. Australia's goal of a modern manufacturing base can be attained only with an industrial sector that is largely competitive on world markets.

Despite what I consider to be the negative effect of some tariffs on Australian industry development, neither I nor, I think, any member of the Government advocates an immediate across the board lifting of tariff protection. However, I do advocate seeking alternatives. If instead of Customs tariffs as outlined in this Bill we move more to a system of incentives and bounties for Australian industry we will not disadvantage the Australian consumer. The most recent example of this method was the Australian steel plan introduced by the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button). This package included Customs tariffs, quotas and bounties. It has been widely accepted by Australian industry , and has been very successful indeed. The other great advantage of bounties and subsidies is that they do not reduce the volume of trade and therefore do not induce counter-action by our trading partners. This would then encourage Australian industry to compete for overseas markets and thus would have a beneficial effect on our balance of payments.

One area in which Australia is a novice in terms of world trade is non-tariff barriers. Unfortunately, many of our major trading partners are world experts in this method of protection. I refer especially to Japan. It is significant that Australia has gone from a position where it exported to Japan many times the amount of goods and products-including mining and primary products-that we imported to the present position where we face a balance of payments favouring Japan. Again, the industries that have had the highest level of Customs tariff protection are the worst performers. Industries such as the motor car industry have a sad track record. The other great tragedy of industries that have had high tariff barriers, such as the motor car industry, is that they have been the industries that have shed the most Australian jobs. Australian industry must modernise and restructure. Customs tariff barriers will not prevent us from declining into a position where we have a status that is little more than that of a developing country, unless we have an efficient Australian manufacturing base.

The first step towards a more mature trading position has been the closer economic relations agreement with our friend and ally New Zealand. CER is the basis of future economic growth for both Australia and New Zealand. This Bill reflects the commitment of this Government to that growth and could work as a model for future agreements with our trading partners. CER has its problems and some of the measures included in this legislation are a move towards solving some of those problems. Trading agreements require both good intent and goodwill on the part of both parties, and I am disturbed at the number of dumping complaints by Australian companies against their New Zealand counterparts. One company in my electorate has suffered severe financial hardship because a New Zealand-based subsidiary of a large Australian company has been dumping in Australia. To me this is economic madness on the part of both the Australian company and its New Zealand subsidiary. Much depends on the success of CER for, if it does not succeed, the natural suspicions of Australian industry will be confirmed.

The measures included in the Bill are adjustments to our existing tariff policies and do not represent any fundamental change to our position or to the protection policies that have existed in this country since Federation; and we have had the debate between free traders and protectionists since Federation. In my opinion there is middle ground that we should move towards. I feel that Australia has now reached a state of maturity that enables us to discuss Customs tariff measures in a sensible climate. As we move out of recession, I urge both government and industry not to waste the opportunity that exists for change. As secretary of the Government's industry committee, I am only too well aware of the power and influence of vested interests. Many companies which advocate the free enterprise system are only too happy to socialise their losses through government assistance and protection. Australian industry must broaden its outlook and reassess its position. Short term planning has played too large a part in Australian industry for too long. Customs tariff measures such as those included in this Bill represent only the stop gap measures of crisis management. This has been for too long a feature of the Australian economy.

In conclusion, I hope that in the near future I will be able to speak in this House in debates about legislation that brings about assistance to Australian industry to modernise and restructure. Customs tariffs will be part of that restructuring and the Australian economy is, I hope, on an upward swing. It is also my hope that with a modern and efficient industrial base there will be much less reliance on Customs tariffs in future as Australian industry becomes competitive on world markets and restores us once more to the level of growth we had in the past. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Minister for Administrative Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I would like to spend a few moments summing up on the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill. It is a pity that the enthusiasm for the restructuring of Australian industry, by either Customs tariffs or other means, displayed by the only speaker provided by the Opposition, the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), who obviously is skilled in this area , is not shared by his colleagues. It is significant that quite a string of Government members wanted to speak on this Bill, but we restricted the number because of other demands for Bills before the House. I commend the two Government members who did speak, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Beddall) and the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly), for their reasoned and intelligent contributions to this debate. This Government faces a very vexed question in finding its way through the minefield of tariffs, quotas, duties, bounties, incentives and the problems of the closer economic relationship and the Pacific Forum.
—It sounded like one of those set speeches that you had given them.

—I can assure the honourable member for Dundas, who interjects with inanities in his usual braying fashion, that I had nothing to do with the speeches delivered by those honourable members. They were the products of their own imaginations and, I suggest, were very valuable contributions to this very important debate.

SPEECH.PARA: To get back to what I was saying, we must address very carefully the difficulties and complexities facing the Government in the whole question of the restructuring of Australian industry. Yesterday in Melbourne I addressed a group of people concerned about the demise of manufacturing industry. It was pleasing to find that, for the first time, with the encouragement of Senator Button, the Minister for Industry and Commerce, this forum comprised people representing the Metal Trades Industry Association and the metal trades unions. They are trying to find a reasoned approach to the restructuring of manufacturing industry in Australia. It is just a pity that members of the previous Government spent so little of their seven years in office in turning their minds to the absolute demise of manufacturing industry. This Government is certainly moving to correct that situation.

I would like to give one answer to the shadow Minister. He asked about the problem of developing country preferences. There has been a long and continuing debate, affecting the previous Government as well as this one, about a total review of preferences available to developing countries. Some developing countries are complaining that others in the same area which are perhaps more developed and more sophisticated now have an advantage. The whole report is now before the Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the Minister for Industry and Commerce. I can assure the shadow Minister that a report to the Parliament will not be very long in appearing.

To sum up, it was an interesting debate and I can assure the House that the Government is looking very seriously at the mix of tariffs, quotas, bounties or other forms of protection or incentive that is required to help restructure Australian manufacturing industry to its former economic and profitable state.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BICENTENNIAL ROAD DEVELOPMENT TRUST FUND AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
ROADS GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL 1984]
Debate resumed from 28 March, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill and the Roads Grants Amendment Bill 1984, as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering both measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation before the House principally deals with three matters. The first matter relates to changes in the tendering arrangements in the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act as well as the Roads Grants Act. The second matter deals with the effort that State governments are required to make on their roads programs. The third matter relates to the effort that the State governments are required to maintain concerning their public transport programs if in fact there is some change to the way in which the Australian bicentennial road development program allocation for local roads is allocated by the States. There is a fourth matter which I will be raising and about which the Opposition wishes to express serious concern; that is, the levy itself and the indexation of that levy. I would like at this stage to indicate that the Opposition is going to oppose the legislation. The Opposition will also seek to move an amendment to the principal legislation in relation to the funds which are flowing as a result of indexation of the levy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) introduced this legislation into the House last week. In the second reading speech he pointed out that some requests had been made by the States in relation to the tendering arrangements presently in place under the bicentennial legislation, which requires that work being carried out using those bicentennial road funds on national highways and on arterial roads should be put to tender.

That is something which the former Minister, the honourable member for Gwydir ( Mr Hunt), introduced into the legislation, and it was very strongly supported by what is now the Opposition. I acknowledge that there were problems, particularly with the unions, and there were some concerns with local government about whether the tendering procedure was the best way of going about seeking the best value for the road dollar. However, the Government at that time believed that that was the way to go, and it was very strongly supported by its back bench members. I was one of those who were very strongly in favour of the tendering procedures. I maintain that position. The Opposition maintains that position. We believe that, if we are to maintain the most efficient use of moneys which are being expended on roads, if we are to get the best value for the money that taxpayers are contributing and for the money that the petrol user is contributing through the levy to roads, then to the maximum extent possible the use of the tender system is the most appropriate way to go.

What the Minister is suggesting is that there is a range of areas in which it may be possible to make an application to him and he would consider varying the tender requirement. He lists those areas. The first is where there is an emergency requirement for the works to be performed. I suppose that means that perhaps it is just not possible within the time frame to have a tender process completed. The second is where the works are of such a minor nature that the calling of tenders would involve undue additional cost. The third one is that it is not practical to prepare adequate tender specifications for the works. The fourth area is where the works are of such a kind that competitive tenders are unlikely to be received. The fifth one is where the works involve adjustments to utility services which would normally be undertaken by a government department, a government authority or a corporation not primarily responsible for the construction of roads. The last area is where the performance of the work under contract would cause unavoidable retrenchment or inefficiency in the deployment of a substantial number of State or local government road construction employees .

I do not think that anyone would want to argue too much about the first five of those areas. There is a question of good sense involved in this matter. For my money, I probably would not even require ministerial approval for waiving tender requirements. This is probably something that can be written into the system so that, where there are demonstrably good reasons for it, one can get around the requirement. However, on the last point, the Opposition expresses serious concern, principally because it believes that this matter will be the one that will cause most of the interest and be responsible for most of the applications to the Minister on this question. We are concerned about that, and we shall oppose it.

The reality is, as I think everyone realises, that over a very long period the State road authorities have built up their day labour forces. They have developed their own top heavy and very labour intensive methods of designing and constructing roads and generally going about the business of providing the roads for which they are responsible. In a normal bureaucratic fashion, that has not necessarily been the most efficient way in which they could have gone. It has built up a situation in which the unions have developed a power structure of their own within the system. It has become very difficult for anyone to challenge that and to try to suggest that there ought to be changes to it. I commend the former Minister for Transport, Mr Ralph Hunt, because he was prepared to take on that situation and to recognise that there was a great deal of inefficiency in these matters and that if we could provide some effective competition in the road making area it would be in the interests of road users and of the taxpayer who is having his dollar allocated to that purpose. So it was with a great degree of optimism that we passed the legislation that included that tendering requirement. We are very happy with the way in which it has gone.
I draw to the attention of the House the fact that the annual report for 1982- 83 on the ABRD program was tabled in this Parliament. That report referred to the tendering procedure. It says:

Under the ABRD Trust Fund Act, the States and the Northern Territory are required to call tenders for Federal Government funded National and Arterial road construction projects and for appropriate capital works on urban public transport projects.

The report says, in conclusion, having given some figures, that the figures indicate that the tender requirement is achieving good value for the roads dollar. The Minister for Transport tabled this report in the Parliament and, very shortly afterwards, brought in for our consideration legislation which seems to fly in the face of the comment made in the report on the ABRD program, which said that these figures indicate that the tender requirement is achieving good value for the roads dollar. What I draw attention to is our concern that variations will principally be in relation to this question of unavoidable retrenchment or inefficiency in the deployment of a substantial number of State or local government road construction employees. I should have thought that it would not be drawing too long a bow to imagine that the State road making authorities would be contacting the Minister on a fairly regular basis pointing out that, if they were not able to get work, there would be serious dislocation, unavoidable retrenchment or inefficiency in the deployment of a substantial number of State or local government road construction employees.

What I am saying is that this is flying in the face of what the tendering system is all about. It is clear that the system is there specifically to provide competition to those road making authorities. If those authorities are good enough they will get the work, and in fact they have got a fair amount of the work that has been tendered for on national highways and other projects which have been funded under this legislation and which have been required to be put to tender. I do not think there is that much difficulty in that matter. The fact is that competition is good for anyone. If no competition exists, State road making authorities tend to get too fat, too lazy and too bureaucratic, and the value for the road dollar begins to decline dramatically. When there is an alternative to that system, where intensely competitive private construction contractors are prepared to get in and do the jobs efficiently, to get on with them and do them in most cases more quickly and at lower cost than the State road making authorities can do them, we ought to be taking advantage of that and we should not be doing anything that would impede that process.

The Bill seeks to fly in the face of that concept. It is trying to say: ' Although we are acknowledging that the tender system is providing good value for the road dollar, and although we do not want to upset that sort of thing, if a construction authority says ''We shall have real problems with our labour force here if we do not get the work, and therefore we cannot put the work out to tender; will you give agreement to that, Mr Minister?'', the Minister will find himself having to make a judgment'. I do not think that that is appropriate. The point is that we want to have that competition. If the road making authorities are good enough, let them have the work and get on with it. But if those authorities are not good enough, if they cannot compete with the contracting industry, so be it; let the work go to the contracting industry, and let us have the best value for the dollar. The Minister said:
It is the Government's intention that the ministerial discretion will be used very infrequently, and then only after the most rigorous and detailed examination of all the factors involved.

I am a little sceptical about that. I believe that there will be a lot more approaches than the Minister is prepared to anticipate at this stage. I think it will be difficult for him to have to make decisions which may in fact mean retrenchments among State road making authority staff and all sorts of pressure on him from the trade union movement. I do not suggest for a moment that the Minister is a man without a heart or anything like that. He has a heart and that is one of the things that worry me. I think that, faced with the prospect of saying 'No, this work must go to tender' and with the prospect of a road making authority saying 'If it goes to tender we know we cannot win it; we will have to put people off', we will get back to the sort of problem from which we were getting away quite nicely. We have to have competition and the process of competition will work out where the road money goes, unrelated to the fact that day labour forces have to be maintained. So there could be some restructuring of the way in which the road industry was developing and the injection of competition would mean greater efficiency. The Opposition is not happy with that aspect of the legislation and will oppose it.

The second aspect deals with the effort that State governments are required to make in their expenditure on roads following the introduction of the ABRD legislation. The ABRD legislation provided a significant input of funds into the road building sector. Again, all credit must go to the honourable member for Gwydir, the then Minister for Transport, for having got agreement with the motoring organisations, the transport industry at large and State and local government for the introduction of a levy which would go to roads. That agreement was put to the States on the basis that there would be a significant input to the road sector and that the Federal Government was not prepared to sit back and see the States withdraw funds from the road sector and spend them somewhere else. That would be absolutely counterproductive. It would be a little like what the States did in the local government area last year, about which my colleague the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) is so concerned. When the Federal Government increased the funds flowing to local government in the last Budget, the State governments, particularly the New South Wales Government, withdrew the local government assistance fund and the rate rebate system for pensioners. The local government sector, in effect, finished up being no better off following a significant increase in the injection of funds from the Federal Government level. We were not prepared to see that going on and we said: 'If you are going to accept the money from the Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund, you have to guarantee that you will maintain your traditional effort on roads and will not cut that back'. The Minister is saying that there is no flexibility in that proposition for giving credit to a State government if it spends more than it has to spend in a particular year and that perhaps some adjustment ought to be made for that in subsequent years. I am not too sure that I am happy about that. I think the reality is that, if a State wants to make a significant effort or feels for some reason that it has to make an increased effort in one particular year, that should not reduce the effort it needs to make in later years.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are their roads.

—As the shadow Minister for local government points out, they are the States' roads. The Federal Government, through its involvement, is providing a topping up more than anything else. Roads are still a basic responsibility of the States. We do not accept a situation in which that is going on, even if it is by a manipulation of the amount that is spent in one year and allowing credits for that in another year. Our view is that the States ought to be spending more on roads anyway. If they spend more on roads in one particular year, that is quite appropriate and so be it, but we do not want a situation to develop whereby they can say: 'Because we spent a little more last year than we were required to spend under the formula arrangements, we will spend that much less under the formula arrangements next year or the year after'. For those reasons we are not too happy about that aspect of the legislation and we will oppose it. We think that the way the Act is structured at the moment is quite appropriate. Although the States might not be too happy about that, it is appropriate from the point of view of Federal taxpayers and the way we seek to have the system running here.

SPEECH.PARA: The third question raised by the legislation is the effort that must be maintained by States if they seek to switch some of the money from their local roads entitlement to the public transport sector. Under the original legislation , because there was a very close relationship between urban roads and urban public transport, it was felt that it might be appropriate to have some financial flexibility and allow States to move money between the urban roads system and the urban public transport system to allow for an appropriate allocation of resources. That was provided for by the honourable member for Gwydir as Minister for Transport when he introduced the legislation, and there it stands.

I was not aware that that capability was being used until it was used with a great fanfare in the recent New South Wales State election campaign. I think all members of the House will be aware that in that campaign the Wran Government said to the Federal Government: 'Listen fellows, we really need a big injection of money into the public transport sector to give things a bit of a boost in New South Wales. We have discovered this section of the ABRD Fund legislation which means that we can switch funding away from roads and into public transport'. So the Federal Government in Canberra, helping out its State Labor colleagues, approved the transfer of $40m from the urban road construction program to the urban public transport program. Knowing the way in which things are run in New South Wales, where the Government does not buy buses any more but leases them-it gets all geared up-its decision to buy something like 40 trains and 700 buses with the $40m that it siphoned off the road building program and into the public transport program was nothing more than a quite deliberate and quite obvious State election campaign stunt. That is the reality of the situation.

We do not agree with that. I think the intent of the legislation when it was brought down was that there be a degree of flexibility and that there be some capacity on the part of a State to move funds around a bit, but I think that the $40m stunt, smacked square in the middle of a State election campaign, reeked of absolute political opportunism. It is something that we are not happy about. I have already made a statement saying that in government we would look at that aspect of the legislation. We do not say that we would necessarily want to knock it out altogether but we would certainly look at it to see that it could not be abused in the way in which it was clearly abused by the New South Wales Government in the course of that recent election campaign. The Minister for Transport, in his second reading speech, stated:

As it stands, a State which decides to apply part of its ABRD entitlement to urban public transport projects receives no more in total assistance than if it were to direct all of its funds to road projects. On the other hand, the State becomes liable to a requirement to maintain a specified level of State expenditure on both roads and urban public transport in each year of the program .

We think that is appropriate. The Minister is seeking to remove the requirement that the State maintain its effort in the public transport sector and the urban roads sector. We think it is appropriate that that provision not be changed and for that reason we will oppose the change.

So much for the Bill. The Opposition is not happy with the changes that the Government is bringing forward. We believe that the tendering arrangements have served the taxpayer well. They have ensured that the best conceivable value is achieved for the road making dollar, that we get as many miles as we can for the dollars that we spend and that we keep pressure on the State road making authorities to ensure that they are not getting fatter and lazier but that they are getting on with the job. I think that for all those reasons the tendering arrangements have been successful. They have not had the impact on local government that local government feared in the beginning. I think local government is now supportive of the arrangements and is not particularly keen to see changes. Those matters will be dealt with by my colleague the honourable member for Dawson when he speaks in his capacity as shadow Minister for local government. Suffice it for me to say that the tendering changes have worked well . We were strongly supportive of them when the legislation was first introduced and we are strongly supportive of them now. We will oppose changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did note the report and paid no more attention to it as I regarded it as quite inaccurate in its interpretation. Accordingly, I respond by declaring that there is absolutely no change in the attitude or the practices of this Government as against the declared intentions, attitudes and practices of the Labor Party in this Parliament when in Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: What was said by me when Leader of the Opposition, and more recently in a major address to the Australian Institute of International Affairs late last year in Canberra on the topic of human rights, and what has been proposed as a formulation more specifically in the policy of the Party under the subject of human rights in the section on foreign affairs, is that, as has been the practice by this Government in the past and, as I understand, on the part of the previous Government, the best interests of people we wish to serve where human rights are at issue are not always promoted by strident public declamation. There is a range of possibilities which can be resorted to and ought to be utilised according to the circumstances of the case so that maximum effect is achieved for the benefit of the people or the causes concerned.

Secondly, it is pointed out very properly, and I am surprised that Mr Davis is not familiar with the extensive writing on the subject of human rights in international relations, that there are varying concepts between countries as to what is the equivalent of human rights. For instance, in some countries economic rights are put ahead of political and social rights. While we may have differences with countries in respect of that, they respond that it is not much good talking about abstract rights of political participation or rights of expression of points of view--

TALK.START.PARA: —If you haven't got food.

—If, as the Leader of the Opposition points out, one does not have sufficient bread and butter to live on. That is their priority, and I can understand it. But I do not understand why Mr Davis has not comprehended that point.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, Mr Davis refers in his article, in a somewhat dismissive fashion by implication at least, to the human rights initiatives by this Government concerning Father Brian Gore. I do not believe any government has taken a more overt and assertive initiative in respect of human rights than this Government did, than I did on behalf of this Government and at the direction of the Prime Minister in going to the Philippines to present personally a case in support of a proper process of law being conducted in the Philippines in respect of Father Brian Gore and his co-defendants. To this point, according to the defence counsel representing Father Gore, that initiative has been completely successful on those matters concerning the procedures about the trial. So in the circumstances, and in summary, it is quite clear to honourable members that there has been no change. In fact, this Government has given much greater emphasis and attention to and has displayed much more activity in the area of human rights than any previous government has.

—Can the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations inform the House of the Government's reaction to today's national wage case decision? Does that decision hold any implications for proponents of alternatives to the current centralised wage system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to the first part of the question of the honourable member for Hunter, the Government welcomes the decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission today to grant a 4.1 per cent increase. That decision is in line with the prices and incomes accord and the wage fixing principles established by the Commission last September which do involve a prima facie assumption of full wage indexation. Having examined the arguments of the parties , the Commission saw fit to adhere to full indexation. We believe that that decision is conducive to continued economic recovery in this country, and clearly so does the Commission. It pointed out that since its last decision there had been a substantial recovery of the economy, and of course there is every prospect that that will continue to be the case through the rest of this year.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the second part of the question, I have noticed reports that the Opposition has finally got its act together and agreed on a wages policy. It is interesting to note that the Leader of the Opposition said when he resigned from the Ministry almost exactly three years ago that what the then Government parties needed most was a wages policy. Almost three years later they finally got one together. What a damp squib it is. It would lead to the destruction of the arbitration system. It is a recipe for industrial chaos and a charter for sweated labour. Apparently the major features of this policy are a limitation of national wage increases to productivity, the restoration of penal clauses and a facilitation of reductions in wages and conditions below award levels on an individual employer basis.

I quickly mention some points on each of those elements of this policy. The limitation of national wage increases to productivity would not be accepted by the trade union movement, for the simple and good reason that it would involve the--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order on the jurisdiction of the Minister. Does it have relevance to our policies?
—The honourable member for Forrest knows about relevance in answers. The answer is associated with the question that was asked of the Minister.

—My comments are directed to the second part of the question, Mr Speaker. As I was saying, limiting national wage increases to productivity certainly would not be a practical policy because it would not be accepted by the unions. It would result in continuing reductions in living standards and, therefore, inevitably would lead to widespread wage increases outside national wage cases, which would lead to wage increases of a considerable measure overall , far beyond the national wage system, and to a breakdown of the centralised wages system. Such a wages policy certainly would not be conducive to a sustained expansion of the economy.

ANSWER.PARA: For the last 15 years penal clauses have been inoperative. For 11 of those 15 years the now Opposition was in government and never once did it seek to use them, for the very good reason that they are quite impractical. The Opposition now suggests that such clauses can be reintroduced. Of course, it is a totally impractical policy, and it knows that to be the case.

In regard to the third aspect of agreements to achieve below award wages and conditions, the proposition apparently is that if the employers and employees in a particular establishment agree to reduce wages and conditions for that firm the Commission must accept the agreement. I make a couple of points in that regard. This would put enormous power in the hands of ruthless employers who could threaten the employees that they would be sacked unless they reduced their wages. It is therefore a charter for sweated labour. It certainly would provoke a strong union reaction. If there were to be below award wage increases for less prosperous companies, then there should be well above award wage increases for the prosperous companies, and there would certainly be an acceleration of wage claims in the more prosperous areas of the economy. Furthermore, this represents an attack on the whole basis of the arbitration system, which is that unions have a right to represent employees.

In this regard it is interesting to note today's national wage decision in which the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission had something to say on this matter. In today's decision the Commission, when looking at the employers' application to vary the food preserving industry's award for its particular employers where there had been plant level agreements to give effect to the no extra claims condition, said that this 'could undermine responsibility of particular unions and of the ACTU in ensuring that the principles are adhered to '. I ask the House to take note of this:
Moreover, we should not do anything to weaken the longstanding convention that the Commission should deal with unions rather than individual employees.

It is quite clear that the Opposition's proposal is to do precisely that-to force the Commission to deal with individual employees or groups of employees unorganised rather than the trade union movement. It is a direct attack on the trade union movement and on the arbitration system. I believe, therefore, it is the sort of proposal which is bound to create absolute industrial chaos if attempts are made to bring it into being. Finally, it is clear that the Opposition's wages policy is completely and hopelessly impractical. It should go back to the drawing board for another three years to see whether it can come up with something workable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try not to provoke another outburst like that. —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Technology. What further Commonwealth assistance can be given to South Australia to help end the Portuguese millipede infestation in and around Adelaide and the Adelaide Hills?

—Funding for a joint Commonwealth-South Australian three-year study into the biological control of the Portuguese millipede ended in December 1983. The funding was on a 50:50 basis with no contribution from the Department of Foreign Affairs. The project involved the recruitment of a research scientist to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation who had already studied the millipede for his PhD thesis. He spent the greater part of the three years in Portugal which is, of course, where the millipede comes from.
—That is why it is called the Portuguese millipede.

—It could have been naturalised. He spent the greater part of the three years in Portugal searching for natural enemies that showed potential for controlling the pest in South Australia and, of course, studying their life cycles.
—That is called the socialist left.

—Ah, yes, but its feet enable it to move in all directions, even the far right. The most promising organism identified was a parasitic fly whose larvae feed and pupate inside the millipede. The next stages would be to collect supplies of the parasitic fly in Portugal, introduce them under quarantine into Australia-which would be the responsibility of my colleague the Minister for Health-develop methods for mass rearing under laboratory conditions--
—What about unemployment?

—If we only had one per millipede it would employ millions. Additional stages would be to test the fly's specificity to the millipede and whether it is likely to attack other hosts, to make field releases in the infested areas and to monitor the effectiveness in controlling the millipede. To keep the project moving South Australia has offered to finance a collecting mission to Portugal by the CSIRO scientist to gather supplies of the parasitic fly. But there is a serious problem in Adelaide. The most suitable time to do this will be next August as that is when the fly breeds. Although the scientist is presently in the early stages of a project on the biological control of pest snails in South Australia, he will work on the millipede project as necessary. This will represent a Commonwealth contribution to the solution to the problem in terms of time, expertise, and salary. If further funds are required at a later stage the CSIRO will approach the appropriate authorities in South Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: One is then confronted by the problem of asymmetrical differences. For example, the Soviet Union has more vehicles to carry weapons. It has more warheads. It has more explosive power. On the other hand, the Americans have much greater accuracy.
I then said:

TALK.START.PARA: —You reject the Defence advice?
—Because of that, I continued:

ANSWER.PARA: Taking these considerations on board, the obvious conclusion is not to spend time trying to work out who is edging ahead, who is sliding behind, who on balance has the greater destructive power or who is lagging but to recognise that both super-powers have sufficient capability to destroy themselves and the world with them many times over. Accordingly, we should work for arms control and disarmament.
In response to the right honourable member for New England, who has been accused of many crimes in this House, significantly none of them requiring courage in their perpetration--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about you and Mick Young?
—Order! I ask the Leader of the National Party to cease interjecting.
—Mr Speaker--
—Order! The Leader of the National Party will not answer back when he is requested to cease interjecting.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I ask the honourable gentleman to withdraw those remarks, which I regard as offensive.
—Order! I ask the Minister to withdraw the remarks.

—Mr Speaker, in response to a much earlier interjection of the Leader of the National Party I say that the ONA has declared--
—Order! I ask the Minister to assist the Chair by withdrawing without qualification.
—in its report 'The Global Balance' that it is extraordinarily difficult to quantify in this area and to do so with any confidence.
—Order! I ask the Minister to assist the Chair by withdrawing unqualifiedly.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: WOORABINDA ABORIGINAL RESERVE: DEATH OF ABORIGINAL

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to the recent incident at Woorabinda Aboriginal Reserve in central Queensland when an elderly Aboriginal man was refused medical facilities and, it is alleged, died as a consequence. Can the Minister inform the House whether an inquest will be held into this most unfortunate incident? If an inquest is not held, what steps will the Government take to ensure that all the facts of the matter are inquired into and made public? Has the Minister assessed the standard of Aboriginal health, especially in Aboriginal reserves in Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned, as I am certain all honourable members are concerned, with the recent incident at Woorabinda, where it is alleged that the tardiness of hospital authorities in providing medical services to an elderly Aboriginal man may have resulted in his unnecessary death. I am concerned to see that an appropriate inquiry is conducted into all the circumstances that surrounded that incident. I have written to both the Queensland Minister for Health and the Queensland Minister for Northern Development and Aboriginal and Island Affairs suggesting that this matter should be dealt with appropriately under Queensland law and an inquest should take place. To date I have not received any assistance from the Queensland authorities. I have simply been told that no inquest as such is planned.

ANSWER.PARA: As I read the Queensland Coroners Act, section 17 would allow the Queensland Minister to direct that an inquest be held even though a magistrate may have felt that one was not necessary. I propose to pursue this matter further. Indeed , if we cannot get the assistance of the Queensland authorities on this matter, it may well be necessary for me to consider making a reference to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs for its inquiry. It would be a matter that could be looked into by that Committee. This sort of incident attracted widespread attention when, as honourable members will recall, our media reported on a situation which arose in the United States of America when a man sought an ambulance service for a relative and that relative died because of the way in which his approach was received. That incident caused a great deal of comment in the media. I suggest that if the media examined closely the situation at Woorabinda, which is much closer to home, it would find a set of circumstances which not only parallels the situation which caused so much comment in Australia but in some areas may have been worse.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Has the Minister 's attention been drawn to the results of a survey conducted by the Confederation of Australian Industry of 41 major exporters wherein more than three-quarters of those surveyed opposed the introduction of an overseas trading corporation? Has the Minister's attention further been drawn to the criticism by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and other business bodies of the proposed overseas trading corporation? In light of the business community's almost unanimous opposition, will the Minister abandon his proposal to establish an overseas trading corporation which nobody has asked for and which nobody wants?

—The honourable gentleman needs to get more evidence than he now has because the independent survey which the Department commissioned as to the feasibility of an overseas trading corporation has already produced evidence that such a corporation would increase trade by $300m, and that is in the very confined atmosphere which exists at present. The idea of an overseas trading corporation is not to take away trade from the private sector, but to add a facility which the private sector does not now have. If one were to look at world trade on a barter basis-I am not suggesting that that is the only basis, but 30 per cent of world trade is conducted on that basis-one would have noticed that recently the United States of America, for example, was engaged in such trade with Jamaica. One would also have noticed that the facilities of an overseas trading corporation are already used by Singapore, Indonesia and other countries. I can understand the criticism by the Chamber of Commerce, which has a pretty blinkered view at any time. I am well aware that one of the secretaries of the Chamber of Commerce has-what will I say?-Liberal Party aspirations. So I do not take much notice of correspondence I receive in that regard.
—What about the political aspirations of Simon Crean? Is it all right for a Vice-President of the ACTU?
—Total double standards.
—Double standards.

—I do not understand. All I am saying is that I do not think that the honourable gentleman who asked the question has an understanding of what trade is all about. I mentioned the fact that one of the secretaries had political aspirations. What is wrong with that? I am trying to make the point that there is a great need for an additional facility in the private sector. It is also very important that that facility be able to compete, as other countries do, for trade which at present we are not able to get. That is the situation. I am quite happy to discuss that matter and any area which the Chamber of Commerce wants to discuss with me. It has never at any stage sought to have any discussions with me about the matter. It might be more important for it to discuss the matter with the independent group that did the survey, that is, the Australian Bank.
—Can the Minister for Aviation inform the House what action is being taken to nominate the site for a second airport for Sydney?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate that question without notice. A considerable amount of action is being undertaken to select a site for a second airport in Sydney. I should say by way of preface, because this has been a matter for discussion recently in the House, that the Government is committed to seeking that site for the very good reason that the current site, Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, is inadequate. It would have been inadequate even if, as was proposed by the previous Government, a close-spaced parallel runway was constructed. The site is also inadequate in the sense that it is causing to the neighbourhood of the airport, in which is situated the honourable member's electorate, a considerable amount of noise nuisance. It is the worst noise affected airport. So for a variety of reasons going to both the inadequacy of the facility for aviation purposes and the impact of the facility on the neighbourhood, the Government believes that it is desirable to select a second site for Sydney Airport.

ANSWER.PARA: We are, in consultation with the New South Wales State Government, investigating a number of potential sites. Those sites include the final sites identified in the previous Major Airport Needs of Sydney study of sites to replace Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. They include two sites south of Sydney . Our objective is substantially different from the objective of the MANS investigation which sought a total replacement for Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. It is not my intention to seek a site which would amount to a total replacement for Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. My objective is to select a site for a second airport in Sydney. We are undertaking an investigation of that at several levels. First, we are investigating what sort of purpose such an airport would serve and, secondly, what size such an airport should be. At a minimum it would require to be somewhat less than the 5,000-odd hectares which were being sought by the MANS survey. Thirdly, we are investigating where the location of that airport should be. In this instance, because of the changed dimensions of the site we are seeking and also because of the possibility that there are alternative sites other than those identified by MANS, we are obliged to undertake an extensive series of engineering surveys both of the sites identified by MANS and of alternative sites.

It is our belief that the possibility of a second airport site for Sydney is welcomed by the general Sydney public, if not necessarily by those areas located in the areas which to this point have been identified as possible sites. Our objective is and will be to ensure that people who live near those identified sites have ample opportunity to comment on the potential environmental impact of an airport in those areas and to recommend to us alternative courses of action. This is not a matter which can be dealt with in a hurried fashion. It is a matter which I think, in terms of its significance to the aviation industry generally, its significance to Sydney and its significance to persons resident near potential sites, requires a great deal of attention from government. Nevertheless, we intend to proceed expeditiously within that framework to the selection of a second site. I have indicated that we expect to be able to do that early in the new year.

Our intention is to provide a permanent resolution of the aviation problems of Sydney, a resolution which will ensure that Sydney remains the premier point of entry for aviation services. I believe it will be a decision which will be welcomed ultimately both because of its employment aspects and also because it will ensure that Sydney remains, as it should remain, the principal aviation centre of Australia.

He really underlined the extraordinary sensitivity to criticism of this Government and in particular the extraordinary sensitivity to criticism of the leader of this Government.

Anybody who has studied the career of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) would be struck by quite a number of things. One of those things is the extraordinary sensitivity of the Prime Minister to any kind of criticism. to any kind of questioning of his personal integrity, to any suggestion that in some way he is, after all, like one of us. He has this elitist response to any kind of criticism : ''Criticise Young, criticise Duffy, criticise Hayden, criticise Peacock, criticise Fraser, criticise anybody, but if you criticise me, it is a national scandal and something will really have to be done about it'.

SPEECH.PARA: I come now to the rather extraordinary events that were reported in this morning's Press concerning the Caucus meeting. I am delighted that the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) is at the despatch box and that he will respond on behalf of the Government. Of course, the Prime Minister, that great consensus- seeker, was not quite so charitable. He is reported to have said:
Freedom of the Press is freedom to lie, I suppose.

That really is a marvellous statement. It indicates a great generosity of spirit on the part of this person who somehow or other is above it all. I will be fascinated to hear a denial of that remark from the Minister for Communications. I will be delighted to hear him say: 'Oh, the Prime Minister did not make any critical remarks about the ABC. He would not do that'. The remark demonstrates very clearly that this Prime Minister has a paranoia about any criticism that is levelled at him from sections of the Press.

We all remember that famous exchange about 'being up to your armpits in blood', which occurred at the commencement of the last Federal election campaign. We all remember that meek-as-a-lamb denial by the Prime Minister when he said: 'No, I had nothing to do with it. I was not up to my armpits in blood in disposing of the former Leader of the Opposition. I just sat there and quietly contemplated my navel. All of a sudden, I woke up and the leadership of the Australian Labor Party fell into my lap. In other words, I was the passive beneficiary of a chain of circumstances over which I had no control. I woke up one morning and found that, whacko, I was the Leader of the Australian Labor Party and I was about to become Prime Minister of Australia'.

Of course, 12 months after that meek as a lamb denial we all know what is the real story. Of course, we are indebted to Paul Kelly's book The Hawke Ascendancy which described to us that the Prime Minister, far from being a passive beneficiary of that change in the leadership of the Australian Labor Party, was a very active participant; that he was plotting and planning. He endeavours to create the pose that somehow or other he is not like any of us, that he is quite different from us and from all other Government members. But somehow or other that story found him out, somehow or other it demonstrated that he was right in the thick of it, plotting and planning with members of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and other members of the Australian labour movement, to bring about a change in the leadership.

We all know that the Prime Minister has a certain paranoia about attacks that are made on him by the media. We have all been impressed by the Prime Minister's political double standards. When he was in the Labor Party, in opposition, he blindly opposed every single thing that the Government of the day wanted to do. When he was the President of the ACTU he did not invite the Prime Minister of the day to any of his celebrations. But, of course, now that he has become Prime Minister, he expects every organisation to respect and honour his office. But that is perfectly all right because in some way he is different and in some way he is entitled to adopt that kind of double standard and to show that kind of sensitivity to criticism!

We all know that in 1972 there was a suggestion that the ABC was being criticised by members of the then McMahon Government. One or two members of that Government, as I think my friend the honourable member for Gippsland will know, did not regard the ABC as necessarily a branch of the Liberal or National Party of Australia; anything but. At that time Mr Hawke was full of righteous indignation. He said he was appalled that any Liberal politician should question the integrity of the ABC. He said that under a Labor government the ABC's autonomy would be strengthened. We are told, now that he is Prime Minister and now that he has the capacity to strengthen that autonomy, that unless the ABC toes the line its funds will be reduced. That is just another example of the appalling double standards of this Prime Minister. This is an example of the appalling standards--

TALK.START.PARA: —He is telling lies.

—No. These are appalling examples of this Prime Minister's double standards. On the question of political interference in the ABC, we are reminded once again by Paul Kelly's book that during the election campaign Mr Hawke worked behind the scenes to influence the ABC's coverage of the 1983 election campaign. That book describes how Mr Hawke contacted the ABC Chairman to protest about the coverage on the AM program. When the then Chairman of the ABC did not succumb to Mr Hawke's will there was righteous indignation involving the present Prime Minister and the present Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button). That Minister contacted the ABC Chairman twice during the election campaign and on both occasions attempted to put pressure on her to act as some kind of censor of ABC programs.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the House what the Labor Party would have said if during an election campaign this kind of pressure, this kind of intimidation, this kind of interference, had been applied to the ABC by a Liberal Prime Minister or by a Liberal Minister. We would have had speeches from the rooftops and from the steps of Parliament House about the freedom of the Press, the rights of minorities and threats to our democratic institution.

Of course we all, particularly the Minister at the table, recall very well that after the election the ABC Chairman was publicly attacked by the Minister for Industry and Commerce. He publicly attacked one of the most respected academic figures in Australia, Dame Leonie Kramer, and the Minister for Communications, no doubt under pressure, refused to declare confidence in her. The end result was that this Government of reconciliation, bipartisanship and consensus, secured, brought about the removal of the entire former Board of the ABC and was so miserable and mean-minded that it was not willing to offer Dame Leonie Kramer even a place on the Board of the Corporation. At about that time the Deputy Prime Minister made the extraordinary allegation that the ABC was so completely anti-Labor that 'it was anxious to exploit any situation at all'.

I ask all fairminded members of this House and the Australian community whether they really believe that large sections of the media have some kind of vendetta against the present Government. I think the ordinary person would take the view that a Prime Minister in our present political circumstances who runs around saying 'The media is out to get us' has some kind of paranoia about the media. I wonder whether the Prime Minister seriously expects the Australian community to believe that in some way the ABC is out to get the Australian Labor Party. I think the Prime Minister has spent far too much time lately in the company of the New South Wales Premier. I think he is adopting some of the paranoia of the New South Wales Premier about the ABC. He would do well to contemplate his own attitude and the balance of his own mind on this subject, because yesterday's Caucus meeting demonstrates a very thin skin on the part of the Prime Minister and a number of senior Ministers of the Government.

The Government has been willing to resort very readily to the cheap intimidation of an organisation which has always valued its independence and which has done a great service-often a discomforting service-to both sides of politics. Let nobody imagine that the Liberal Party has enjoyed some of the criticisms that have been made of it by the ABC. But the fact remains that through the years the ABC has been a very worthwhile organisation in Australia. It has shown courage, it has shown independence and, frankly, that is what the Prime Minister cannot really abide.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) started his speech by talking about the political ambitions of a member of the Australian Chamber of Commerce. The honourable member for Bennelong referred to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as a craven populist. He referred to the concerns that the Prime Minister has about the media. I ask all honourable members opposite to give some consideration to the fact that in the past 10 years, or maybe more, in this country, no person has been more exposed to public scrutiny than the present Prime Minister of Australia. It is absolute nonsense to argue that this Prime Minister, of all people, is concerned about that sort of exposure.

It is also worth noting how that so-called 'craven populist', referred to by the honourable member for Bennelong, is regarded by the people of Australia at the moment. According to all the polls he has a popularity rating of between 74 per cent and 78 per cent. The Opposition talks about the exposure that the Prime Minister of this country has had to the Australian people. The result of that exposure is the way that these people regard him, which is as reflected in the polls.

In relation to the specific matters raised, the honourable member for Bennelong really got to the guts of it in the last four or five minutes of his speech. In those few minutes at the end of his speech he dealt with the question of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. That is the real issue today: The sensitivity of the Government, according to the Opposition, as exemplified by the Prime Minister's attack on the ABC. The real issue is the question of the independence of the ABC. I propose to deal in some detail with the record of this Government on that matter. It must be emphasised that such independence-and let us get this clear-does not mean that the ABC, or for that matter any other media organisation, is shrouded in some immunity from criticism. I do not think that even honourable members opposite are putting such an absurd proposition.

The fact is that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is paramount and that independence is and will continue to be entirely respected on this side of the House. That does not mean that from time to time honourable members on this side of the House and on that side of the House cannot and will not be critical of the ABC. Before proceeding with that, let me say that one of the most extraordinary aspects of today's debate is that the desperation of the Opposition becomes worse day by day. We have in this Parliament today a discussion of a matter of public importance based at best on hearsay evidence of unconfirmed reports of what is alleged to have been said at a private meeting.

I said that I would deal in some detail with the record of this Government. I want to deal particularly with my attitude to the independence of the ABC and the attitude of those opposite to the independence of the ABC. Their attitude surfaced very early in this Parliament. I refer to two matters which were raised in this Parliament, the first on 3 May 1983 and the second on 4 May 1983. On the first of those occasions the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) asked whether I or any member of my staff had been approached or contacted by anyone suggesting that I intervene in the Four Corners program alleging political interference by the Premier of New South Wales in the course of justice in that State. The answer to that question was very simple and short. It was no. The question indicated the state of mind of those opposite in raising the fact that there was on the ABC a program in relation to which the Premier of New South Wales rightfully took action available to him, that is, an action for defamation against the ABC. I recall an interjection from the honourable member for Bennelong when that matter was debated. He said that that program was very well researched. We will see about that when the outcome of the defamation proceedings is known.
The second question again indicates the mentality of those opposite. On 4 May, one day later, I was asked what action I had taken-and I quote:
. . . relevant to the Australian Broadcasting Commission's program alleging political interference by the Premier of New South Wales in the course of justice in that State, since he-
that is, I-
learnt of that program and its contents.
Again I was able to say:

The ABC has been requested to supply a transcript of the program. Other than that, I have not taken any action. The question of the programming of the ABC is a matter for it, and we on this side of the House respect totally its independence in that regard.

That was the position then and that is the position now. There will be no political interference from this Government in that absolutely fundamental factor in the ABC's whole operation-its independence on the question of programs .

—It is interesting to hear the honourable member interjecting. Even Professor Downing cannot deny the mounting evidence--

—Just listen to this. The honourable member normally interjects and carries on and will not listen to anybody. He has behaved himself reasonably well today and he could learn something if he just listened for a change. To continue:

That was in 1975. Then, of course, we had the coup and Mr Nixon became caretaker Postmaster-General. Following that coup, those opposite were quaintly termed the 'Acting Government'. Let us look at what happened then. We get back to Mr Nixon who was reported as follows:

—I do not care whether it was yesterday or 10 years ago. The honourable member can sit here and listen to his record on this issue. On 13 November the report of Mr Nixon's statement continued:

On 18 October 1983 Mr Anthony put to me a question in relation to the conduct of the Queensland elections. He said:
Can the Minister assure the House that neither he nor anyone under his authority had any part in this attempt at political interference in the ABC news service?

He was referring to some insane suggestion he had got in his mind that there was some interference in the news coverage at that stage in the Queensland election. On that occasion I was able again to answer him without any equivocation. I said :

I have heard other people say so often, and it is now obvious that it is so very true, that there are some very slow learners opposite and it is necessary to repeat again-I do not know whether it will ultimately sink into the head of the right honourable member for Richmond, the Leader of the National Party-that no person has spoken to me at any time about anything connected with the allegations until Monday last, when the Press reports were referred to me. They have advised me that none of them was asked by anyone to request, direct or otherwise influence the ABC to change its current policy. Further, I have been advised by my staff that none of them has spoken to the ABC on any matter connected in any way with the Queensland election.
That was said in the adjournment debate on 18 October 1983, as reported at page 1885 of Hansard.

Let us move to what we did when we came into office.
