. . . this Government is committed to maintaining a strong and independent ABC, able to meet the broadcasting needs of the Australian people. This Government believes that as Australia's only national broadcaster the ABC has served and must be able to continue to serve in the forefront of Australian broadcasting.

That was the attitude of this Government then. That is the attitude of this Government now. That will continue to be the attitude of this Government to the ABC. This Government regards the fundamental independence of the ABC as something which will be defended by this side of politics as long as it is about . The fact is that honourable members opposite are always on the attack on this issue because they have such putrid, guilty minds. Every time anything crops up in relation to the ABC, they start attacking the ABC and attacking the Government in relation to the ABC when, as a matter of fact --

It must be yet another source of embarrassment for the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) and his deputy to have to carry the heritage of the National Party into areas such as this one.

Let us just look at some of the performances turned in by the former member for Gippsland, the Hon. Peter Nixon, when he was an Opposition spokesman. On 17 March 1975 he accused the ABC Commissioner, Professor Downing, of being either a naive academic or part of a plot to disseminate socialist propaganda Australia- wide over the ABC radio news. I suggest that that was somewhat over-sensitive. When Professor Downing attempted to defend himself Mr Nixon asked how Professor Downing's comments, that the ABC reports and comments from a neutral position favouring neither one political belief nor another, could apply in that instance . A few months later, when he no longer had the excuse of being in Opposition, Mr Nixon said publicly that a moderator was needed to balance what he called ' the ABC's now well established bias towards Labor and the socialist side of politics'. Mr Nixon declared in November 1975:

Never in its history will the ABC be under such close scrutiny as during the coming election campaign. ABC news and public affairs programs must expect unprecedented watchfulness by the National Country Party and the Liberal Party.

Many of us in this chamber will recall the furore in the community that centered on the debate about whether a moderator would be imposed upon the ABC. Those comments and others quoted by the Minister are in my view pretty impressive stuff on which to build a reputation of concern about the independence of the ABC and the freedom of the news media in general. This is just one more example of the political acrobatics the Opposition is prepared to undertake in its desperate search for an electorally attractive stance. Yet the truth about the situation of the ABC is perfectly obvious to anyone who cares to look at the record. Let us compare what Mr Nixon said and the attitude condoned by the Opposition parties with what the current Minister said last year when he was introducing the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill. The Minister said:

. . . this Government is committed to maintaining a strong and independent ABC, able to meet the broadcasting needs of the Australian people. This Government believes that as Australia's only national broadcaster the ABC has served and must be able to continue to serve in the forefront of Australian broadcasting.

That is the position of this Government. It is a position which will not change while the Labor Party is in government. It is a position which is recognised throughout the Labor Party as being the foundation of maintaining the integrity of the ABC and the quality of its news and current affairs reporting.

Let me now turn briefly to the other problem which seems to be worrying the Opposition, particularly the honourable member for O'Connor. In my view, the Opposition is using the ABC only as an example of what it has interpreted as this Government's undue sensitivity to criticism. The Opposition's contributions to debates and discussions in this House are proving to have more entertainment value than many of the ABC programs which are actually classified as comedy. Maybe I am being unkind. Perhaps the message being conveyed by the people of Australia to the leaders and members of the Opposition parties has not got through yet. They obviously have not read the latest polls published in today's Press. Perhaps they also have not heard about the many Liberals who prefer our leader to their own. Perhaps they have not got around to doing their sums about where the support of the Australian people lies and who they want as the government.

To be sure, we are sensitive and we have done nothing to hide our sensitivity over the last 13 months. We are sensitive to the need of people to own their own homes. Look at our first home owners scheme. We are sensitive to the needs of people who are unemployed. Look at the $300m we are spending to employ people. Those of us on this side are sensitive-maybe, as someone suggested, unduly sensitive-to those needs. As the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher) demonstrated last week, these are sensitivities that the Opposition cannot even begin to perceive, let alone act upon. We are also sensitive to the criticism which stems from the cynical light in which politicians are held as a result of seven years of conservative hypocrisy and manipulation.

This Government is not ashamed to admit to a sensitivity to the feelings of the people of Australia. There is one thing, however, to which we are absolutely and totally impervious and that is the kind of ludicrous, trumped up, cynical charge which the Opposition has dragged up today. It is the Opposition, not the Government, which has shown its weakness in the face of criticism.

This Bill, unlike many Bills to amend the income tax law, covers but one subject . Its need arises because of the decision taken by the Opposition parties in the Senate and some other honourable senators to reject outright measures contained in a Bill passed by this House, the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1983. The measures would counter some tax avoidance practices associated with employee superannuation funds which are, by any test, blatant and contrived.

As I explained in my second reading speech on the introduction of the earlier Bill, some proprietors of businesses, after establishing superannuation funds purportedly to provide superannuation benefits for their employees, wind up the funds in circumstances where the accumulated assets of the funds are paid out, not to the employees but to the proprietors themselves. This happens after advantage has been taken of the considerable tax concessions provided for superannuation contributions and the income of the funds. One technique adopted is to terminate the employees' employment under some pretence shortly before they would otherwise become entitled to substantial superannuation benefits from the funds. Another is to make tax deductible contributions for workers who, in the ordinary course of events, do not stay long with their employer. The benefits that are forfeited are then allocated to the proprietors who, technically, as the sole remaining employees, take the whole of the accumulated assets. The funds, having been wound up in this way, are not then able to meet any tax liability which, under the existing law, may fall to be met by them.

Not only does the revenue, and therefore the Australian taxpayer, suffer by these particularly distasteful practices, but the unsuspecting ordinary employees of companies are deprived of superannuation benefits accumulated in their name and ostensibly for their benefit. It is difficult to imagine a more brazen abuse of the taxation law. Ingeniously planned to give the appearance of bona fide superannuation arrangements, these practices involve clear raids against the revenue and the unsuspecting employees, who are used as mere pawns in this particular unsavoury practice. It is one where the losers are the taxpayers of Australia and the winners are those who seek to enjoy the benefits and privileges of living in this country without meeting their rightful share of the tax burden.

A policy of retrospective application of anti-avoidance legislation was one which we put before the people of Australia on 5 March last year and on which we were elected to govern. That policy was confirmed by my colleague the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) in a statement he made shortly after we came to office. In the Government's view these tax avoidance practices are clearly in that category of schemes which we intended would be covered by our retrospectivity policy. Not only are they of the most blatant kind, but they contain elements of fraud against employees, many of whom stood to benefit from many years membership of a superannuation scheme which has been afforded substantial taxation benefits. A technical explanation of the proposed section 26AFA is contained in the memorandum that was circulated to honourable members at the time of introduction of the Bill containing the original measure. I commend the Bill to the House.

This Bill proposes to implement the Government's decision, announced on 12 January 1984, to pay a temporary bounty for two years from that date on the production in Australia of two-stroke air cooled spark ignition engines. Engines up to a maximum power output of 4.5 kilowatts with an Australian content of not less than 55 per cent will be eligible for the bounty, if during the two-year bounty period they are sold for use in Australia or used in Australia by the manufacturer. The rate of bounty is to be $6 per engine and bounty payments are to be limited to a maximum of $1.2m per annum. The bounty is designed to assist established manufacturers who were producing these engines at the time of the Government's announcement. It is part of a package of industry assistance determined by the Government following consideration of the Industries Assistance Commission's report of 6 July 1983 on lawnmowers, certain engines and parts.

Australian production of engines, other than motor vehicle engines, has diminished very rapidly in recent years. Such engines have in the past been produced by James N. Kirby Pty Ltd, Norton Villiers, Simpson Pope Ltd, Toowoomba Foundry and Victa Ltd. By the time of the last IAC inquiry in 1977, only Norton Villiers, Toowomba and Victa were involved in engine production. Today the only producer is Victa, which produces a single-engine model for use mainly in its lawnmowers. To remain competitive, Victa has incurred considerable expenditure in the development of a new engine, the Series 80. This engine has fewer parts, reportedly incorporates the latest available two-stroke engine technology and has a lower cost of production. Victa has indicated that the engine is suited to many industrial applications, in competition with imported four-stroke engines. The potential for increased export sales by Victa has been considerably enhanced by the new engine. Manufacture of this new engine commenced in 1983 and full production is expected to begin in August 1984.

In its report, the IAC considered that the then existing general duty rate of 35 per cent on engine imports provided effective assistance in excess of that available to manufacturing industry generally and tended to penalise the relatively lightly assisted engine-using industries. The Commission considered a 15 per cent duty would provide Victa with a rate of return on funds employed of about the same order achieved by manufacturing industry generally in recent years and would be sufficient to maintain local engine production. Accordingly, the IAC recommended that the 35 per cent duty be reduced to 25 per cent immediately and be further phased down to 15 per cent over two years.

The Government considered the reduction in assistance as recommended by the IAC could endanger the continued production of small engines and decided that the long term duty rate should be 25 per cent, in line with other power sources such as electric motors and motor vehicle engines. To assist the wide range of engine users, it was decided that the duty reduction should be immediate. However, to give Victa time to adjust to the lower level of assistance and to have an opportunity to develop new markets for the engine, to thoroughly test its commercial attractiveness, and to recoup some of the developmental costs, the Government has decided to pay a temporary bounty for two years. The proposed bounty of $6 per engine roughly equates to a 10 per cent duty and will effectively maintain the existing level of assistance for the next two years.

In taking this decision the Government was mindful of its desire to encourage industries which are willing to undertake research and development activities and to modernise their operations to improve their long term viability. To ensure that assistance for engine production is not undermined by imported lawnmowers which incorporate engines, the Government also decided that the duty on lawnmowers should remain at 25 per cent, instead of 15 per cent as recommended by the IAC. The Government accepted the IAC's recommendation that engines not made in Australia be dutiable at minimum rates. The assistance accorded lawnmowers and engines will be referred to the IAC for a further review in four years time.
Financial Impact Statement

I indicated earlier that there will be an annual upper limit of $1.2m on bounty payments. The maximum cost of this bounty scheme will therefore be $2.4m over the two-year bounty period. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BICENTENNIAL ROAD DEVELOPMENT TRUST FUND AMENDMENT BILL 1984

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate on this Bill is resumed, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and the Roads Grants Amendment Bill 1984.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the time that remains to me I want to say a few words about the Australian bicentennial road levy. I think that most honourable members will recall that in 1982 there was discussion between the then Government, industry and motorists' organisations about whether a levy would be acceptable and, if acceptable, whether it would be applied to the construction of roads. At that stage there was a lot of concern in the community, and quite rightly so, about the amount of money that was going to roads. All sorts of work had been done by those concerned with this matter and it was clear beyond any shadow of a doubt that, in real terms, the amount of money going to roads was declining. There was concern by the then Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), that he had not been able to secure more road funding. There was concern at local government level and State government level. There was concern by members of this Parliament about the fact that the relative effort on roads was declining.

SPEECH.PARA: At that time, as a result of discussions with local government and discussions at the Premiers Conference, a 2c per litre levy on motor spirit and automotive distillate was agreed to but only on the basis, and very clearly on the basis, that the 2c would be hypothecated and used on roads. The Australian Council of Local Government Associations issued a statement on 19 July 1982 in which it said:
Local Government would welcome a new Federal Government commitment to road funding even if a fuel surcharge had to be introduced.
It went on to say:

. . . the fuel surcharge must be spent on roads and the funds generated by it must be in addition to a road funding commitment by each of the three spheres of government which at least keeps pace with the road price inflation.

It was fairly clear, from the point of view of local government and similar statements that were made by motorists' organisations, that the levy would be agreed to on the basis that it was spent on roads. The then shadow Minister for Transport, the present Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris), rejected it. He issued a statement in August 1982 in which he said:
Labor thus rejects Fraser's proposed new fuel levy of 2 cents-a-litre, to rip another $350m annually from motorists, to fund national highways.
He went on to say:
The new levy does absolutely nothing for arterial and local roads and also disadvantages Australia's country people by raising transport costs.

All I can say is that on that occasion, as on so many others, the then shadow Transport Minister, the present Minister, had it wrong. Of course, in office he has now capitulated and has come to the view that the levy is something that he is quite prepared to accept and that his Government is not prepared to remove. We say 'Hear, hear!' to that. We recognise that the agreement that was struck between the previous Government, local government, State governments and motorists' organisations was appropriate and the 2c that was agreed upon as the levy would be allocated to roads.

Of course, that was wonderful. It was going along extraordinarily well until the Treasurer (Mr Keating) introduced his Budget last August. In that Budget the Treasurer provided for the indexation of all the different excises and things that the Government collects. No specific mention was made of the 2c road levy but it became apparent within a brief period that the 2c road levy was one of those excises that would be indexed. That started to raise some concern in the minds of people who were worried about these matters, myself included. It became apparent very quickly that the legislation which had been passed by the former Government was only going to provide for 2c a litre flowing into the bicentennial road trust fund. The former Government provided the 2c because it had absolutely no intention of indexing any excises, let alone this excise. Therefore there was no need to take into account anything other than the 2c levy .

But the situation changed quite dramatically. When the Treasurer indexed these levies this one was also indexed. Contrary to the spirit of the agreement that was made between the Commonwealth, the States, local government and motorists that the amount raised by the levy would flow to roads, it became quite apparent that all the excess over 2c that came from indexation would flow simply to Consolidated Revenue. There was concern about that.

The Australian Road Federation has produced an estimate of the shortfall to the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund resulting from the allocation of the indexed component of the levy to Consolidated Revenue. That is an amount which, over the life of the program up to 1988-89, totals $491m. I have put those figures to the Treasurer and to my knowledge he has not been prepared to dispute them. As far as I am concerned, they stand. I seek leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard a table from the Australian Road Federation concerning the shortfall in the levy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill involves three areas of amendment to the principal Act. The three areas deal with tendering, real terms State expenditure and public transport. The clauses of the Bill dealing with tendering allow for flexibility in the tendering system. In remote, sparsely populated areas such as the Northern Territory the inflexible tendering provisions currently in the Act create difficulty. In remote, sparsely populated areas it is not always possible to get competitive tenderers for jobs. In all areas the contract may involve such a small amount of money that it is either disproportionately too expensive to justify tenders or not practical to prepare tender documents. This Bill allows for those types of contracts to be exempted from the strict inflexible requirements previously necessary for tendering in all cases. I am sure that the Territory and local government authorities in the Northern Territory will welcome these amendments which will allow flexibility and take account of local conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from changes to the tendering procedures the Bill introduces an averaging formula for establishing whether the State and Northern Territory governments are maintaining their road construction expenditure in real terms. At present the Act once again is inflexible. If, for example, a State or Territory spends above the level of real term expenditure for a number of years and then drops off in one year the provisions of the Act currently would adversely affect the grant to that State or Territory in the year the expenditure drops off. The Bill allows for the expenditure to be averaged.

Since we are dealing with State or Territory expenditure it is instructive to consider this Labor Government's record in road expenditure and the record of the Northern Territory Government on the same issue. The 1982-83 Budget, the first Budget of the Hawke Labor Government, is in relation to road construction expenditure, something that we can justly be proud of. Road funding increased by 45 per cent to $1,233 billion in 1982-83. That is the largest increase in road funding for more than 40 years. It contrasts markedly with the record of the Fraser Government, which managed a decline of 23 per cent in real terms in road funding during its seven disastrous years in office. Funding for Northern Territory road construction has gone up by 17 per cent to $35.9m. At the same time the 1982-83 Budget increased the total dollar allocation to the Northern Territory by $125m, taking it up to $850m. This too was a record increase in expenditure. In fact, that is the largest dollar increase in funding granted to the Northern Territory since self-government.

This funding boost allows the Northern Territory Government itself to spend more on road construction. The Hawke Labor Government can justly claim credit for that Northern Territory Government's expenditure on road construction because the Australian Government provides almost 90 per cent of the Northern Territory Government's income. Put another way, about 90c of every dollar spent by the Northern Territory Government on roads or anything else in the Northern Territory comes directly from the Australian Government.

Of great importance to the Northern Territory is a project outside the Northern Territory which has received a big boost from the Hawke Labor Government. I am referring to the section of the Stuart Highway between Adelaide and Alice Springs. The section is actually in the electorate of the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) in South Australia. I praise this Labor member for Grey for the excellent work he has done in lobbying for this project. The Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) has announced that the Stuart Highway project will be accelerated so it will be completed by mid-1986. It is difficult to describe just how significant that project will be for Territory trade and tourism when the highway is completed in about two years time.

For decades it has been an ongoing national scandal that most of this so-called national highway has remained unsealed. The report for 1982-83 on the Australian bicentennial road development program indicates that 579 kilometres of the 925 kilometres of road between Adelaide and Alice Springs in South Australia remain unsealed. It should not be forgotten that Liberal-National Party governments are directly responsible for that continuing scandal. After all, they have been in power in this country for 31 of the past 35 years.

When the Hawke Labor Government presides over the completion of the sealing of the Stuart Highway in about two years time there could be at the same time another continuing national scandal in relation to the Stuart Highway. The scandal could then relate to the section of the Stuart Highway between Alice Springs and Darwin. It could be a scandal because of the insistence by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory that the section of the Stuart Highway between Alice Springs and Darwin does not need upgrading.

The work of this two-faced saboteur is not limited to the Territory's justice system or the Territory's act of self-government. Of course, it is all part of his perverse Canberra-bashing campaign to get elected to this House. Any Territorian who has any doubt about just what disasters would befall the Territory if by some fluke they decided to opt for an Opposition member in a Peacock Opposition in place of a Government member in the popular, successful Hawke Labor Government need only look at what the Chief Minister has done in the Northern Territory on the question of the upgrading of the section of the Stuart Highway between Alice Springs and Darwin. This saboteur has consistently said that the section of the Stuart Highway between Alice Springs and Darwin does not need upgrading. This stupid, insensitive statement has put that whole project at risk.

I shall make my position clear. However, my problem is this: When I approach the Minister for Transport, as I have done repeatedly over the past few months, about the absolute necessity of upgrading I am confronted with the Chief Minister's statement that it is not necessary. If only the Chief Minister knew what damage his ill-considered shoot from the hip statements do. The statements he makes in the Northern Territory do get down to Canberra. People here unfortunately hear them. If only he would stop and think every now and then of what is best for the Territory instead of what he thinks is best for his doomed election campaign. Not even the Chief Minister's own Minister for Transport and Works agrees with him. In a telex to the Minister for Transport on 21 March this year the Northern Territory Minister for Transport and Works said:

It is imperative that the construction of the Stuart Highway proceeds if the objectives of the ABRD program are to be met. As you know the primary objective is to upgrade the nation's road system to a high standard by, or soon after, 1988. Important factors in this aim are the meeting of the growing transportation needs of Australia: The enhancement of safety on our roads: The construction of developmental roads, including those of importance for national tourism.

I would very much appreciate your urgent consideration in expediting approval to these outstanding projects in order that these aims be achieved. Continuity of work and much needed job opportunities in the Territory will also result once these works get under way.

I agree wholeheartedly with the Territory Minister for Transport and Works, but the Minister for Transport and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have both been told by the Territory's Chief Minister that that upgrading is not necessary. The Chief Minister is two-faced. He is a saboteur. He struts around the Northern Territory using his expensive and extensive propaganda machine to put across the lie that he acts in the Territory's best interests at all times. Yet this two- faced saboteur comes down here to Canberra on his much publicised visits and tells the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport that this very vital Territory project is not necessary. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. The honourable member's speech is very wide-ranging. It may well be that you will not uphold this point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I would at least like to establish the guidelines for the conduct of this debate. —Mr Deputy Speaker, I understand why the honourable member is concerned about the statements I am making. It is because they are deadly accurate. SPEECH.PARA: I have travelled the road between Alice Springs and Darwin on many occasions. It is the Territory's main transport link. I hope that the whole exercise will be a salutary lesson to him that in the future he should think about the Territory before he shoots his mouth off.

Let me deal now with another aspect of Territory road funding. Some part of the Australian Government's funding for roads is passed on by State and Territory governments to local governments. In the Northern Territory the formula provides that only about 10 per cent of road funds go to local government. That formula was unilaterally adopted by the Northern Territory Government. When I was an alderman on the Alice Springs Town Council and a representative on the Northern Territory Local Government Association, the Territory local government bodies asked the Territory Government to explain how it calculated the formula. The Territory local government bodies believe that, since they cover over 70 per cent of the Territory's population, they should get more than 10 per cent of the road funding allocation. To my knowledge no satisfactory explanation has yet been given by the Territory Government as to how it calculated the 10 per cent formula. The formula certainly has not been changed.

This issue has been going on now for a number of years. The Territory local government representatives approached the Federal Minister for Transport last year and asked him to approach the Territory Government to do something about the matter. He did exactly that. He asked the Territory Government to expedite a review of the formula. I regret that I have to report that the Territory Government still has not sorted out the matter. If the people of the Territory see the standards of their council roads slipping, they should remember that it is the Territory Government's procrastination that is the source of the problem and not the excellent local governments in the Northern Territory.

I have mentioned tendering and State and Territory road funding. The third area covered by this Bill is public transport. The Bill allows State and Territory governments to direct spending towards urban public transport. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to speak on this legislation because of some important matters relevant to it that have arisen in my electorate. But, perforce of the speech that we have just heard, I feel that it is necessary to make some remarks about the address by the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Reeves). As I listened very carefully to him, I am sure that I could have been forgiven for believing that it was a political address par excellence. SPEECH.PARA: I think that what needs to be understood-I think it is understood in the Northern Territory and understood Australia-wide, in fact-is that the roads question in the Northern Territory is relevant only insofar as it is juxtaposed with the Government's intention to abandon the former Government's proposal to build a rail link between Alice Springs and Darwin. The Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, like honourable members on this side of the House, is intensely interested in the future of that rail link because of its importance to our national security and because of its importance to the Northern Territory . He has been told that he has no chance of getting his rail link so he is trying to put far greater weight on the road link to retrieve his position. But what needs to be understood is that the honourable member for the Northern Territory has failed. He has failed his electorate and the people of Australia because of his unwillingness to articulate properly in this place and to his own Government the needs of the Northern Territory.

I do not think that any honourable member could reasonably be expected to come into this House and to show his face when he has had such an absymal failure as the honourable member has suffered concerning his constituency. In fact, I must say that I felt somewhat sorry for him when these announcements were made by the Government because it seemed to me that he had been grossly let down by his colleagues. Obviously he was the sacrificial lamb who had to project some degree of economic responsibility. Heaven knows, one could not regard a deficit of $8 billion as responsible. The Northern Territory has only one seat, and we can forget about that. We can cut the traces so far as the honourable member for the Northern Territory is concerned. To come into this House and endeavour to defend that situation by attacking the real defender of the Northern Territory, the Chief Minister, the man who has been most articulate on that question, is, I think, a real failure on the honourable member's part.

I wish to discuss in some greater detail the two Bills with which we are dealing, the Roads Grants Amendment Bill 1984 and the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill 1984. The purpose of these Bills is to make changes to the arrangements for the States' level of real expenditure on roads and urban public transport and to vary the tender requirements in relation to each of the Acts. The tender requirements of the legislation put in place by the previous Government were quite important. They were designed to ensure that the money being spent on roads by the Commonwealth would achieve its purpose to the greatest extent possible, that is, that we get more miles of road built for every dollar spent. I think that is an important national purpose and one that ought to be lauded and very much admired. The former Government recognised that the States, by force of circumstances over many years, have built up their own work forces for carrying out road building. They have not always been the most efficient bodies for that purpose. I do not mean that in any unduly critical way . It is simply that they have built up a situation where in many cases they have a large number of employees who work in a day labour situation and not in a competitive environment in which they might well be able to deliver somewhat more for the public.

The former Government said: 'Look, we do not want to deprive State authorities of work that they might have been able to do or local government of work that it might have been able to undertake in the building of roads. We will give them an opportunity, with others, to be able to tender competitively for the building of national and arterial roads projects and other roads projects the Commonwealth is funding'. I do not think we could ask for anything more reasonable than that. It was a very laudable and proper purpose and one which I think would have achieved for this nation more roads of a better standard for the amount of money specially collected under the Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund arrangements.

The Minister's purpose is to change those arrangements and enable the calling of tenders to be dispensed with in a situation where a State approaches the Minister and satisfies him on a number of matters. One has only to consider the list of matters about which a State is required to satisfy the Minister to understand the purpose of the amendment. Its purpose is to ensure that the States and local government authorities in the road building business, notwithstanding that they are not competitive, that this will cost a lot more and that we will get less for our dollar, will be able to build roads with the money collected under this charge.

The specific circumstances of which a State can advise the Minister are these: Firstly, in an emergency, that the works must be performed urgently; secondly, that the works are of such a minor nature that calling tenders would involve undue additional cost; thirdly, that it is not practicable to prepare adequate tender specifications. I am not sure precisely what that means, except that it is sufficiently vague to give the Government an excuse in an appropriate case to do away with the tender requirements. The fourth situation is where the works are of a kind that competitive tenders would not be likely to be received. Again that makes a judgment. Surely one could call tenders to see whether any would be received. The State can advise, fifthly, that the works are of a kind usually carried out by a State or Federal government department, authority or corporation not primarily responsible for the construction of roads; and, sixthly, that the performance of work under the contract would cause unavoidable retrenchment or inefficiency in the deployment of a substantial number of State or local government road construction employees. That is the rub. That is the provision that is intended to ensure that this Government, in concert with State government authorities, is able to give work to those State government authorities to keep their day labour forces on the job, regardless of whether they are competitive, and whether others are available to undertake the task and build those roads at a far better price. I regard this amendment as one that is not worthy of support. For that reason my colleagues and I will oppose this provision.

The legislation is also important in two other respects, and I wish to address them jointly. First of all, in relation to access to the Australian Capital Territory it ought to be known that under the legislation the Minister for Transport is required to be consulted by the States about the distribution of funds and he has to give his approval. I am quite alarmed that in regard to the Australian Capital Territory the large amount of money being spent in duplicating the Federal Highway between the Canberra border and Wells Station Road will be spent for naught. This is largely because the balance of the road, the Federal Highway into Canberra, which is the major road thoroughfare, will not be duplicated in time to complement the Canberra development and ensure that the Federal Highway between the Hume Highway and Canberra is in a satisfactory form for Australia's bicentenary.

The bicentennial roads program was designed to ensure that for our bicentenary our national roads will not be a disgrace. Yet the road that will lead people to the most important memorial associated with that occasion, the new and permanent Parliament House, if in fact it is built, will be grossly inadequate. I felt so strongly about this matter that I spoke on it in the Parliament on 3 November. I outlined the reasons why the Minister ought to involve himself in ensuring that this matter is dealt with. On that occasion I read to the Parliament a question I intended to ask the Minister about this very matter. It asked:

(1) Is it a fact that (a) the duplication of the Federal Highway between Goulburn, New South Wales, and Canberra is unlikely to be completed in time for the bicentennial celebration in 1988, (b) planning by the National Capital Development Commission is advanced to ensure that duplication of the highway within the Australian Capital Territory to the New South Wales border has been included in the NCDC works program for 1983 and (c) notwithstanding grants by the bicentennial roads program, duplication of the highway between Canberra and Goulburn might not now be completed until 1990.

(2) If so, (a) are there any acceptable reasons for this delay, (b) is the delay likely to occur because the level of funding under the bicentennial roads program for New South Wales is insufficient to meet the 1988 target, (c) is the program for bicentennial road spending in New South Wales established by the New South Wales Government and (d) is there any action that the Commonwealth Government can take to ensure that the duplication of the highway is completed in time for the opening of the new Parliament House in 1988.
The Minister answered that question on 28 February. He did not pick up the specific points I made. He sought to obfuscate by his answer. He said:

The current position in regard to the duplication of the Federal Highway between Goulburn, New South Wales and Canberra is that I have advised the New South Wales Minister for Roads that construction to a four-lane standard is to be completed.
That is fine; I am glad it is to be completed. The Minister continued:
Whether it will be completed by 1988, the bicentennial year, is dependent on a number of factors, the most important of these being movements in construction costs-
they will undoubtedly rise because of this legislation, because of the tender requirements--
decisions as to future funding after the expiration of the current Roads Grants Act in 1985, the speedy resolution of possible environmental issues-
which he did not detail-
and finally planning, design and engineering capacity constraints.
again, which he did not detail-
Despite these uncertainties, the following major projects are expected to be completed or substantially under way . . .

He gave me details of those projects. Of course, they do not in any way complete to a dual carriageway standard the road between Canberra and Goulburn. As shadow Minister for the Australian Capital Territory, I regard that as extremely disappointing. I make that comment as one who is concerned about access to the Australian Capital Territory. I believe that a Minister in an Australian government has a responsibility to ensure that this road is a dual carriageway before the Australian bicentenary in 1988. I do not regard the Minister's answer as being in any way adequate. I think he has a responsibility to explain to this House why such a situation should arise.

The second matter I wish to address relating to the way in which the funds are dealt with concerns the Minister's approval of the transfer of certain roads funds in New South Wales to certain election programs of the New South Wales State Government. I was surprised, as many were, to read, in the context of the New South Wales State election, an announcement by Mr Cox, the Minister for Transport, that there had been approved a $40m package of improvements to Sydney 's bus and ferry services and that the improvements would be funded using money from the Australian bicentenary roads program. The arrangements were, of course, for 200 Mercedes Benz buses with electronic destination boards; a second hydrofoil for 240 passengers to operate between Manly and Circular Quay, worth about $10m; and four more ferries for inner-harbour services from Drummoyne, Gladesville, Rhodes, Ermington and Silverwater, at a cost of $8m.

Those changes mean that less funds will be available for road purposes. The funds were collected for road purposes and, while there was an entitlement to change the mix between urban public transport and urban arterial roads, it does mean a corresponding reduction in funding for roads in Sydney. It means, for instance, that the linking of two parts of the important freeway project in the western suburbs-that between, say, the F4 and the works that have been developed to this point between, say, Auburn and Strathfield-is delayed. There are $40m less in funds available to carry out that work. It cannot be carried out at the same pace at which it might have been carried out if those funds were available. That is a consequence of the sort of change that has been made.

The Minister, in the context of the election, did not want to talk about that; but the change had been made. The shadow Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher), said that this was a stunt, and he was right. I have raised the matter of ferries since 1975, both in this Parliament and locally. Notwithstanding that fact, Labor governments in New South Wales have ignored the need for ferries on the Parramatta River. I took Mr Jones, a former Minister for Transport, on the hydrofoil operated by Mr Halvorsen. But because of the difficulties Mr Halvorsen had in terms of funding an additional hydrofoil or two, to ensure that he was able to operate an adequate service between Meadowbank in my electorate and the city, his service had to stop. His was a very important initiative. We knew at the time that other vessels could be developed. A Tasmanian firm developed a vessel called the Jeremiah Ryan, a twin- hulled vessel that could have been used on the Parramatta River.

But the fact of the matter is that the Government was not interested in that design. Eventually, it came up with its own duplicate design and said: 'We will get the boat builders in Newcastle to build those'. Of course, the effect of that was to delay further the plans that might have brought ferries to the Parramatta River, and the consequence has been that we have no service to this point in time. The fact is that the ferries are an important initiative, but it is very late. While it is important that the Government should get this program under way as quickly as possible, it would have been far more beneficial if the New South Wales Government had picked up this initiative and used some of its own funds to meet that need in the western suburbs of Sydney which I have been articulating since 1975.

SPEECH.PARA: I am particularly pleased to have this opportunity to speak to the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill and the Roads Grants Amendment Bill as the construction, upgrading and maintenance of Australia's roads have been of vital interest to me for many years. It also gives me considerable satisfaction to support the amending legislation because of the major improvements that it makes to the Australian bicentennial road development program. The major problems associated with the administration of the ABRD program which currently obtain derive from the obsession of the previous Government to downgrade the role of experienced government instrumentalities. Discussions with personnel of municipalities and the State Government road authority in my electorate of Ballarat have shown that the ABRD program was limited in its capacity to provide a service because of the unnecessary restrictions placed upon the commonsense involvement of the State authorities.

As has been stated, the record of the previous Government with respect to concern for the nation's roads was lamentable. We know that so little was its concern for the nation's roads that between the financial years of 1975-76 and 1981-82 there was a reduction in real terms of 23 per cent in the amount of Federal assistance given to the States. This statistic is irrefutable. This reduction took place despite, firstly, the growth in road transport and other road traffic during that time; secondly, the increase in the place of tourism as a significant economic factor in the life of many parts of Australia-in particular, that of north Queensland; and, thirdly, the aging of many of the nation's roads, with a consequent increase in the need for extensive maintenance and reconstruction programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you talking about north Queensland?

—I am talking about not only north Queensland but many other parts of the country as well. That is simply a fact of life. When in 1982 the then Fraser Government introduced the ABRD program the Australian Labor Party had to indicate how late was the development of its concern for the nation's road network.

SPEECH.PARA: It was no coincidence, I suggest, that the ABRD program was introduced in that Budget, which the then Prime Minister believed-erroneously, thank goodness-would ensure his re-election. Like so much of that Budget, the ABRD program would always have been seen as an election gimmick, and I suppose the people of Australia had just cause for recalling the fate of the 1977 Budget commitments which were clawed back so ferociously in 1978. Fortunately, with the defeat of the Fraser Government in 1983, the same fate was averted for the ABRD program.

When we announced our transport policy prior to the 1983 campaign we promised, among other items, to continue the ABRD program. I must congratulate the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) for his tenacious and determined efforts and his pursuit of the success of this policy. It is certainly to his credit that in 1983-84 the total allocation of Commonwealth funds for road works will be $1,233m, as was indicated by my esteemed colleague, the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Reeves), and which represents an increase of 45 per cent over the sum expended in 1982-83. The ABRD program was allocated $385m in 1983-84, which more than trebled the amount allocated in 1982-83.

The Government places great importance upon the purposes of the ABRD program and is committed to continuing it. It has been said before that the purposes of the program include the following, and I think they are worthwhile restating and I hope naturally that they will have the concurrence of both sides of the House: Savings in travelling time; savings in vehicle maintenance and running costs, including fuel consumption; a reduction in road accidents and their associated economic and social cost; the removal of dust hazards; a reduction in road closures, stoppages and delays due to flooding; less driver strain and fatigue; and increased employment from the extra construction activity, which is certainly tremendously important. It is probably fairly easy to gloss over these , but I am sure that everyone who thinks about the significance of these goals will agree that they are enormously important.

I indicated when the original legislation was adopted that we wanted some enlightened components added to it, but the narrow and reactionary disposition of the Fraser Government would not allow that. The amendments proposed in these pieces of legislation free up the funding arrangements in a particularly rational way. It makes common sense to enable the States and the Northern Territory to be more flexible in their planning for expenditure without actually losing moneys available under the scheme. I remind the House of the provisions of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill 1984. Firstly, the Bill requires States to maintain expenditure in real terms at a level set under agreement. The amended legislation will permit States to spend more than required under the Act, with excess expenditure being able to be treated as expenditure by the State in a subsequent year. This flexibility is sensible and should allow for planning in a way that suits the States' available resources and priorities. However, the onus, of course, is now placed upon the States to ensure that relevant expenditure will not include money provided by the Commonwealth through the community employment projects. This is also, I contend, a very reasonable provision.

I am particularly pleased to see a relaxation in regard to section 4(3) of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act 1982 to enable States to direct part of their ABRD allocations for urban arterial roads to urban public transport capital projects. I think it is extremely important that they be able to do so, given the compensating effects. They will be able to do so without necessarily receiving a penalty, so long as the Minister is satisfied that this will result in a reduction of the traffic on or the wear and tear affecting urban arterial roads in the States, and is a project which the States consider should be given priority. I believe this will mean that the State is not disadvantaged by reasonable use of these funds.

I also wish to comment on the major amendment in the Roads Grants Amendment Bill 1984 which will, I hope, remove from the State road construction authority a cause of considerable frustration and inefficiency. It is included in both these Bills. I refer to the requirement under the Roads Grants Act and the ABRD Trust Fund Act 1982 for States to call tenders for all construction works associated with national road projects approved for funding under the Act and, with respect to the ABRD Trust Fund Act, for national rural and urban arterial road projects. The new procedures will free up considerably the process of tendering which, under the previous Government, had been dogmatically inflexible . In its own way it reflected, as I said before, the blinkered ideological stance of that Government that so stifled co-operative development in this country. It was obviously a procedure meant to frustrate government authorities and in fact simply worked against the interests of a vast number of Australian people.

Our proposed procedure is a considerable advance on the existing legislation because it allows for circumstances which States have recognised for years and which cannot be met adequately under inflexible rules. The provisions now cover circumstances, as the amendments state, where the work to be done is urgent, where the work to be done is of such a minor nature as to involve undue additional cost should tenders be required, where it is not practicable to prepare adequate tender specifications, where it is just not likely that competitive tenders will be received, where it is usual for the responsible government department or authority to do the work for the public utilities, and where the requirement to accept a private contract would result in retrenchment of State or local government employees. I know that that is of little consequence to honourable members opposite and certainly would be of little consequence to the first speaker on this Bill today, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher), as everyone would know. They will also cover the circumstance where it would be quite inefficient to employ day labour employees of the State or local government road construction bodies.

We are committed to ensuring the maximum efficiencies and cost-effectiveness of the ABRD program and all road construction programs. These amendments retain the best elements of the tendering principle but build in commonsense possibilities through flexibility. Fortunately the Minister has developed these amendments through a process of consultation with the States, local government, industry and the unions, which again, might I say, is something which the Opposition, if in government-God forbid-just could not do. I know that these amendments will be welcomed by the road construction authority and the local government bodies in my electorate of Ballarat.

TALK.START.PARA: —In mine too.

—I am sure of that. It is a very worthy electorate with a very worthy member. I must say that during the past year, in all aspects of road funding, my electorate of Ballarat has received considerable benefit from the Government's decisions, as has Victoria generally. In western Victoria alone 88 new projects in new urban and rural arterial roads and local roads have been allocated funds. In Ballarat $2m under the ABRD program has been allocated to highway duplication in Victoria Street, Ballarat, and in the east national road construction program . The municipalities of Buninyong and Ballarat City have received funding for urban and arterial roads improvement, also under the ABRD. Local road schemes under the ABRD program have attracted grants in the municipalities-I mention these because of the wide-ranging scope of the program-of Avoca, Ballarat City, Ballan, Ballarat Shire, Bungaree, Buninyong, Creswick, Daylesford/Glenlyon, Grenville, Kyneton, Lexton, Maryborough, Sebastopol, Talbot and Clunes, and Tullaroop.

SPEECH.PARA: In all, the ABRD commitment to local roads schemes now totals $2,219,000. Apart from the jobs on local roads project, which has also created worthwhile employment, the ABRD program as announced will provide directly-and this is something that is forgotten by honourable members opposite who do not come from rural electorates-the opportunity for a considerable number of jobs in the communities I have mentioned. It injects much needed income into the economies of many country towns. Whilst I do not expect that the amendments will have a dramatic effect upon the administration of the ABRD program, they will enable more common-sense relationships to develop between each of the concerned authorities, and to that extent the program should proceed more smoothly. I congratulate the Minister on his diligence and on his success in discussions with the interested parties. I commend these Bills to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: I now deal with aspects of the amending Bill. The first aspect concerns contracts. I appreciate the value of the tendering system when I recall the system in vogue prior to this legislation being passed and these conditions being applied. As a public accountant in the years before I became a parliamentarian, I saw first class road contractors, people of high quality, very efficient people, being pushed out of the contracting work because the main roads boards were gradually taking them over, to the extent that only a pitiful amount was allocated to the tender system. I believe that such people have proved their efficiency, so when this was made a condition I was not unhappy at all. Perhaps I was unhappy about the 100 per cent qualification that everything had to go to tender; but basically it has proved its worth.

One Government supporter challenged us to say where the improvements have been. The annual report on the ABRD program indicates that it has been successful in getting more roads at a lower cost. But in a State where the development has decreased quite considerably and contractors are moving in from the mining areas , there are tremendous tenders from very reputable companies being placed on road contracts in that State. That is so to the extent that I heard one figure from my own Main Roads Department suggest that prices were coming in 40 per cent lower than the estimated price put on jobs by the Main Roads Department. So what we are getting is cheaper roads but roads of a higher quality, and we are getting more of those roads of a standard that will take the traffic. So there is no argument there but that the tender system has been good. It has also exercised control and power over the State road authorities which were reliant on day labour. There have been great successes. That is the evidence that I am able to adduce in that regard.

No main roads authority in any State should be the planner, the programmer, the constructor and the supervisor. That is the worst of all worlds. If we want to get in this nation the roads that we require-and it is difficult enough to get priority for funds in that regard-no State authority can take all of those positions and expect to get efficient road spending as a result. What we have had under this program is fewer delays and more roads. However, as I have said, the 100 per cent clause gave it a rigidity which was not approved at that stage either by State authorities-I have no real comment in that connection-or by local government authorities. Some freeing of that system-I say 'some', not a total freeing-will be welcomed by local government, for the reasons that it gave at the time.

As to clause 5(2) of the Bill and the conditions under which the Minister now has to be satisfied in order to exempt works, this is a discretion that was not in the original legislation. Can one imagine the problems that the Minister will bring on to his shoulders just through the fact that there is now to be a discretion? Everyone will be asking for an exemption. In view of the nature of the conditions that are to apply, one might say that one could drive the proverbial bus through some of them.

I agree with several of the conditions. I agree with paragraph (b)-that the works are of such a minor nature that the invitation of tenders for those works would involve undue additional cost. I agree with, perhaps, paragraph (c)-that they are of a kind for which it is not practicable to prepare adequate tender specifications. But that is not spelt out. That could leave itself wide open to interpretation. The next one is paragraph (d)-that they are of a kind for which competitive tenders are unlikely to be received. Who, in that case, makes the assessment that they are unlikely to be received? But in all the other things for which the exemption might be sought, such as the works being urgently required by reason of an emergency, who determines the urgency and who determines the emergency?

As far as I am concerned, road construction throughout Australia is an emergency situation. We are so far behind, not by the will of any government but because of the lack of programming and funding, that there is an emergency. Does this mean that every part of these works will involve an emergency? Then we come to paragraph (f). I think this has to be very carefully looked at. The condition is:

. . . would need to be carried out by employees of a State or a government authority responsible for the construction of roads in order to avoid the occurrence of a loss of employment by or the inefficient deployment of, a substantial number of those employees, even if the State or authority were to take all practical steps to avoid that occurrence.

Let us think in terms of what this would mean in a system in which we use a private contractor who has a reputation for building good roads at a reasonable price. The decision has to be made as to whether the day labour force-not in place at the moment; the States have lived with this situation for a couple of years now-should come on. It could be an encouragement. Somebody suggested that there was a criticism of the day labour force. There is no criticism of the day labour force, but when we have honest competition, as the tender system now provides, and when the system provides for the State or a local government to contract, we have the best of all worlds. I see these amendments, while freeing up the system, as being sufficiently wide to enable the proverbial cart to be driven through them.

The second set of amendments would give some authority to the States to carry forward excess expenditure in one particular year, as I understand it, to expenditure in the year to come. I am sure the point should be made here that State roads are State authority roads. It is the States that should be responsible for the funding. To suggest in this Bill that they should not be allowed to take up their section of the responsibility is a mischief. The argument for States withdrawing their road funds is provided by the Commonwealth not only in respect of State roads but also for local government roads, is well known, but I do not think we should encourage it. In fact, we should be disciplining the States to the extent that they accept that they should be providing the funding for main State roads and that if we do anything at a national level it is only on a topping up basis.

Mention has been made of the 2 per cent levy. In fact, it will be embodied in an amendment to be moved later by the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher). As I understand it when this was first mooted-the idea was germinated at St Lawrence-the Australian Council of Local Government Associations, represented by Councillor Maddern, said:

. . . the fuel surcharge must be spent on roads and the funds generated by it must be in addition to a road funding commitment by each of the three spheres of government which at least keeps pace with road price inflation.

When that 2c was allocated to the trust that money was allocated to road construction. While we do not agree with the indexing of that levy, I believe that, morally, the index itself ought to be applied to those road funds. Within the last three weeks I was at a conference where an engineer who was well known for his interest in local government and road funding said he thought that the people of Australia would not mind an additional price on their fuel if the money was to be allocated to road construction. When I told him that in fact that levy was being charged but not being appropriated to road funds it came as a bit of a surprise to him. It was incomprehensible to him that, despite the increased price of fuel, the money collected was not going to road funding. In reply to a question in this House a few weeks ago, the Minister indicated a lack of acknowledgement that the funds obtained from the levy should go to that source. I believe that was an indication that his conscience might have been getting the best of him through the representations that had been made. They have been made to me from many sources in the last few weeks. I would have thought that his conscience would perhaps have directed him not to answer the question in the way that he did, because the answer did not mean anything. He could have applied himself positively in this legislation to bring about that further amendment. I believe it was an ideal opportunity to amend the legislation to provide for contracts and other situations and that he should have concerned himself also with the amendment that the Opposition will be introducing to make sure that that situation is not overlooked. I hope the Government is prepared to accept that amendment.

There is a problem with local government, as I have said. Local governments believe that through the indexation of the bicentennial road fund they will be missing out on their 12 per cent of the total amount that will be appropriated to Consolidated Revenue. That figure, $491m, was mentioned by the honourable member for Hume. Local government's share of that sum is $59m over the next five -year period. It is an area in which money is vitally important. I believe local government right throughout Australia is concerned basically with road funding. That is its major problem. Local governments' open grants go to that end. They also desire more funds. It is incomprehensible that they should feel that they will miss out on $50m in a five-year period in an area where it is drastically required. This Government and State governments are putting additional burdens on local government not only in fuel levies and excise but also in payroll tax, the bank transactions tax, workers compensation, and the non-rateability of properties. All this is getting out of perspective. Local government is not getting back sufficient money to do the work it is required to do in relation to the money that it pays to the other spheres of government. It is just not good enough.

All I can say is that the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund has been designed to cater for a real need in this society, to improve the major links between areas of Australia. I approve of the manner in which the Government has endorsed the program but I cannot really give my approval to giving a discretion to the Minister under the conditions mentioned. I believe that the Bill should be amended so that we can get that indexed amount through to the road construction authorities.

I have just one final comment to make. It comes back to Canberra roads. We heard from the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) about the access roads to Canberra. I suggest that the access road to the airport be immediately looked at to make sure that it is completed by the bicentenary celebrations. Work on the road has been going on for 18 months. It is an absolute disgrace and I believe that the money is being wasted. I hate to think that if I am a member of this place in 1988 I will still have to deviate over two bridges and avoid the road works, potholes and everything else to make the trip to the airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do the tourists think about it?

—Of course, it would be a great asset to Canberra if the tourists could make the trip speedily but at the moment they are just wondering how many times they have to cross that river to get to the airport. I suggest that the Minister look very closely at that situation also.
