The Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill provides for changes in three aspects of the arrangements under which financial assistance is made available to the States and the Northern Territory under the Australian bicentennial road development program. Firstly, the Bill provides that where a State's expenditure on roads in any year exceeds the amount necessary to meet the requirement under the Act spending be maintained in real terms. The excess expenditure may be treated as expenditure by the State in a subsequent year. The Bill also removes the requirement that where a State directs assistance received under the Act to an urban public transport project it must maintain in real terms its own capital expenditure on urban public transport. I feel that this is very important. The Bill introduces some flexibility into the requirement that tenders must be called by the States for all works associated with national and arterial road projects. The Bill allows the Minister to agree, upon request by a State, to an exemption from the requirement to call tenders for particular works where the Minister is satisfied that specific circumstances apply. This amendment is to be backdated to 12 February 1984, the date on which the revised arrangements were announced.

When the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act was introduced by our predecessors the Labor Party supported the objectives of the program. Because our predecessors could not or would not provide adequate funding for roads, the need for such an initiative was obvious. However, we were concerned about some of the provisions of the legislation, which appeared to be too extreme in their application. We indicated that upon coming to government we would review a number of provisions in the ABRD Trust Fund Act, especially those related to the calling of tenders. In giving this undertaking the Labor Party was concerned to have provisions that were reasonable to all parties. Consistent with our approach of conciliation and consultation, detailed discussions were held with the States, local government, industry and relevant unions. This process identified three areas where changes to the provisions of the legislation were necessary. The amendments to the ABRD Trust Fund Act therefore make the changes which this Government considers are desirable in order to improve the operation of the ABRD program. The Bill varies the requirement that tenders must be called by a State for all works associated with national and arterial road projects. Under the legislation developed by our predecessors, this was an absolute requirement with no provision whatsoever for it to be waived.

After careful consideration and discussion this Government is satisfied that the general principle of calling tenders for road construction is appropriate if Australia is to obtain full value for its investment in our road infrastructure. However, we recognise that there is a need for some flexibility to cover situations where the process of calling tenders is either impractical or not cost effective. The Bill therefore allows the Minister to approve an exemption from the requirement to call tenders for specific works where a State can demonstrate to his satisfaction that there is an emergency requirement for the works to be performed; the works are of such a minor nature that calling tenders would involve undue additional costs, and I think the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Reeves) mentioned that; it is not practical to prepare adequate tender specifications for the works; the works are of such a kind that competitive tenders are unlikely to be received; the works involve adjustments to utility services which would normally be undertaken by a government department, a government authority or a corporation not primarily responsible for the construction of roads; or the performance of work under contract would cause unavoidable retrenchment or inefficiency in the deployment of a substantial number or State of local government road construction employees.

It has been emphasised that each of these provisions for exemption has been carefully considered. They have been included as there are obvious circumstances where time or cost make the tendering process inappropriate. It is the Government's intention that the ministerial discretion will be used very infrequently and then only after the most rigorous and detailed examination of the factors involved. There can be no argument that the Hawke Labor Government has a thoroughly thought out transport policy. Since we have been the Government we have been implementing that policy. As I said at the outset, I believe that more has been done in the transport field in the last 12 months-the first 12 months of the Hawke Labor Government-than in the whole of the preceding seven years. I invite honourable members to look today at the amount of work going on. I often drive to Canberra from my electorate and along the way, and indeed wherever I drive in the State, I see examples of years of neglect being corrected by the Hawke Labor Government. I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian bicentennial road development program has a degree of bipartisan support in this House. It is proving to be a most successful program. I notice that the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) disagreed with it violently back in 1982. As I understand it, he now supports the program. I think most Australians support it. Although they do not agree with having to pay an extra 2 per cent tax levy, I think if that money can be seen to be going directly into a project which benefits them as motorists, although they might not be happy, they are prepared to put up with it.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to cover briefly a few points on the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill, which seeks to change the system of compulsory tendering for national and arterial roads. The changes brought forward by the Government really highlight the difference between the philosophies of the Government and the philosophies of this side of the House. In bringing in these changes the Government is looking around to see what it can do. I hope that the philosophy on our side, which is very much ingrained in most of us, is: What can free enterprise do? As the Government is looking for statutory authorities, main roads departments and State governments to do more, quite rightly, we are defending the principle of free enterprise. We are saying: 'Let us leave it to free enterprise if we possibly can'. That is the difference between the two.

The present tendering system does favour free enterprise. It is all very well for honourable members to get up and say: 'What about the people in country towns?'. Everyone is conscious of the people who work for local authorities, but what about the people who work for local contracting firms, big and small, who are finding, and have found in the last few years, it most difficult to keep on the black side of the ledger? What about them? We are not saying 'Sack all the people from the councils'; what we are saying is 'For goodness sake, let the councils look after the local roads to a large extent and let free enterprise and the tendering system look after the national and arterial roads. If the councils feel these firms are efficient they also should be quite welcome to tender, as they are entitled to do under the system'.

The conditions for exemption laid down in this Bill are: In an emergency, when works are of a minor nature, when it is not practical to prepare adequate tender specifications, when competitive tenders are unlikely to be received, when works would cause disruption to existing government authorities and when works would cause unemployment in State or local government road construction areas. It seems to me-I note some other speakers have picked up the theme as well-that in general there are so many exemptions that State governments and local authorities will have no difficulty in convincing the Minister that they have good reason, under one of those exemptions, not to go through the tendering process. In effect, it would appear that compulsory tendering has gone. There are so many exemption clauses that, as the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) said, trucks will be able to be driven through it.

I have no doubt that local authorities will welcome the changes but, as I said before: What about the people who are working for private enterprise in these areas? The fact is that under this system we probably will have fewer roads which will cost more. As the honourable member for Dawson said-he quoted some figures-some of the tenders from private enterprise for roads and road works were 40 per cent down on tenders received for similar works from various departments of main roads. I note that the Minister in his second reading speech says that his discretion will be used infrequently. I hope that that will be so. I wait with interest to see how it turns out. If his discretion is used infrequently I will congratulate him and the Government. The trouble is that the changes to the Act seem to be far too wide-ranging to offer any comfort.

I want to say a few words about the failure of the Government to index the proportion of the levy on petrol that goes to the road program-at present it is 2c a litre. We have to ask the question: Why has the Government chosen not to index the 2c levy so that the money goes where it should be going? Of course, it should be going to the road program. The answer the Minister gave to a question from his own side in this House on 29 February can only be described as weak. He tried to blame it on the previous Government. He stated:
. . . it was the intention of the previous Government that the legislation cover the period from 1982 to 1988 . . . It knew there would be increases in excises . . .

That is no excuse. The present Government has introduced indexation for petrol excise. Why should it not choose to index also that 2c a litre which goes to the road program? The reason is that it wants the money to fund more and bigger social programs and to reduce the deficit. These are not unworthy aims, but the trouble is there is only a limited amount of money to go around and priorities have to be set. We have to get the balance and the priorities right. Is Australia's road development to suffer as it has for years because the Government wants to fund bigger and better welfare programs and a socialist commitment to welfare spending?

We all know we have a huge country and a massive road bill. Here is a program in which we have a chance to make an inroad into the backlog of road development work in this country. It is inexplicable to me and to most people why the 2c a litre is not indexed and the money put into the road program. It is not a matter of we cannot do it. Here is a golden opportunity to do it right now, when we have this amendment to the legislation. It is not a matter of we cannot do it, it is a matter of we will not do it. Local governments are very concerned about the amount of money they are missing out on, some $58.9m over the life of this program-a massive amount of money for local government alone. Of course, that represents only 12 per cent of the total estimated loss to the road program of some $491m. In August 1982 the present Minister was adamantly opposed to this levy. He said it would do nothing for arterial and local roads. One can only conclude that he is doing his best to make sure that the effect is minimised.

The next point I mention is the readjustment of the funds which allows State governments to use them more widely and freely in urban public transport. I commend the Government and the Minister because this seems to me a very sensible approach. I will give an example of why it seems to be a step in the right direction. In my area of the Gold Coast an electric railway line project from Brisbane to Beenleigh has been brought forward because funds have been allowed to be used on it. I am hoping now that because this funding system has been further eased the project to extend the railway from Beenleigh to the Gold Coast will be brought forward. I believe the project is most important to that area. It is servicing not only the increasing population of the Gold Coast but also the important corridor between Beenleigh and the Gold Coast, which is a fast- developing residential and tourist area.

My last point is a very controversial and contentious one: It is the failure of the New South Wales Government to start on what is commonly known as the Tweed Heads bypass. I ask the Minister-I seek a response later in this debate-whether he can tell us why work on this bypass has not commenced. We can go back for some years to the promises made by New South Wales Ministers. In the New South Wales Hansard of 15 March Mr Rex Jackson, who seems to have departed, stated:
I have every reason to believe that the promise given by the former federal Minister for Roads will be honoured by the new Minister.

That was shortly after the change of government. The New South Wales Government had applied for this project to be considered under the Australian bicentennial road development program and it was given permission. We then had the Federal election and a change of government. All the indications were that the Federal Government would support the program. More than 12 months later there is still no sign of a start. I ask the Minister for Transport to tell us why this project has not started. I presume it is because the New South Wales Government is steadfastly still refusing to ask the Federal Government for matching money for this project.

Honourable members might ask why this matter is important to me when it is not even in my electorate. It is important to that whole area-northern New South Wales, the Tweed Heads area and the Gold Coast and for me and my electorate of McPherson in particular. As much as 18 months ago, in December 1982 and January 1983, some 34,000 vehicles a day were plodding their way across the single lane bridge over the Tweed River. That is why this matter is important. When something like 85 per cent of our tourists come by road, and probably half of those come from the south, honourable members will see why the tourist development in northern New South Wales and the Gold Coast is something about which I express concern tonight.

I saw in a recent Press release that the Minister has granted another $600,000 to New South Wales under the ABRD program. That makes a total allocation of $67m for local roads alone in New South Wales with an allocation for 1983-84 of some $90m. It is impossible for any sensible person to believe that the Tweed by-pass does not get some priority for access to those funds. I have to ask: What is going on? The only conclusion I can come to is that that area of New South Wales is being discriminated against by the New South Wales Government simply because it does not hold that seat. I, like other speakers in this House, oppose this Bill mainly because the exemptions on tendering are too wide and the road levy should be indexed. I fully support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher).

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I think it is appropriate that we look at the objectives as set out in the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act 1982 as they are pertinent to the debate this evening . Section 3 of the Act states:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) in accordance with national priorities, upgrade the road network in Australia to facilitate the reliable and efficient carriage of road traffic;
(b) to enhance the safety of Australian roads;
(c) bring the national highway system that links the main centres of population to a standard that will meet the growing transport needs of Australia;
(d) accelerate the construction of development roads, including roads of importance for national tourism;
(e) assist the development of urban and rural arterial roads; and
(f) enable appropriate authorities to upgrade local road systems.

I do not think there would be any dispute from honourable members opposite that those are fine ideals. It is unfortunate that those ideals are not practised by the Queensland Government. This evening I would like to spend some time dealing with the misappropriation and the deceit of the Queensland Government in the distribution of road funding in Queensland. I raise this issue, which is of serious concern for people living in the more remote areas of Queensland, particularly far north Queensland, during the debate on the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Bill and the Roads Grants Bill because of the importance of the funding, maintenance and development of our road system in the remote areas of Queensland. Whilst I do not wish to open the debate on the necessity for a public accounts committee for the State of Queensland, it is clear that the Queensland Government, through its Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Racing, Mr Hinze, has indulged in misappropriation and that people in the more remote areas of the State are disadvantaged.

This evening I would like to alert honourable members in this House to what has become over the years an almost total and appalling misuse of Commonwealth funds by the Queensland Government. I raise this issue as it is one of serious concern for people living in my part of Queensland. In so doing I wish to advert to certain areas where the Queensland Minister has quite clearly and categorically misrepresented the facts of the funding of Queensland roads, particularly in the more remote areas. I appreciate that a charge such as this is very serious. However, the evidence clearly indicates that not only the Minister concerned but also the Minister for Environment, Valuation and Administration Services, Mr Tenni, have deceived the people of far north Queensland.

In the 1982-83 Budget special funding was allocated for north Queensland roads and transportation. At page 66 of Budget Paper No.7 it was made patently clear that $20m had been allocated for the upgrading and maintenance of north Queensland roads-I emphasise the words 'north Queensland'-and the transportation system. It is clear on the evidence that not one red cent of that money has been spent in north Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is just another example of their vandalism.

—It is misappropriation, deceit and vandalism. It is a most unfortunate fact. Yet when I approached Mr Hinze back in October 1983 and asked where the money had been spent he quite unequivocally stated that it had been spent in north Queensland. I would like to quote from an article in the 28 October 1983 edition of the Cairns Post which is headed 'Twenty million spent in north-Hinze'. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Main Roads Minister Mr Hinze said in a statement yesterday a $20m 1982 Federal Budget allocation for north Queensland roads and transportation had been spent totally on these projects. Mr Hinze said: 'If local Federal Labor MLA, Mr Gayler , had done his homework he would have discovered that the Federal Budget term ' transport systems' had not simply included roads'.
He goes on:

'He should have been able to discover that, of the $20m, $10m was for northern roads and $10m was for other transport projects such as railway and bus development in north Queensland. I emphatically deny the suggestion that the money has been spent anywhere else'.

That was a clear, unequivocal statement that I had made representations that were untrue. I ask honourable members to note that in fact what he said was that $20m had been spent in the north. I quote from the Queensland Hansard of yesterday when a question put to Mr Hinze was answered in this way:

I am advised that the statements in the Commonwealth Budget documents referred to by the honourable member are inconsisent with the purpose of the special funds as officially advised by the then Federal Treasurer-namely, 'the upgrading of Queensland's transportation system'.
I quote further with the most damning piece of evidence that Mr Hinze has to face. Mr Hinze said:

The funds were accordingly distributed by the State Treasurer in the amounts of $10m each to the Main Roads Department and the Railway Department as special allocations to the capital programs of those departments for application in accordance with needs as determined by them.
What in fact happened was that the money was intercepted in Brisbane and spent in the south-east corner of Queensland to the detriment of the people living in far north Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not on racetracks.
