SPEECH.PARA: The list of indictments of this Minister in north Queensland is endless. In 1976 Mr Thomson, my predecessor-it was not often that he had much to say in this place, but on this occasion he stumbled across something-asked Mr Nixon, the Minister for Transport, what happened to the $24m-only another $24m-allocated to Queensland for the beef roads system, as it was called in Queensland. An amount of $24m was allocated but north Queensland, which, of course, is the capital of the cattle industry in Queensland, got nothing. That $24m was another amount misappropriated by the Minister. In fact, Mr Nixon washed his hands of the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —No beef roads money at all?

—There was no beef road money at all. The money went down to the brigalow country. I do not need to remind honourable members who live in the brigalow country of that. Mr Nixon was not going to have any part of this. In his reply he said:

SPEECH.PARA: At the commencement of the 1974-77 program $24m was made available for the beef roads program. As I understand it, at that time consultation between the Queensland authorities-
I imagine Mr Hinze was privy to that-
and the then Department of Northern Development decided which roads would be included in that program.
He continued:
I understand the honourable member's concern in this matter-
why would he not be concerned as only another $24m has been misappropriated?-

because it appears that certain sections of road in the Gulf Country were included in previous programs and then, all of a sudden, excluded from the 1974- 77 program, leading to the situation which he has described. The reason given for the exclusion of the roads in the Gulf Country was that the Queensland authorities and the Department of Northern Development apparently decided that resources could be better spent in the brigalow country.

In those two examples we have $44m gone from the north of Queensland. In a recent incident when ABRD funding of $400,000 was given to a local authority in north Queensland a previous grant from the Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Racing and the Queensland Government was then withdrawn. This is a matter I have brought to the notice of my Minister. These incidents cannot be allowed to continue. These instances of misappropriation and deceit of the people of north Queensland cannot be allowed to continue.

In conclusion, I refer to another issue which involves road funding. It is a matter I have taken up over a long period with the Federal Minister. I place on record that he has paid particular attention to this problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a pork barreller, is he?

—It concerns pork barrelling. Just before the last State election in Queensland, Mr Hinze came to north Queensland and decided to pork barrel the Mulgrave State electorate. Honourable members will all be aware of the honourable member for Mulgrave, Mr Menzel. He is one of the leading lights of the National Party in Queensland and an embarrassment to his party, to Queensland and Australia. Anyway this time an $llm pork barrel was involved. The pork barrel was in regard to a road bypass. I use the word 'bypass' although the road is to go right through the middle of a township. It will not bypass anything. All it will do is result in the bulldozing of 26 houses if it goes ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: Some five years ago Mr Hinze was reported- once again in the Cairns Post-as saying after having had discussions with the people of Babinda that the bypass would not go through what was then known as the western route. He said that it was not possible for the road to go there and that certainly would not be done by the Queensland Government. That was in 1978. In 1983, just before the State election, Mr Hinze said: 'We are going the western route now'. That means a cost of $llm. I have challenged Mr Hinze as to whether he would be using State funding or whether he would require ABRD funding.

TALK.START.PARA: —He would be terrified of you.

—Yes. I can look after Mr Hinze. All I say is that 650 people of the township of Babinda signed a petition opposing the bypass. The reason for the change in the routing of the bypass was that a handful of cane farmers got the ear of Mr Hinze and told him it would affect their cane paddocks. Mr Hinze, in his wisdom and to accommodate the cane farmers, intends now to bulldoze 26 houses of the people of the township of Babinda. Mr Hinze said unequivocally five years ago he would not do that and he has turned around now and said that the matter will proceed. I have had the utmost assistance from my Federal Minister in this regard.
—Have you got a cheque yet?

—No, I have not. I can assure taxpayers that, having proscrastinated for five years on this matter, an extra $5m will be added to the cost of that bypass. The honourable member need not worry about any cheques. Such a decision is an utter disregard for the people of north Queensland. It represents the misappropriation of funds, deceit and lies on the part of senior Ministers in the Queensland Government to the detriment of the people of north Queensland. I can assure all honourable members and those Ministers that that deceit and that misappropriation will be remembered whenever the people go to the polls again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: — Honourable members opposite think in regard to roads that the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) is a good Minister. He may be in an administrative sense but he has been rolled by Treasury. A 2c a litre charge is levied. It was a concept of its introduction by the previous Government that there should be a discrete collection of excise payable directly to road funds in Australia. It was an innovation. It was a brilliant scheme and one widely accepted by all Australians as a process that would upgrade, to the highest possible standards, our national highways by the year of the bicentenary . Hence the program took on the title of the Australian bicentennial roads development program. It is an excellent program and one that has already started to bear fruit.

SPEECH.PARA: However, in the last Budget, the Government in its wisdom, decided to index the factor that was used as the base to collect funds for the bicentennial roads program. The factor that was indexed was the excise on petrol. The indexation takes place in a way which increases the excise charge to consumers by the amount of the increase in the cost of living. That increase takes place on a six -monthly basis. Included in that charge, of course, by the process of indexation , is the 2c which has been allocated to the development of road programs throughout Australia. So, of the total excise collected, there is 2c in it somewhere which belongs to the bicentennial roads program. That 2c allocation will not increase. In fact, it is not indexed, as is the excise duty. What is happening is that the road users of Australia are paying more for their petrol and a smaller proportion of their total contribution to Commonwealth funds through excise is being allocated to roads. There is a falling off of the amount which should be allocated to road programs.

The motorist is not contributing the same proportion to the program as he was 12 months ago. Twelve months ago, upon the election of the Hawke Government, commitments were made to programs. One of those commitments was that the road programs would continue. If one reads the material carefully, one finds that there is no commitment that additional funds gained for the bicentennial road program will be passed across to the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund and held within it. What has been done is that the Treasurer has done over the Department of Transport and its Minister. He has said: 'We will take those additional contributions from motorists and put them into Consolidated Revenue'. When the Minister was in opposition he fought day after day in this chamber to maintain what he considered to be a proper profile for road programs in Australia. He did it consistently and forcefully. But as soon as he became the Minister he was rolled. He has proved ineffective because he cannot maintain the proportion of funds which should go into the bicentennial roads program.

The funds provided by the program are significant and important. I am expressing today my extreme disappointment that the Minister has proved to be so ineffective in maintaining the real level of contribution through excise to this program. One has only to look at the great needs around the country to understand why that level of effort needs to be maintained. If one looks at the way in which road programs are funded, at the categories of roads throughout Australia, one will recognise that funds from the bicentennial roads program apply both to national roads and to State governments and that a small proportion of them also applies to local authorities. Those local authorities have shared to a minor degree in the bicentennial roads program.

Just last week this House witnessed a delegation of local authorities from western Sydney visit the House to raise the problems regarding the categorisation of roads and the way in which road funds were applied. The main contention they put forward is that the gap, the roads that lie between local roads and State roads, is a no-man's land to which neither the State governments nor the local authorities feel they should contribute. I put the proposition to the Minister that if only he could gain the sympathetic ear of the Treasurer and if only he had the capacity to express forcefully the views that he knows are right and sound, he would gain additional funds from this program which could well be applied to the specific needs of local and State governments.

The Western Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils comprises nine local government authorities and covers a vast area of western Sydney, an area of 350 square kilometres. Over the last 20 years those councils have experienced a massive growth rate. Even at the moment the growth rate is running at something like 2.2 per cent each year. The population is growing to that extent. It is now over one million people. It is, in fact, an area much larger than Tasmania. It represents four times the population of Canberra and twice the population of Tasmania. That is the size of western Sydney, an area which is experiencing a significant problem in regard to roads.

The funding programs which the Commonwealth have instigated have tended to ignore the difficulties that are faced by local authorities in such a fast growing area. The Western Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils put a series of propositions to the Minister for Transport about what the councils' needs were in regard to roads. Most of them are substantial needs which could easily be solved by the Minister saying that he is prepared to go in to bat to gain the additional funds which should rightly be going to roads and by his being willing to have State governments apply those funds to particular areas of need. The increase in the total funds available to the western Sydney councils has risen each year-and that is without the bicentennial roads program-by approximately 7 per cent to 9 per cent. The Minister would be aware that the bicentennial roads program has supplied an additional small amount. But in western Sydney no roads are classified as national highways. Consequently, the region does not have access to half the moneys which the Commonwealth makes available for road works. Furthermore, since national highways quite rightly have a high priority, none of the roads passing through western Sydney which are equivalent to national roads have priority for funding in any way.

The Minister was asked whether he would agree to extend the national highway system to cover the area. I do not believe that that decision would be proper. The area contains none of the roads which make up the great capital city link- the national grid. Therefore, the Minister could not satisfactorily make such a decision regarding that area. But the councils in the western region of Sydney rightly pointed out that they face a non-recoverable road cost which has been estimated to be about $540 per lot in new residential developments. Residents expect and traffic usage requires suburban standard roads with the appropriate widths. These are more expensive to maintain than two-lane, rural local roads. Yet many of the councils concerned have lost their rural road funding.

The Minister was asked whether he would agree to change the current formula for urban local road grants so that it would recognise the problem of need. I do not know what the Minister said in regard to that question. But a needs base for programs such as that is something that the Commonwealth has tended to reject, holding the view that, in fact, it is properly a decision for State governments. In regard to State governments, the councils said of the Government of New South Wales:

Despite numerous submissions and discussions with the State Government, there has been little action on WSROC proposals for special programmes to finance urban growth in the Region. In addition, new Government charges and extensive cutbacks in some grants have combined to produce an even more difficult situation. Until 1981-82, the State government's Local Government Assistance Fund used to provide over one million dollars per year for the ten Councils of Western Sydney; it has now been abolished.

So we have a situation where the State Government has walked away from the problems and the councils are saying to the Federal Minister: 'Will you please consider us as a special case?' I await with great interest the Minister's response to their plea. I believe that there is only one way in which this problem can be solved. The Minister must go into the Cabinet room and get the right proportion of fuel excise applied to petrol. He must have those additional funds applied to areas of need such as those in western Sydney. Some 6,500 to 7, 000 new building lots are put in place each year in this area of Sydney. That imposes tremendous strains on transport planners. As I have said, the link between the local road systems and the main urban arterial roads falls into a no man's land where neither the State Government, nor local government because of its lack of capacity, can do anything in planning or upgrading the system. I want the Minister to take that on board and to take action. He has done a terrible thing in denying the appropriateness of an indexed 2 per cent of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund moneys being paid out to the motorists. They have made the contribution; the funds should go back into roads.

The final aspect of this legislation about which I wish to complain is the Minister's decision to move away from a contractual basis for the construction of roads. The Minister, as shadow spokesman when in opposition, said on a number of occasions that he did not like the process of contracts. He is being consistent in this legislation. In fact, at one stage he moved an amendment proposing that State governments be given the option of choosing contractors to carry out road programs. An amendment moved on 28 May 1981 said in part:

. . . moneys paid to the State in accordance with the grant are required by virtue of this Act to be expended on the carrying out of an approved project by way of the construction of a national road, the State, in its discretion, may invite, and deal with, tenders for those works.

I draw that to the Minister's attention because it will very quickly become clear to him what will happen when the tender process goes and the contractual program instigated by the previous Government is abandoned. He will quickly find that the situation which applies to the construction of Housing Commission homes in New South Wales will apply also to the road construction program. He may not be aware of it, but there is a surcharge of 25 per cent on the cost of every house built by the New South Wales Housing Commission. That comes about in this way: There are very tight arrangements with the unions because there is an approved list of builders. The builders must ensure that every man on the site is a member of a union, whether he be a sub-contractor or deemed to be an employee. The cumulative effect of that process of having approved builders and a unionised site is that costs have risen to 25 per cent above private enterprise construction, side by side on the same land.

I say to the Minister that we will go back to the situation where Commonwealth funds will eventually build a smaller proportion of roads. For the same money he will get fewer miles of road. The funds will not go as far as they should and a massive backlog will accumulate which future governments will have to pick up. I think it is not a good decision. It is one to which the Minister has been committed for a long time, and one with which I heartily disagree. It will prove to be unsound, uneconomic, and a false economy in the construction of roads under the bicentennial roads program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before moving into the text of what I want to talk about on the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill and the Roads Grants Amendment Bill, I believe it is appropriate to set the record straight. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), spoke about the indexation of the excise. In seven years the previous Government quadrupled the revenue it was getting from Federal fuel-related matters. When honourable members opposite talk about what we have and have not done and about our backing off some commitments, it has to be stressed that not only did they do that but also they trebled the price of petrol in seven years. When they talk about the bad deal transport is getting under this Government, they should look at their record. Their performance was abysmal. I repeat: The previous Government quadrupled Federal fuel-related revenue in seven years. That was the burden the economy bore.

SPEECH.PARA: We know a lot about what happened to the economy under the previous Government. It went into a severe recession, and one of the reasons for that was the increase in costs generated by the previous Government. The increased transport cost was one which had a severe negative effect upon the economy. The previous Government trebled the price of petrol as well. In effect, it reduced real expenditure on roads by $520m in its seven years in office. That is not a very good record, and it is not one which should cause honourable members opposite to take this Government to task. In fact, this Government has met its commitments. The Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) has met his commitments. When in opposition the present Government was critical of the low priority accorded to roads. Given that many honourable members opposite speak about how important roads are and how they will build roads, between 1975-76 and 1981-82 Federal assistance to the States for roads declined by 23 per cent in real terms. That is just one example of the Fraser economic vandalism, and it occurred in regard to roads and in many other areas. I could talk for a long time in this place about its mismanagement, and that is one example.

Late in its term of office, the previous Government introduced the Australian bicentennial road development program. We supported the program at that time and we have supported it since we came to office. Before we came to office we made a very clear statement about our transport goals. It is to the credit of the Minister, and I congratulate him, that he is putting these goals into operation. In my electorate of Stirling it was very important that the construction of the Mitchell Freeway should continue under this Government, and it has. We had a guarantee; we have had consultation. The electors of Stirling recognise that, and I congratulate the Minister for it. I am very impressed by the Government's performance and willingness to consult. It is not good enough for honourable members opposite to come in here and talk about deficiencies. It is always possible to find deficiencies. They are very marginal. The reality is that the performance is there and this Minister is delivering. The electors of Stirling know he is delivering because the Mitchell Freeway is proving to be a substantial boon to them, and I will come back to that subject later.

In our transport policy statement we made some commitments. They were, firstly, to accelerate construction of the national highway system, which was originally begun under the Whitlam Government; secondly, to continue assistance to States for the construction of other roads; thirdly, to continue the ABRD program, which was initiated by the previous Government and which we followed through; and fourthly, to establish a jobs on local roads program. Before I comment on the JOLOR program, I want to give a couple of figures. For 1983-84 total Commonwealth allocation to roads amounts to $1,233m, an increase of 45 per cent over the $851m expended in 1982-83 and the largest increase in nearly 40 years. I repeat: The figure went from $851m under the previous Government to $1,233m, an increase of 45 per cent and the largest increase in 40 years. It is not good enough for the honourable member for Mitchell to come into this place and say that it is about time the Minister for Transport got into Cabinet and started fighting for roads. If that is not fighting for roads, if that is not delivering economic results, the honourable member for Mitchell has a very unusual grasp of arithmetic. The performance is there and it is very telling.

We know that the arithmetic of honourable members opposite is faulty, because somehow the deficit that was supposed to be around $6 billion blew out to $9.6 billion. I say that because, in the face of that massive deception by the discredited former Treasurer, we were able to continue funding roads. It is a credit to the Minister that he was able to win the fight for that funding. Even in the tight budgetary circumstances that we faced when we came to office, we were able not only to increase spending on roads, but to increase it massively- by 45 per cent. That is a real performance. As I say, the national accounts were not in the best of health when they were handed over to us. In fact, they were very shaky indeed. The Minister and this Government have taken up the issue, and they have delivered.

I want to address some other issues. JOLOR has been a substantial success for this Government. It is certainly a success in the electorate of Stirling. However, I would like to see more funds spent in the electorate of Stirling. We need to ensure that we do as much as we can in terms of job creation. One of the areas that I think it very important and very impressive in respect of the JOLOR program is that it permits local councils to do some innovative and important things with respect to road construction, maintenance and the upgrading of areas around roads, including one area in which I am particularly interested-the construction of bicycle paths, which is a very important issue. Those funds are well used in the central areas of cities in Australia. I know many people in the electorate of Stirling are very concerned about that. I compliment the Government and the Minister on the fact that JOLOR funding is enabling us to allocate funds to that. I add that we must have a commitment to obtain further funding for that and the local council must become more flexible in looking at the issue. We certainly need a strong commitment in terms of JOLOR.

It has often been difficult to meet some of the guidelines under JOLOR because of the labour and materials arrangements involved. But I certainly believe that with proper consultation and with assistance from Federal members such as myself and local councils we can persist in that area. JOLOR will provide $70m in 1983- 84. That is an important part of the community employment program. I believe it is one of the issues of which we in this place can be justifiably proud, because we did inherit an economy that was in substantial recession, in addition to which there was a high degree of unemployment. The JOLOR program is one way to deal with that unemployment. I find that a very satisfactory area of endeavour.

I turn to the issue of national highways and the objectives for construction of national highways in Western Australia. Two particular projects concern me: The completion of construction and sealing of the Fitzroy Crossing-Halls Creek and Newman-Port Hedland sections and the widening of the narrow pavement from Wubin to north of Meekatharra on the Perth-Darwin national highway; and also the commencement of reconstruction and widening of the Eyre Highway west from the South Australian border on the Perth to Adelaide national highway. They are two very important projects to which I want to relate very briefly. They are important projects because Western Australia is on the verge of a substantial boost in tourism. I believe that the proper upgrading of roads that this national highway program envisages will be an important contribution to tourism. We must recognise that, despite the efforts made in the area of air fares by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) and the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley)-and they have been very impressive efforts-we still have in Australia a desire by many people to travel around the country in their own motor vehicles and to take the family with them. It is important, in light of that, that the national highways system is up to standard.

This Government has carried through what I would call an important Labor tradition that started with the Whitlam Government-that of having up to standard national highways. I am very pleased to see that further efforts will be made in that area. Certainly, it is appropriate to talk about the things that we can expect towards 1987 and 1988, because a tourism boom will develop in Western Australia towards 1987 and 1988 for the obvious reason that there will be a substantial yacht race contested there and many other tourism matters will develop at that time. The development of national highways ties in with that. I am very pleased to be able to say in this place that that will be an important development.

I will talk specifically about two projects closer to the electorate of Stirling. Two projects to cost $44m were approved in Perth's urban arterial roads. The $30m project on the Beechboro-Gosnells Highway will involve construction of a high standard four lane road, including a major bridge over the Swan River, from the Leach Highway to Morley Drive. That is important for my colleagues who represent the electorates of Moore and Canning, because that will certainly improve transport for their constituents, but it also impacts upon people in my electorate, because it will enable them to travel around Perth. For those who might not be familiar with the road to which I have referred, it is in effect a ring road. It provides a very good ring road service that circles the north and east of the city. It is a very important development, and I am pleased to see that that is happening.

Within the electorate of Stirling the other project, which will cost $14m, involves the construction of stage 5 of the Mitchell Freeway, to serve increasing travel to and from Perth's expanding northern suburbs. I was pleased to be in the company of the Federal Minister when he visited Perth with respect to stage 4 of the Mitchell Freeway, and now stage 5 is underway. We had the co- operation of the State Minister. The consultation and co-operation provided by the Federal Minister and the State Minister gives great encouragement to members such as myself in the electorate of Stirling. My colleague the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard) faces the transport issue that I face. The northern suburbs of Perth have expanded very rapidly and the Mitchell Freeway is central to the whole construction plan and the transport plan of the north of Perth.

As the economy is being rejuvenated-the housing program is doing a great deal towards that-it is important that if people are looking at buying houses and living in that area they can be sure of getting to and from the city, to and from their friends' homes, to and from relatives' homes and to and from work. The Mitchell Freeway offers that possibility. I certainly commend the Minister, as I said at the beginning of my speech. It was gratifying to know that before we won government it was possible to consult and to feel that that important project not only would be continued but would be persisted with and advanced under this Minister. That has been a great boost for me, because one of the things it has done in regard to my electorate is that it has improved the local road issue.

There are many problems. As everyone in urban Australia knows, when we have rapidly developing populations and people need to get to and from their places of leisure and work often people's lives are totally disrupted by through traffic. The way to improve this substantially is to spend money on major roads and thereby move traffic on to those major roads. That is what we have done in the case of the Mitchell Freeway. I am pleased to see that the funding for that project will continue, because already in my electorate we are seeing an enormous move of traffic from the West Coast Highway, which clearly is not capable of taking that traffic, which provokes a lot of traffic hazards and which has downgraded the quality of life for those people along the West Coast Highway. All of that traffic is being moved inland onto the Mitchell Freeway. It has meant that people can now move into the city to their places of work. They can travel to the important industrial area of Osmond Park with great ease. The safety conditions have improved remarkably. I believe that that is a great factor in favour of this Government. It is one thing that we can be proud of, the Minister can certainly be proud of and I know that the electors of Stirling are proud of, because we are doing a very good job in that regard.

One issue we must take up involves the State Government. We have some difficulty in Western Australia-I am sure that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, would recognise this point-in ensuring that traffic keeps to the left. Traffic seems to spread all over our lovely roads. That is an issue that we will try to take up with our State Government to ensure that, as in some of the other States, drivers intelligently keep to the left unless overtaking. It is a problem that we will have to take up. If we build these good roads and we make sure that people have access to those roads, we must make sure that the conduct on those roads is appropriate. Some of the traffic matters around Canberra tend to approximate some of the traffic matters around Perth. This makes one feel at home from time to time. Certainly, it is an issue that we will be able to take up with the State Government. We have good relations with the State Government and we will be pleased to take up that matter.

The record of this Government is good. The record of the Minister for Transport , in fact, is quite outstanding. I will close by citing the figures. In 1983-84 total Commonwealth allocations to roads amounts to $1,233m, an increase of 45 per cent over the $851m expended in 1982-83. It was the largest increase in nearly 40 years.

It is not good enough to quibble about the excise. Incidentally, we have done the intelligent thing about fuel excises; we have indexed them. What those opposite have to face is that they trebled the price of petrol in four years. They cannot blame it on the Arabs; they did it themselves and they have to live with that. In addition to that, they quadrupled Federal fuel-related revenue in seven years and they reduced the amount of spending on roads by $520m. We have increased the funding. We have done a substantial thing in terms of road development and there is a lot to be proud of.

Might I say in concluding that I think it important that we talk in this debate about the performance of this Government. It is a substantial performance. I say to the honourable member who is trying to interject that between 1975-76 and 1981-82 federal assistance to the States for roads declined by 23 per cent. I know that the former right honourable member for Wannon was a mean and miserable Prime Minister. He was also mean and miserable about roads. Those opposite have to cop that. The Australian people copped that, but they did not cop it for too long because, come March 1983, they gave him his marching orders. They put in a government that has done a substantial job on roads. It has done a substantial job on the economy. We have the economy going again. We have roads going again and we have Australia going again; and the important thing is that we have all people in Australia going again, not just the narrow sectional interest whom those opposite purported to represent but who gave them the bye-bye and will continue to do so. I am pleased to commend these Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The condition of roads in Australia affects all the people of Australia. I believe it is very important that the Commonwealth is very closely associated with the funding of all categories of roads throughout the continent. I know that in recent times the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) has spoken a lot about the additional funds available today from the Commonwealth for roads generally, but I think that our minds should be fairly clear here. I think our people understand that the reason more money is available for roads today is simply the Australian bicentennial road development program. The Minister has said that an extra 40 per cent is available to be spent on roads. This may be true, but it is there because the previous Government decided upon the initiative of the bicentennial road development program into which the Minister and the Government have now stepped so that they are able to allocate more for roads generally within Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: There are three ways in which the Commonwealth assists: Firstly, under the Roads Grants Act, which is virtually the petrol tax; secondly, under the tax sharing arrangement; and, thirdly, under the bicentennial road development program. These are three very important funds which bring the Commonwealth into line to a very great degree with the upkeep and building of roads throughout Australia.

Naturally I am opposed to the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill today simply because it takes away one or two of the initiatives in the original legislation. As I have gone around the countryside over the years, attending meetings of a council, a progress association, a farmers' association or a chamber of commerce, people have indicated to me that it is time these road and bridgeworks went out to contract. Any sensibly-minded Australian would agree with that. I have no criticism of the ability of the people involved in the day-labour scheme to do their job vigorously. I have found that the Department of Main Roads in New South Wales is a well organised body which has carried out its work particularly well. But should not people and certainly private contractors have the right to be involved in this major development within the country? That is why I emphasise that private enterprise should play its part.

The Department of Main Roads, or the main roads boards, or whatever they might be termed in the States, along with local councils, all have the opportunity to submit tenders in respect of any bridge or roadworks. I suppose that the Minister and the Government will say: 'But we are not taking that option away from them'. I claim that in the clauses of this Bill the Minister is taking away the opportunity for councils or States to call tenders. The clauses are fairly watertight. They let councils or States out so that they can carry on their work under a day-labour scheme. I feel that the Minister might well have amended the Act completely and taken the option of tenders completely out of it, because that is virtually what the amendments before the House at present will do.

Let me say something about the indexation of the 2c per litre fuel excise. What has occurred is that the Government has taken approximately $450m away from roads and bridging expenditure within Australia over the term of the bicentennial road development program. Were there no indexation that large amount of funds could go to the States, to the national roads program and, importantly, to local councils for work on local roads. It is a shame to see the Government taking away these funds.

Another aspect of the Bill is that it gives greater scope or flexibility to each of the States to spend more money on their urban transport systems. I know that the original Act provided for this, but we were amazed that during the State election Mr Wran decided that he would spend $40m on water and road transport within the Sydney metropolitan area. In other words, we found that $ 40m was going to be spent on the purchase of craft for the harbour and maybe for buses that were not even going to be produced in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Importing them.

—That is right; importing them. The bicentennial road development program created at least 8,000 jobs directly and another 20,000 jobs indirectly. Here we find a government, I suppose because of political expediency, which was actually determined to spend money in those areas I mentioned. I have no objection to that. But I do object to the employment atmosphere of that decision . These moneys, under the true meaning of this legislation, should have been spent on roads that are vital to our country towns and our rural communities. That is why I emphasise that the actions of this Government, which came to power only a year ago, have virtually taken away money that could have been allocated to the rural roads of Australia. These roads are terribly important to those of us who live in country electorates. I do not know what honourable members on the Government side of the House think when they study the legislation. I wish they would say what they think about the effect that this legislation will have in virtually taking away funds from the expenditure available for important roads in the areas they represent.

SPEECH.PARA: Roads are important to this country's economy. They are productive. They are necessary to get our products to the market for shipping. As I said earlier, they affect every Australian, whether on the way to work, taking a product to a market or touring. Certainly they are important to defence. We have talked a lot about defence in the House throughout the week. If we look at the nitty gritty of this Bill we will see that it contains more that will actually assist the defence of Australia than any other item we have talked about through the week.

We are providing for l6,000 kilometres of national road around Australia and, under the Bill, we shall be providing funds for the arterial roads of Australia. I can think about roads within my electorate of Lyne. Most honourable members who have spoken in this debate spoke from a parochial point of view of roads within their electorates. I do not blame them for that, because they are a typical illustration of the problem that faces the nation in regard to building up the provision of roads and bridging. In my electorate there are a number of arterial roads which are neglected, which the State fails to recognise, and on which local councils do not have the money to spend. They are literally going into disrepair because of the lack of funds.

The Minister and I had a look at the Medowie Road, main road 518. I know that the Minister is keen to assist with it. But the New South Wales Government has not made it a number one priority. I can understand that to a degree, because in the Port Stephens Shire there are other very important arterial roads to be dealt with. The road to Nelson Bay carries a tremendous amount of local traffic, yet the council is unable to upgrade it because the moneys cannot be made available for that.

Forster is the headquarters of the Great Lakes Shire. There are roads in that area that need attention immediately, but the council does not have the money to spend. There are local roads in the Greater Taree city area, such as the road from Nowendoc to Walcha, which is terribly important so far as the meatworks, the timber industry and tourism are concerned and to the many graziers who live along that road. However, I am pleased to say that it was the nomination of the council for bicentennial road funding, and there is to be an allocation of money for that road-about $700,000 over the six-year period. But that will do only a mile or so. Here is an important road linking the coast and the tableland area, for which the Cattlemen's Union of Australia and other groups have agitated for years. I have raised the matter previously and I have fought for it within the New South Wales Parliament and here. There is a road which is so important for linking up the tablelands with the coast in order to get people and produce through quickly. The same can be said for the adjoining shire, the Gloucester Shire. It has a main arterial road going back to Walcha. But it is important that this road, when dedicated, should be able to take any form of traffic.

The Pacific Highway is a vital road serving the New South Wales coast including the whole area north of Newcastle right up to the Queensland border. The honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) spoke today about Tweed Heads and the by-pass area, but here is a road that is incapable of continuing to carry the traffic that runs over it every day. I am often on that road, and it is nothing, of a night-time, to pass up to 15 very large trucks, following each other bumper to bumper, bringing produce down to the Sydney markets for sale. This road is growing in importance.

Australia is so dependent upon road transport. I know that we have the railways , and perhaps it is a shame that we are not using them more than we do. But the Australian people are accustomed to roads. They are accustomed to owning a car. They are accustomed to having their produce from farms coming to them mainly by road transport. As regards the centralisation of industry, people are establishing industries in country areas only if they are able to obtain the place upon a truck to send goods directly to a destination. They do not want to take goods and to load them upon a train because that involves handling them three or four times. These are the factors which we must appreciate.

I am somewhat concerned about the attitude of the New South Wales Government, particularly with regard to the tax sharing arrangements. Over the last year that Government has gained, within the State, about $176m under the tax sharing arrangements. Almost $70m of that has been taken from the councils by the State Government in extra charges. The New South Wales Government has now loaded more on to the councils with respect to the rebate for pensioners. The councils now have the responsibility of finding about $30m for that. There is an extra charge with the Board of Fire Commissioners. The New South Wales local government assistance fund has been abolished. That was $9.5m a year.

I hope that the Minister notes very closely that what is happening-no matter who is sitting on the Federal Treasury bench, and no matter what extra funding we are prepared to give to the States under the three schemes of which I spoke earlier-is that the State of New South Wales is putting those extra charges on to the councils concerned to relieve its own expenditure. This is an important matter. It is quite unfair for a State government to do this when the cry from the people is that we want more money spent on roads. I trust that the Government will take that matter on board and will try to influence the States to the view that they must put their expenditure into roads, too, and try to relieve the local government scene. Our roads are a worry to us. Our shires, cities and municipalities are not able to keep up to a reasonable standard the rural and urban roads within their areas. Ratepayers have reached the maximum of what they can afford to pay. There is a problem here. The Commonwealth has a great responsibility to invoke the legislation which will go directly to councils and to keep an oversight on that in the States. We must ensure that, as we provide the extra moneys, the States do not take the money away.

I was delighted and honoured, and actually excited, when we introduced the bicentennial road development funding program. We on the Opposition benches just do not like to see that legislation tampered with. We do not want to see private enterprise prohibited from tendering to build the roads and bridges of Australia . The people are calling out for more initiative by private enterprise, which is efficient, and the councils, as I indicated earlier, and the departments of main roads and the road boards, were able to compete. They themselves won quite a lot of contracts, so why should we remove this provision now? Once we prohibit private enterprise contractors, the long term effect of the legislation-as with many other features of legislation that the Government undertakes-will be that we shall eventually deprive the working man of work in public services. I oppose the removal of these parts of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill and the Roads Grants Amendment Bill amend certain arrangements under which financial assistance is made available to the States and the Northern Territory under the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act 1982 and the Roads Grants Act 1981. The amendments are the result of consultation and detailed discussions held with the States, local government, industry and the relevant unions.

SPEECH.PARA: Three areas were identified where amendments were required to these Acts. First , many objections were raised against the requirement that all construction work on national, urban arterial and rural arterial roads go to tender. Secondly, the provision requiring the States to maintain in real terms their expenditure on roads for the duration of the Australian bicentennial road development program was stated to be impracticable. Thirdly, objection was taken to the policy of applying additional conditions to a State which had exercised the option of directing part of its urban arterial roads allocation to urban public transport projects without providing additional funding.

The amendments contained in the Bills are, therefore, designed to improve the effectiveness of the implementation of the Government's road programs and to ensure that taxpayers receive the maximum advantage from expenditure of public moneys under these programs. The requirement to call tenders for specific works had a profoundly adverse effect on road construction in north Queensland. The Minister stated in his second reading speech that the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill 1984:
. . . allows the Minister to approve an exemption from the requirement to call tenders for specific works where a State can demonstrate to the Minister's satisfaction that:
there is an emergency requirement for the works to be performed, or
the works are of such a minor nature that calling tenders would involve undue additional cost, or
it is not practical to prepare adequate tender specifications for the works, or
the works are of such a kind that competitive tenders are unlikely to be received, or

the works involve adjustments to utility services which would normally be undertaken by a government department, a government authority or a corporation not primarily responsible for the construction of roads, or
the performance of the work under contract would cause unavoidable retrenchment or inefficiency in the deployment of a substantial number of State or local government road construction employees.

In addition, the requirement that State urban public transport expenditure be maintained in real terms where the State has exercised its discretion to use part of its urban road allocation for urban public transport capital works projects is no longer necessary. Transport absorbs more than one-quarter of the national resources and is a large and critical item in government Budgets. Therefore, effective management of Australia's transport resources is basic to the nation's well-being. In this regard the Federal Government's commitment to improve the road network is clearly demonstrated in its transport policy statement issued prior to the March 1983 election. The statement provided undertakings to accelerate construction of Australia's national highway system. The statement recommended a continuation of the Australian bicentennial road development program to provide worthwhile employment opportunities for the nation's unemployed. It called for the establishment of a jobs on local roads program. In 1983-84 total Commonwealth allocations to roads amounted to $l,233m, which represents an increase of 45 per cent over the $851m expended in 1982-83. It is the largest increase in federal expenditure on roads in nearly 40 years.

Three programs are being administered by the Federal Government to provide effective management of Australia's transport resources. First, $778m was allocated in 1983-84 under the Road Grants Act program. This represented a 6 per cent increase in expenditure over the year 1982-83. Secondly, $385m was allocated in 1983-84 under the Australian bicentennial road development program. This sum is more than treble the 1982-83 expenditure of $117m. Thirdly, the jobs on local roads program has been enthusiastically adopted by councils in all States. An amount of $70m has been allocated in 1983-84 for this program as an element of the community employment program. Additional employment opportunities have been created and the backlog of local roadworks is now being reduced.

However, particular emphasis has been given by the Hawke Government, an authentic Australian government, to the upgrading of the national highway system , with 42 per cent of total funds being allocated to this program from 1983-84 onwards. The Bruce Highway is the declared national highway connection between Brisbane and Cairns. The condition of the highway between Townsville and Tully is inadequate for a national highway which is serving an area undergoing a rapid degree of development. This area of Australia is benefiting from a growing national and international tourist trade. In recent years resource development and commerce have also become major growth industries.

Visitors to north Queensland frequently complain about the primitive condition of the Bruce Highway. Long term residents recall that just over 20 years ago the Bruce Highway was split into sections of trafficable road. It should be recorded , however, that it was not until 1962, some 13 years after the Menzies Government took power, that the Bruce Highway from Brisbane to Cairns was completely sealed. The Bruce Highway has really existed as a sealed through route on the present corridor only since that time. Prior to World War II the Bruce Highway was not a through road.

The costs of providing an adequate highway standard are enormous. Northern Australia is subject to heavy rainfall. Falls of more than 750 millilitres of rain have been recorded in a 24-hour period. Numerous streams and rivers traverse the highway corridor. This requires the construction of more bridges than would be required in dryer regions of Australia. An increased standard of pavement is requird to cope with conditions of heavy rainfall and road foundation instability. The cost per kilometre of road construction in north Queensland is significantly higher than in other parts of Australia. It is estimated that road and bridge construction costs amount to approximately $600, 000 per kilometre in north Queensland.

The Townsville office of the Mains Roads Department is responsible for the maintenance and enhancement of some 444 kilometres of the Bruce Highway. This office is ably led by the extremely competent Assistant Commissioner in north Queensland, Dick Wharton and his District Engineer, Ron Piper. More than 50 kilometres of national highway are under construction or are about to commence construction in the Townsville area. Over the last two years 15 single-lane timber bridges have been replaced. Work is under way to replace an additional seven single-lane timber bridges. The program provides that all of these dangerous single-lane bridges on the Bruce Highway in north Queensland will be replaced by 1987. An allocation of $9.4m for road works was made to north Queensland by the Fraser Government in 1981-82. The Hawke Government has allocated $20m for road works in this region in 1983-84. In other words, the road allocation has more than doubled.

The amendment to allow the Minister to approve an exemption from the requirement to call tenders for specific works in certain circumstances is welcomed by the people of north Queensland. Prior to the introduction of the Australian bicentennial road development program, the Townsville office of the Main Roads Department employed 67 people in its day labour force; that is, three road and three bridge construction gangs. The Fraser Government's action in requiring that all construction work on the national highway be given to private contractors has now reduced that work force to 35 employees. Every effort has been made by the Townsville Main Roads Department to retain its day labour force . Employees retained have been engaged on maintenance tasks on other road works. The main roads day labour force is vital for the efficient operation of the Main Roads Department in north Queensland. It enables the Department to retain employees with significant expertise and experience in road construction techniques.

North Queensland highways are subject to flooding and frequently become impassable during the wet season. Road damage is caused by washouts during cyclones. Vital communication links are severed during these times. It is the responsibility of the Main Roads Department in these circumstances to re- establish road communications as soon as possible. The cities and towns of north Queensland depend on the Bruce Highway for the carriage of fresh fruit and vegetable supplies, daily milk supplies and a host of other goods and services. Obviously, it is vital that the highway remain open all year round. In addition, 80 per cent of tourists travel to north Queensland by road and use the Bruce Highway.

The upgrading of the Bruce Highway will enhance Australia's defence self- reliance by improving the mobility of our defence forces and their supplies and equipment. The highway will be a vital communications link for defence purposes. Recent defence studies have been directed towards greater utilisation of civil road transport assets. Clearly, there is a need for an effective process of consultation and co-ordination between the defence forces and the road transport industry.

Notwithstanding the commitment of the Hawke Government to upgrade the Bruce Highway urgently, the road continues to remain extremely hazardous for unwary motorists. In 1983, 15 per cent of all road fatalities in Queensland occurred on the Bruce Highway. The tragedy of loss of life on the national highway from Brisbane to Cairns can be reduced only by an urgent acceleration of the reconstruction of the Bruce Highway. The Hawke Government should be applauded for its expansion of the national campaign against drink driving. This campaign, together with improved road conditions, will hopefully reduce loss of life on our national highways.

Of particular significance is the amendment requiring both State and local governments to show to the satisfaction of the Minister for Transport that the performance of the work under contract would cause unavoidable retrenchment or inefficiency in the deployment of a substantial number of State or local government road construction employees. The amendment requires the State or local government to demonstrate that it has taken all practicable action to avoid this problem. For example, the Hawke Government has allocated $2.5m to reconstruct a section of the main street in Ingham later this year. As a result of this amendment, the Main Roads Department intends to construct this work using day labour employees. Many government services, including telecommunications, electricity, sewerage and drainage will be affected during reconstruction. During construction traffic will be inconvenienced and business houses may be adversely affected. In these circumstances, it would be folly to allow the work to be carried out by a contractor over whom the Department would have little influence in protecting the interests of business people and motorists.

The Federal Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) has travelled the Bruce Highway in the Herbert electorate on at least three occasions during the last few years. Without his positive and constructive intervention to provide funds for the improvement of this section of the national highway, motorists would have continued to be exposed to unnecessary hazards and risk to their lives and the lives of their passengers. Not only has the Bruce Highway benefited from the generosity of the Hawke Government but also local authorities in my electorate have been major beneficiaries of massive Federal Government grants for road works. This has permitted the replacement of dangerous single lane bridges, the upgrading of important arterial roads to bitumen standard, and the reconstruction, widening and bitumen sealing of numerous other roads in every local authority area in my electorate.

The jobs on local roads program has been a major boost to local government road construction in north Queensland. It is funded through the community employment program and will, therefore, generate additional worthwhile employment opportunities. The sum of $70m is provided this financial year for the construction and maintenance of local roads and cycle paths. The provision of cycle paths, particularly outside high schools, has been welcomed by education authorities in north Queensland. Finally, the Hawke Government will continue to speed up the construction of the national highway system. It will continue consultation and discussions with State and local governments to ensure that Federal road grants are passed on in full to their intended recipients. It will provide the legislative framework for a national roads policy that for the first time since Federation will enable Australia to develop one of the finest road transport systems in the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill and the Road Grants Amendment Bill are of great importance and interest to honourable members. However, I express my concern at what is happening in the Parliament at the moment. I refer to the paucity of legislation that the Government has available to bring before the Parliament in the interests of the Australian people. The Opposition opposes these Bills. They certainly could not be called heart stoppers, Bills that offer magnificent hope to the Australian people in the areas such as the economy, defence, industrial relations, unemployment, or any of the major issues confronting the Government. It is interesting to note that in the six or seven days on which the Parliament has sat so far during this sitting period the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill attracted 14 speakers, the Appropriation Bills attracted 19 speakers, the Torres Strait Fisheries Bill-a very minor Bill-attracted four speakers, the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Bill attracted eight speakers, and on Thursday 29 March one small Bill attracted 13 speakers and another attracted 12 speakers.
—Order! I ask the honourable member for O'Connor to make his remarks relevant to the Bill.

—The relevance of my point is that it is time the Government came forward with some legislation for the Australian public. It is great if one does not mind speaking two or three times a day, and some of the Bills are worth while, but the Government is not delivering legislation of consequence to this place.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. The roads legislation before the Parliament is of vital importance to millions of Australians. I am sure there are honourable members on the other side of the House who would like to speak on the subject of roads. Maybe they can be given the opportunity.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—In addressing myself to these Bills, I start by referring to some of the statements of the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards). The honourable member, like everybody else on the Government side, thinks that the Government can govern in a negative fashion. Provided it can make a comparison with the previous Government, which is now the Opposition of today, and say that the previous Government was worse, that is sufficient for it not to be very good . That is not a position this Opposition takes any more. We are not responsible in many ways for the attitudes of another day.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member again brought up the $9.6 billion deficit issue. The other day the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford) told us we were a mob of meanies because we would have spent $2 billion less had we been on the Government benches at this time. Somebody will have to make up his mind in the Government or we will get double counting to the point where there would have been no deficit at all. If there is something good about that, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) might tell us why he has now discovered that forward estimates are illusory. He had great fun with them last year. The honourable member for Stirling, if he were present, might take the time to tell us how the Government, confronted with all these terrible financial problems, managed to increase expenditure on its programs by 7.5 per cent. That is the reality of the situation.

I am more interested now to raise matters relating to current problems. The O' Connor electorate has 48 separate local authorities and many miles of roads, probably more than some larger authorities are responsible for. It is quite densely populated in rural terms and it requires many roads to link its 170 small towns. I have stated already that the Opposition is opposed to this legislation. It is a pity that the legislation we are debating is not designed to overcome the ridiculous and disgraceful decision of the Government not to keep a commitment related to ABRD funding, that is, the commitment to pay on any additional funds that are earned by indexing the 2c levy. It has been said in the Parliament today, and in round figures it is estimated, that during the life of the ABRD legislation the automatic indexation of excises that has been introduced by the Government will raise slightly less than $500m and take some $ 60m from local government alone.

I guess it is worth repeating in this House the frivolous attitude of the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) to this very serious problem. When the previous Government brought in this legislation it was well aware of the avaricious attitude of governments towards fuel taxes and how they have refused over the years to recognise that there should be a link between taxes collected on fuel and expenditure on roads. Government after government has rejected that argument, particularly when it has been put by local government. The previous Government said: 'We will give you some money that you can identify. More importantly, we will create a trust fund to put it in'. That was something the back bench of the Liberal Fraser Government was very keen on. We had little trust in any administration keeping its sticky fingers off the money. The 2c levy is now locked in, and no government would be game enough to try to steal it . But now we have a new trick whereby the Government indexes that amount of money, banks the proceeds and uses them in some obscure fashion. If Government members think that only local government is upset about that it ought to talk to some of the truck drivers. The Minister had his one rough ride to Newcastle and probably has not got into a truck since. He should ask the truck drivers what they think now about something they accepted because they could look out the front of their trucks and see some improvement on the roads. They could see where their money was going. Now they know they are being conned.

Let us look at the frivolous approach of the Minister when a question was put to him on this subject. His answer is recorded in Hansard of 29 February. The honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) asked:
I address my question to the Minister for Transport. Is it a fact that the fuel levy of 2c a litre for the Australian bicentennial road development program is indexed?
The Minister said:

One could say that the bicentennial road levy component of the total excise charged on fuel is indexed as a result of measures in the last Budget. But the bicentennial roads legislation enacted by the previous Government of those honourable members opposite who are now chiacking about it did not provide for other than 2c a litre of the levy to be directed to the trust fund for road expenditure.

What a frivolous and disgraceful answer to what was, even from his own back bench, a sensible question. The Minister should have been smart and put a sweetener in this legislation to which we object. He should have done what the Western Australian Government does. It comes into the House with proper legislation, then puts in a piece of socialism and tries to force local government into accepting it. It will not succeed. But the point is that the piece of legislation first brought to this House by the Minister under the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Act made provision to transfer the results of that indexation to the trust fund. It would have been as simple as ABC. It is quite wrong to suggest for a minute that the previous Government had some fault. Quite clearly the previous Government would never have been sufficiently avaricious to go down the track of this Government. Let us get that point settled at the start.

There is another interesting part to that and other honourable members have referred to it. We get this double counting again. The Minister tells us that in fact there has been a 45 per cent increase in road funding under this Government . I think the honourable member for Stirling said something about that. As I have told honourable members before, when we get down to statistics I have great fun in reminding people that it is a statistical fact that lions have killed more Western Australians than sharks have. That is a useless piece of information, but it is true. The fact is that the claim of 45 per cent is in the same category. Let us look at why.

Firstly, we find that the ABRD levy was only 1c in the first year and then it doubled to 2c. That had nothing to do with any decision taken by this Government . Furthermore-this is a fact-by the time the processes of application had all gone through in the first year only $7m of the $27m available got to local authorities. So all of a sudden we have this massive double counting, counting the full result of the previous Government's decision and the full result of the 2c a litre levy. Of course the Government has written to them and said: 'We are not too game to give you 100 per cent of what was promised, we will give you only 80 per cent'. Nevertheless, I guess the Government has a reason for that, although I doubt that it needs to vary the sum by 20 per cent, with the figures that are available today. Maybe there is some profit to the Government, maybe the interest that has been earned has not been sent off yet. Let us just remember what that figure would do to the Government's expenditure. Of course it had nothing to do with the Government.

Let us look at the wonderful double counting effort where we add the $70m of jobs on local roads program funding. JOLOR is a really interesting exercise. Every time the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) speaks in the House he tells us about JOLOR, which he says is one of his programs. It is a form of community employment program. Then the Minister gets up and says: 'I spent the $70m'. We are double counting that $70m. It is a fact that that money expended on roads is not necessarily being used productively, for various reasons. The principal reason is that, as honourable members know, JOLOR has an extremely high labour component. It has requirements relating to the employment of unemployed people and it limits the ability of local authorities to do good, productive and constructive road works with the high quality machinery that the authorities have today. Of course, we do not build roads with picks and shovels any more. If we did we would not have many roads.

The JOLOR program is not the province of the Minister for Transport. It should not be thrown around as part of these 45 per cent figures, because clearly it is a make work program and, like all the other make work programs, it is artificial and does not do much for roads. Nevertheless, local government will take the money and it will do its best with it. It is, of course, being confronted with more and more difficulties of matching grants that exist on this and other CEP programs. I predict that by next year many local governments will have to reject a lot of this money because they just cannot afford it. I am not from New South Wales, but the people tell me it is doubly difficult there because of the interference of the New South Wales State Labor Government, which will not even let them increase their rates for the purpose of raising money to gain some of the Federal Government's matching grants to create employment, useless though some of that employment might be for the future of Australia.

These are the sorts of situations we get when people start this wonderful percentage business. Of course we must remember how easy it is to increase some of those figures. There was no base in the ABRD prior to last financial year. How quickly can the Government get the percentages up? The Government should tell us how much more money was spent and how much of it was spent on initiatives of this Government, not on initiatives of the previous Government. That is the sort of situation to which we have to address ourselves. It is quite a problem.

I refer to the legislation and explain again why the Opposition objects to some of these amendments. I have some experience and knowledge in the arena of local government and public road construction as I was a member of a local government authority for some 16 years. In fact, I was also President of the Country Shire Councils Association in Western Australia for the two-year term available to me. I was a State grants commissioner in Western Australia for four or five years, handling the Federal funding that came to local government. During that time I spent hours and hours and weeks and weeks talking to local government authorities throughout the State of Western Australia about the problems. So I do know what I am saying.

What is this Bill proposing to do? It wants to take out the very real and sensible move of the previous Government to see that tenders are called for major construction work. I say 'major construction work' because the Act as it stands refers to urban arterial and rural arterial roads. It does not refer at any time to those little $30,000 and $40,000 grants given to most local authorities. It talks about the big stuff. I think the previous Government and the then Minister for Trransport, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), were able to concede to local government that those small projects which in some way are being insidiously introduced into this argument now were not necessarily to be tendered for. Generally local authorities, other than some very large ones , were not obliged to tender for their minor works. I have no objection to tenders not being called for certain works. If some of the words that now appear in this Bill will help to tidy things up I do not mind very much. These works include: Emergency works, works of a minor nature-although I believe they were previously covered-works for which it is not practicable to prepare adequate tender specifications, works of a kind for which competitive tenders are unlikely to be received and the cost of some other works done by other departments, although I view the latter with some concern. Then all of a sudden we get to this ripper, as set set out in the explanatory memorandum:
Performance of the work under contract would cause unavoidable inefficiency in the deployment of a substantial number of State and Local Government road construction employees.

Of course we are then warned that this last provision also requires the State or local government to demonstrate that it has taken all practical action to avoid this problem. Those are roughly the words in the Bill. Paragraph (f) in clause 3 continues:
. . . even if the State or authority were to take all practicable steps to avoid that occurrence.

What do those few words mean? They mean nothing. What they mean is that a person has to be a smart engineer. I knew plenty of smart local government engineers. In local government we were experts at working the system. That is what we were there for. We were there to represent the people who elected us. It did not matter whether it was a regional employment development scheme, a CEP or any of these types of grants, one very smartly came to grips with the situation. One did not act in a dishonest fashion, but on behalf of one's electorate one made sure that if that was the way one wanted it one achieved it. Once we get into that type of complicated statement anybody can win the day. Of course, if there is a particular union around that wants to see a heap of its members employed and not the members of a firm working under contract, those sorts of conditions will be established without doubt.

The pity of it is that if the Government had really wanted to look at some good Australian private enterprise it might have done something the previous Government did not do. It might have made some provision for expenditure by sub- contract, compared with full contract. The sub-contractor, particularly in some of the more remote areas, is the greatest asset to the community that can be found. He represents hard-working private enterprise in his own field and he is a man who will get a lot of work done. Trucking sub-contractors in an otherwise day labour-type operation will lift the game for everybody present. They want the dirt, will cart the dirt and put it on the road and make sure everyone else keeps up to that rate of work. These are the sorts of things the Government could have done if it wanted to relax the system.

The Government might have brought in something which provided for the situation to be viewed differently in remote areas on the grounds of maintaining a work force in the area to address itself to the various problems that occur from time to time. That would have been commonsense. That would have been good stuff and maybe we could have understood it. Every piece of legislation can stand some improvement. But the facts are that this has nothing to do with that.

One of the other matters to which the Bill addresses itself is the provision requiring the States to maintain their expenditure in real terms. Two other sections really cover that; they cover the situation regarding expenditure on roads and expenditure on public transport. What a disgrace it will be. People think that this money is going to roads. The State governments are equally able to work the system. One of the effects of this wage rise will be to lift average earnings from their present level of $19,453 to $20,251. That will have the effect of putting many more workers into the 46 per cent tax threshold bracket, which cuts in at $ 19,500. Most workers who are earning wages above that figure will now be paying 46c in every extra dollar they earn. Obviously that situation will have a serious impact. In addition, increased Medicare payments will flow from the increased income, and that will add up to something like 15c a week for the fellow on average wages. On top of that, there is the automatic indexation of the excises, and that will flow on as a result of the 4.1 per cent decision handed down today. So in overall terms this is not something which will help the economy. It is not something which will help the recovery of the economy or the necessary investment in our economy.
