SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words-not very many, actually-in response to the honourable member for Dawson ( Mr Braithwaite), who spoke earlier about the changes that will take place as a result of the Government's decision on coastal surveillance. As he would be aware, when I made the announcement last Friday I gave an undertaking to the House that we saw the decision as being of sufficient importance to give the House the opportunity to debate this matter when we resume after the Easter break. I did that in co-operation with the shadow Minister of State, the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), so that he would be aware of this matter. I will reply to a couple of points because it seems to me that perhaps the honourable member for Dawson, rather than leading newspaper opinion, has been led by it. He made a couple of observations which are not true.

SPEECH.PARA: It seemed to the Government on taking office that this was an area that had been somewhat neglected in terms of offering an overview of what was happening, the structure of command of coastal surveillance, and updating the user departments on what was required. Subsequently, as we interpreted it, the former Government had almost placed it in the too hard basket. We asked the Minister for Aviation and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) to carry out a review of the requirements of our coastal surveillance, which he undertook for several months. He talked to departments and travelled extensively throughout the north of Australia. He looked at what was required and at what was being done. Ultimately he made the decision that coastal surveillance ought to be based in a department that had a career structure, and that had a relationship with the enforcement of the laws laid down by this Parliament. I think that the recommendation he ultimately, made-if one is so guided by the newspaper reports-has been accepted as the correct decision by the Government; that is, that the Australian Federal Police should be in charge.

As I said in my statement to the House, it has not been the traditional role of the defence forces to enforce the laws as such. It is not a role that they feel they should play. In supplementing the coastal surveillance operations throughout Australia we are not changing their role. But we are recommending and putting into place certain rationalisation based upon the user departments of coastal surveillance-departments such as the Department of Primary Industry, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and, particularly, the Department of Health which felt that for its purposes as a user department it was being utilised far too much, far beyond its requirements and it was far too costly for its needs.

In terms of the criticisms of people who may not have their terms extended, obviously, as the honourable member would know, people make a commercial decision when they tender for a government contract, whatever their field may be . They make their capital investment based on the successful tender that they may be granted, and that is what these people have done. It is not a question of their being given an opportunity to retender, because we are redeploying. I have seen some reports in the Queensland Press that some people were upset because they felt that Queensland firms were missing out and firms from another State were perhaps coming in. It is true that Skywest Airlines Pty. Ltd. has been described as a Western Australian firm. But in my opinion and on the information which I have already given the Parliament Skywest, by virtue of its takeover of H. C. Sleigh Industries Ltd. in Queensland, is as much a Queenland company now as it is a Western Australian company. It will do the additional work that is required in the redeployment that will take place.

As I said in my statement to the Parliament, we will also talk to the Queensland, Western Australian and Northern Territory governments about the deployment of the units of Commonwealth police, where they will be located and under what circumstances. Within a week of the House rising for the Easter break I will travel to Darwin with the Commissioner of Police to talk about those matters. Very shortly afterwards I will travel to north Queensland and the north - west of Western Australia also to hold discussions about those questions. We have set up what might be called a ministerial council, of which I will be chairman. All the departments that are affected by it-the Department of Transport, the Department of Defence, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the Department of Primary Industry and so forth-will be part of it. The new measures will be monitored very closely and if changes are required by virtue of our circumstances those changes will be made.

I assure the honourable member, in view of what he said about drugs, that the emphasis of the new coastal surveillance system will be very much on drugs. That reinforces our decision to put the AFP in charge. With the new coastal protection unit which has been set up within the coastal surveillance area, which will be run by the AFP-supplemented, of course, by the normal procedures carried out by our defence forces, be they Army, Navy or Air Force-we believe we have now set in place with the proper structure a more constructive coastal protection unit than we had previously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too want to reply briefly, although most of the points I would have made have been covered appropriately by the Special Minister of State (Mr Young), who is now in charge of coastal surveillance. Reference has been made to whether there will be increased vulnerability of the northern coastline to the possibility of the importation of narcotics. I do not know whether the criticisms that have been made in that regard are made in terms of deliberate ignorance, or simply ignorance. The fact of the matter is that the coastal littoral search, which covers the particular contractual arrangements for littoral surveillance which were under consideration at the same time as my report and decisions on it were announced jointly, have absolutely nothing to do with drug surveillance, and never have. They were associated in the first instance with the requirement of the Department of Health for quarantine and, in the second instance, at least to some extent, with the requirements of the Department of Primary Industry in regard to fisheries and also, to some extent, in the case of Queensland, with the requirements of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment in relation to the Great Barrier Reef. The only alterations that have been made in terms of their impact on surveillance in any of those areas have been in the Department of Health. It was determined that the extent of the surveillance that it conducted for its own purposes was not necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: Littoral surveillance in the way in which it has been carried out for the purposes of drug interception is virtually valueless. For that very good reason, it is not being used for that purpose. That was the situation that existed under the previous Government. A number of planes and boats in the north of Australia are involved in that activity. They are associated with at least by the Australian Customs Service and of course, they are not in any way affected by this decision, except that now those assets, along with the littoral surveillance assets and the assets of the Department of Defence, will be combined with those additional assets that will be given to the Australian Federal Police, and we will have a properly co-ordinated surveillance activity.

Far from depleting the capacity of coastal surveillance to deal with the problem of the illegal importation of narcotics through the north of Australia, we are now, in a coastal surveillance sense, in a co-ordinated fashion addressing that problem for the first time. It was not addressed by the previous Government in the context of the littoral surveillance that it offered. Unfortunately, but perhaps to some extent understandably, there has been a little too much concentration in the northern Press on the question of littoral surveillance, and not enough recollection of the very relevant criticisms that they have made from time to time that coastal surveillance was not serving any valuable service in regard to narcotics and was not being accompanied by appropriate efforts at enforcement. I agree with many of the criticisms that were made, not least by those people associated with papers in the north and, of course, with the governments in those areas. For the first time the Commonwealth is accepting a co-ordination responsibility for that exercise. Given the financial constraints under which we are operating and the requirement for further investigation of our needs in that regard, under the formula and the framework worked out by the Commonwealth it will be the first time that those very important needs will be properly addressed.
